However it is not necessary to make the diagnosis of pancreatitis in this patient with epigastric pain radiating to the back and severely elevated lipase and amylase. IV fluid resuscitation should take precedence over obtaining a CT scan.  
❌ Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in acute pancreatitis is not recommended. Antibiotics should be reserved for patients with evidence of infected necrosis or extra-pancreatic complications.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Incorrect: ERCP is indicated within 24 hours of presentation if there is evidence of acute pancreatitis with concurrent acute cholangitis. Stabilizing the patient takes precedence.  
❌ Administration of intravenous morphine:
Incorrect: While pain management is a crucial aspect of treating acute pancreatitis, it is not the first step. Aggressive fluid resuscitation remains the initial priority.

questions.text:
A 91-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive abdominal distention and lack of bowel movements for more than a week. She is nonverbal but accompanied by her adult son who provides additional history. He states that she has a past medical history of hypothyroidism, hypertension, osteoarthritis, constipation, and a recent stroke. She is no longer able to ambulate and spends much of her time in bed. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 142/81, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, she appears mildly uncomfortable, her lower abdomen is moderately distended, and there is a palpable left lower quadrant mass. A hard mass of stool is palpated in the rectum. An X-ray of the abdomen and pelvis is performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

From Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive lower abdominal distention, absence of bowel movements, a palpable abdominal mass, palpable stool in the rectum, and is found to have significant rectal and colonic fecal burden on imaging, which is consistent with fecal impaction.

Fecal impaction occurs when the patient’s baseline peristaltic activity is insufficient to pass stool normally, resulting in a bulky fecal mass impacted typically in the rectosigmoid bowel. When chronic, fecal masses can harden and calcify into one or more fecaliths, or form a single large mass called a giant fecaloma. This patient has multiple comorbidities that are risk factors for fecal impaction including advanced age, hypothyroidism, history of constipation, and immobility. Physical examination findings associated with fecal impaction can include abdominaldistention and mild tenderness to palpation. In thin patients, the examiner may be able to palpate fecal masses in the colon, and hard impacted stool is typically present in the rectum on digital rectal examination.  

Option Analysis

❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: In rare cases a patient with a large bowel obstruction and an incompetent ileocecal valve can reflux large bowel contents into the small bowel and present with signs and symptoms that mimic SBO. However, in this case, the imaging demonstrates a large colonic fecal burden and no evidence of small bowel dilatation.  
❌ Sigmoid volvulus:
Incorrect: Sigmoid volvulus occurs when the sigmoid colon twists along its mesentery resulting in closed-loop mechanical obstruction of the large bowel. X-ray imaging in that case would show a distended loop of large bowel (Coffee Bean Sign), which is not seen on this imaging.  
❌ Toxic megacolon:
Incorrect: Toxic megacolon is a complication of severe colon infection or inflammation resulting in significant dilatation of the large bowel in the absence of mechanical obstruction. It is frequently associated with systemic toxicity such as sepsis. This patient has a large rectal and colonic fecal burden seen on x-ray, and signs and symptoms consistent with fecal impaction.  
✅ Fecal impaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perforated sigmoid diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Perforated sigmoid diverticulitis can be categorized using the Hinchey Classification system, which distinguishes between pericolonic or distant abscess, as well as generalized purulent or feculent peritonitis. X-ray imaging findings, in this case, are not consistent with perforated sigmoid diverticulitis and are consistent with fecal impaction.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a history of cocaine use presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden, severe chest pain. The pain began approximately 2 hours ago shortly after using cocaine. She describes the pain as 'tearing' in nature. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 36.7°C (°F), blood pressure is 192/108 mmHg in both arms, pulse is 108/min, respirations 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears in distress. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. ECG is significant for sinus tachycardia. Which of the following should be ordered next to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a sudden, severe, “tearing” chest pain in the setting of cocaine use and severely elevated blood pressure, which is highly suggestive of an aortic dissection. This life-threatening condition occurs when blood enters the medial layer of the aortic wall through a tear in the intimal layer, creating a false lumen. Cocaine use is a known risk factor due to its hypertensive effects. The best next step in the evaluation of this hemodynamically stable patient is to obtain a CT angiography of the chest for diagnosis and classification.  

CT angiography (CTA) of the chest serves as the primary diagnostic method for suspected acute aortic dissections in stable patients as it provides detailed visualization of the aorta. If a patient cannot undergo CTA due to a contrast allergy or severe renal impairment, an MRI angiogram (MRA) can be used instead. If the CTA or MRA reveals a normal aorta without any signs of dissection, alternative causes should be considered such as myocardial infarction, pericarditis, or pulmonary embolism.  

If imaging reveals an intimal flap and a double lumen involving the ascending aorta, regardless of whether it extends to the descending aorta, Stanford type A aortic dissection is diagnosed. If the imaging reveals an intraluminal flap and a double lumen in the descending aorta only, this is indicative of a Stanford type B aortic dissection. Management differs depending on the type of aortic dissection, with type A requiring emergent surgery and type B often requiring medical management first.  



Option Analysis

✅ CT angiography of the chest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum troponin levels:
Incorrect: Serum troponin levels will likely be part of the diagnostic workup. The tearing nature of the pain and the absence of ischemic changes on ECG in the setting of highly elevated blood pressure following cocaine use is more consistent with a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection, not an MI.
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) rather than a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is indicated in the evaluation of acute aortic dissection for hemodynamically unstable patients. Transthoracic echocardiogram is not as sensitive or specific as CT angiography or TEE for the diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect:  An abdominal ultrasound is indicated in the evaluation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm, not acute aortic dissection.  
❌ Serum D-dimer level:
Incorrect: While D-dimer may be elevated in aortic dissection, it is also elevated in other conditions like pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis. For this patient with a likely aortic dissection, a CT angiogram should be performed.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after his wife found him unresponsive upon returning from a trip to the grocery store. The wife states that he had been complaining of left leg pain, chills, and fatigue for 1 day. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes treated with insulin, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. The patient is responsive only to pain. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, pulse is 117/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient appears acutely ill. The left lower extremity is shown below. It is erythematous, indurated, warm, and firm to the touch. Crepitus is felt on palpation. The patient is started on IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Labs are ordered and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  


Reproduced from wikipedia

choices.text: CT of the left lower extremity
Radiography of the left lower extremity
Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for evaluation of rapidly progressing pain in the left lower extremity, chills, and fatigue and is found to be in septic shock. The patient has evidence of warmth, swelling, induration, and crepitus on exam. Crepitus indicates the destruction of subcutaneous tissues by gas-forming organisms. Crepitus which can feel like tiny pops of air or crunch under the skin indicates destruction of subcutaneous tissues by gas-forming organisms and is an indication of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is the most aggressive form of necrotizing soft tissue infection (NSTI) and is considered a surgical emergency. An emergent surgical consult should be called for exploration, debridement, and wound cultures. Debridement with removal of the infected and necrotic tissue is the only effective method of source control.    

Necrotizing soft tissue infections, or NSTIs, refer to rapidly progressing infections resulting in necrosis of the epidermis, dermis, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and muscle. NSTIs can occur anywhere in the body and can rapidly lead to limb loss, systemic toxicity, and death without surgical source control. Of the various types, necrotizing fasciitis is associated with the highest mortality rate because of how quickly it can spread throughout the body. Patients often present with rapidly progressing pain, erythema, edema, induration, evidence of necrosis, foul-smelling wound discharge, and crepitus.  

Due to the rapidly progressing nature of NSTIs, patients may be hemodynamically unstable requiring appropriate resuscitative measures including intravenous fluids, empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, and vasopressor support if they are unresponsive to fluids. Emergent surgical consultation should be called for confirmation of the diagnosis by visualization in the operating room and debridement and to obtain wound cultures.



Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.  
❌ Radiography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.  
❌ Infectious disease consultation:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings consistent with a necrotizing soft tissue infection. The patient requires broad-spectrum antibiotics at this time and emergent surgical consultation for operative debridement and wound cultures. Antibiotics can be tailored and infectious diseases consulted when wound culture results return  
❌ Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe sharp right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates toward the right lower thoracic back. The pain began that morning. The pain in the back is not improved or worsened with movement. Her symptoms are accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 150/78 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, pain is elicited upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this patient’s referred back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. These findings are concerning for acute cholecystitis. This patient’s pain in the right upper quadrant is due to irritation of the gallbladder and is considered somatic pain, which refers to pain located directly at the site of injury (e.g. pinprick on the skin).    
The patient is also experiencing referred pain to the back due to visceral referred pain. Referred pain is located away from or adjacent to the organ involved. Patients with acute cholecystitis often experience referred pain in the right lower thoracic spine, ribs, and right shoulder.   

Referred visceral pain occurs due to spatial and temporal summation of general visceral afferent (GVA) pain fibers. GVA pain fibers follow sympathetic nerves back to the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. As these preganglionic sympathetic fibers route to the spine and central nervous system (CNS), the CNS is unable to perceive the spatial location of the pain since it is lost at the level of the nerve ganglion. As a result, the pain is poorly localized and often referred to the dermatomal areas innervated by the same spinal level as the autonomic nerve supply. Consequently, when there is abdominal pathology, foregut pain is usually referred to the epigastrium, midgut to the umbilicus, and hindgut to the pelvis or hypogastrium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Greater thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lesser thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut
❌ Lumbar splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the hindgut
❌ Sacral nerve roots S2-4:
Incorrect: Sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4 provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe abdominal pain. The pain started approximately eight hours ago and was initially located in the periumbilical region. The pain increased in severity and became more localized to the lower right abdomen. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Using the image below, which of the following best identifies the location where this patient will be most tender with deep palpation?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with abdominal pain that originated in the periumbilical region and subsequently became more severe and migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. These findings are concerning for acute appendicitis.     

Appendicitis occurs due to obstruction and inflammation of the appendix. Initially, the visceral afferent fibers are stimulated and poorly localized abdominal pain or pain around the umbilicus is seen. As the appendix becomes more inflamed, the adjacent parietal peritoneum is irritated, and the pain becomes more localized to the right lower quadrant. On examination maximal tenderness with deep palpation at McBurney point will be seen. McBurney point is located two-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the right anterior superior iliac spine. Pain with deep palpation in this region is highly concerning for acute appendicitis and is called McBurney sign. Follow-up imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) should be obtained for further evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Location 1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location 2:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can initially manifest with referred pain in the periumbilical area, represented by location 2. However, the pain will often localize to the right lower abdominal quadrant. Maximal tenderness will be experienced with palpation at McBurney point, represented by Location 1, which corresponds to the base of the appendix  
❌ Location 3:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology.
❌ Location 4:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness in the suprapubic region indicated by Location 4 can be due to processes affecting the pelvic organs (e.g., cystitis, endometritis). In contrast, this patient’s history and physical examination are concerning for acute appendicitis, which may present at first with referred periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower abdominal quadrant. In acute appendicitis, maximal tenderness with deep palpation is typically seen at McBurney point, represented by Location 1.  
❌ Location 5:
Incorrect: Pain around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology. Left anterior superior iliac spine pain or tenderness is not typically seen with acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IV cholangiocarcinoma, for which she is receiving chemotherapy. Periodically, the patient develops ascites, for which abdominal paracentesis is performed. However, the patient was lost to follow-up. The patient is brought to the emergency department by her daughter with diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. On admission, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended and shifting dullness and a fluid wave are present. There is diffuse guarding with abdominal palpation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain in the setting of large-volume ascites due to end-stage liver failure caused by cholangiocarcinoma. These findings are concerning for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).    

SBP develops when enteric bacteria translocate from the intestinal lumen and infect the ascitic fluid. This occurs as a complication of liver disease due to increased permeability of the small intestinal wall and impaired immune defense mechanisms. SBP is a common cause of peritonitis which is defined as widespread inflammation of the inner abdomen wall and covering of the abdominal organs (the peritoneum). In addition to SBP, other causes of peritonitis include gastrointestinal tract perforation, infection due to surgical interventions, systemic infection, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Key signs and symptoms of peritonitis include fever, diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, abdominal rigidity, and paralytic ileus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of nitrogenous metabolites:
Incorrect: Accumulation of nitrogenous waste products, such as ammonia, can occur secondary to liver failure and may cause altered mental status or hepatic encephalopathy. However, hepatic encephalopathy does not cause fever and abdominal pain in the presence of ascites as seen in this case. A better explanation for this patient’s constellation of symptoms is SBP.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Large fluid shifts can be seen in patients with end-stage liver disease and they can result in symptoms of dehydration and even nausea and vomiting. However, dehydration would not account for the patient’s fever, abdominal pain, and ascites.  
❌ Tumor lysis syndrome:
Incorrect: Tumor lysis syndrome causes metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia), leading to acute kidney failure, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. This patient’s fever, abdominal pain and distension, and altered mental status are more likely caused by spontaneous bacterial peritonitis..  
❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Small bowel obstruction can lead to perforation and subsequently peritonitis. However given the presence of shifting dullness and fluid wave indicating ascites and the history of end-stage liver disease in this patient, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is the most likely cause of peritonitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and nausea for the past several hours. The patient vomited once and saw a small amount of blood in the vomitus. His past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient has not experienced similar symptoms before. He is not prescribed any medications, but he routinely takes multiple ibuprofen tablets for headaches. He took several tablets for a severe headache this morning that would “not go away.” He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and does not consume alcohol or other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness with no guarding. A complete blood count shows a hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows a deep, bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb. Bleeding from which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (abdominal discomfort, nausea, and hematemesis) in combination with endoscopic findings of a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb, is consistent with the erosion of the ulcer into the gastroduodenal artery, which perfuses both pylorus and the proximal part of the duodenum. Risk factors for bleeding duodenal ulcers include Helicobacter pylori infection, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use, and smoking.  

Posterior duodenal wall ulcers are more prone to bleeding than anterior duodenal ulcers due to the posterior relationship of the gastroduodenal artery. In contrast, anterior duodenal ulcers involve the anterior wall, and are prone to perforation but not bleeding. Duodenal ulcers are more likely to bleed than are gastric ulcers.  

Gastric ulcers commonly involve the lesser curvature of the stomach at the junction of the body and antrum. The left and right gastric arteries run along the lesser curvature of the stomach and can bleed from gastric ulcers. The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas), and is rarely eroded by posterior gastric ulcers.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic artery:
Incorrect: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas) and is rarely involved in bleeding posterior gastric ulcers. Posterior duodenal wall ulcers with bleeding do not involve the splenic artery.  
✅ Gastroduodenal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding from a gastric ulcer. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the left gastric artery.  
❌ Right gastric artery:
Incorrect: The right gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding secondary to gastric ulcers. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the right gastric artery.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left and right gastroepiploic arteries run along the greater curvature of the stomach. They will not bleed with posterior duodenal wall ulcerations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and early satiety for the past three months. His clothes are looser than usual. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history, drinks alcohol occasionally, and does not use other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, pale, and cachexic man. Abdominal examination is significant for an enlarged spleen on palpation. CT scan abdomen shows an irregular mass arising posteriorly from the greater curvature of the stomach and compressing the splenic vessels. If the mass continues to enlarge, tissue supplied by which of the following vessels is most likely to be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation suggests a gastric tumor compressing the splenic vessels posteriorly. The splenic artery originates from the celiac artery and courses superiorly to the pancreas, giving off branches to the stomach and pancreas before reaching the spleen. These branches include: 
  •  Greater pancreatic artery and dorsal pancreatic artery 
  •  Short gastric arteries 
  •  Left gastroepiploic artery 
  •  Posterior gastric artery 
The short gastric arteries supply the fundus of the stomach along the proximal greater curvature where they have very poor anastomoses if the splenic artery is blocked. Therefore, this area is vulnerable to ischemia in the case of splenic artery blockage. In contrast, the left gastroepiploic artery which supplies the body of the stomach at the greater curvature forms strong anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery, and this region is usually spared from ischemia if the splenic artery is blocked.  



Option Analysis

✅ Short gastric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery arises from the celiac artery and runs along the superior portion of the lesser curvature of the stomach. It anastomoses with the right gastric artery, which runs right to left. Splenic vessel compression would not involve the lesser curvature.  
❌ Gastroduodenal artery:
Incorrect:  Gastroduodenal arteries (branch of the common hepatic artery) supply the pylorus of the stomach and the duodenal bulb. This region would not be affected by splenic artery obstruction.  
❌ Proper hepatic artery:
Incorrect: Proper hepatic artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery, which supplies blood to the liver and gallbladder. Splenic artery obstruction would not affect these structures.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies blood to the body of the stomach along the greater curvature. It forms an anastomosis with the right gastroepiploic artery (branch of the gastroduodenal artery). Therefore, this region of the stomach would not be at risk for ischemia with splenic artery blockage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with COPD is undergoing repair of a torn shoulder labrum. The patient develops tachypnea and respiratory distress as the orthopedic surgeon prepares for surgery. While in the preoperative suit, the anesthesiologist performs an interscalene nerve block. Vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 26/minute,  pulse is 109/minute, blood pressure is 101/67 mmHg, and SPO<sub>2</sub> is 81% on 2L nasal cannula.  Physical examination demonstrates a frail man with increased work of breathing and faint end-expiratory wheezing. The patient subsequently undergoes rapid sequence intubation with the demonstration of bilateral breath sounds following endotracheal tube placement. Which anatomic structures were most likely implicated in this patient’s abrupt change in respiratory status?
questions.solution:
An interscalene nerve block anesthetizes most of the territory innervated by the brachial plexus and is generally performed on patients undergoing shoulder, upper arm, or elbow surgery.  Landmarks used to perform this procedure include the interscalene groove, which is found between the middle and anterior scalene muscles at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra, which is approximately at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Nerves anesthetized during this procedure include most of the brachial plexus, sparing the ulnar (C8-T1) nerve.  In addition, the phrenic nerve is often anesthetized during this procedure, resulting in ipsilateral hemidiaphragmatic paralysis. Therefore, patients with underlying respiratory conditions (e.g. COPD) should not undergo this procedure. In addition, the recurrent laryngeal nerve is often anesthetized--resulting in temporary paralysis of the ipsilateral vocal fold. Additional complications include iatrogenic pneumothorax, as well as hematoma/seroma formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Visceral pleura:
Incorrect: A pneumothorax may occur secondary to an interscalene nerve block; however, this patient is noted to have bilateral breath sounds following intubation.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve and digestive issues and slowed heart rate.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Spinal accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury manifests with shoulder/neck pain and a drooping shoulder, and weakness with overhead abduction.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a foreign body sensation in the throat. The patient reports she was eating fish soup when she felt a small bone “get stuck in my throat.” After topical lidocaine is applied to the posterior pharynx, a fishbone is retrieved from the piriform recess under video-assisted laryngoscopy. At her follow-up visit several days later, the patient reports she has noticed a slight change in the quality of her voice. Which of the following anatomical structures was most likely injured during removal of the foreign body?
questions.solution:
The piriform recess (or sinus) is a subsite of the hypopharynx. It is a recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet, bounded laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane and medially by the aryepiglottic folds.  It is a common area for foreign bodies to become lodged during swallowing.

The superior laryngeal and its branches lie deep to the mucosa of the piriform recess and may be damaged during lodging or retrieval of foreign bodies from this space. Superior laryngeal nerve damage often manifests with vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality in timbre, pitch, voice projection, and decreased sensation to the laryngeal mucosa.

Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve may result in altered sensation to the laryngeal mucosa, as this nerve only carries sensory information. In contrast, damage to the external laryngeal nerve manifests with changes in voice quality, as this nerve carries motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), when damaged, often presents with new-onset hoarseness, changes in vocal pitch, and noisy breathing.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Upon arrival, the patient has a GCS of 15, is speaking in full sentences, and has left-sided chest discomfort and shortness of breath. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates bruising over the left lateral chest wall and absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax with dullness to percussion and decreased tactile fremitus. The patient's chest radiograph is shown below. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL and platelets of 150,000 U/L. Which of the following is the best next step to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation after blunt chest trauma following a high-speed motor vehicle collision and is found to have opacification of the left hemithorax and anemia, suggesting hemothorax. Given that this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best next step is to confirm the diagnosis with CT imaging of the chest which will show a heterogeneous collection within the pleural cavity. The use of IV contrast can evaluate for contrast extravasation, which would suggest ongoing bleeding.     
Hemothorax refers to the collection of blood within the chest cavity or the pleural space. This collection can be a result of direct trauma to the chest or can occur spontaneously when patients have pre-existing clotting disorders. It’s important to address the hemothorax in a timely manner to avoid a potentially life-threatening hemorrhage, as well as to avoid the formation of a chronic fibrothorax, which is an organized clot within the chest cavity surrounding and restricting the patient’s lung from expanding.    

The first step in management of patients with hemothorax is an ABCDE assessment in order to determine if the patient is stable or unstable. Unstable patients, e.g. those with hemodynamic instability, altered mental status, or tension physiology, require immediate decompression via tube thoracostomy. This should be followed by surgical consultation and administration of blood products. Stable patients should have a full history and physical examination performed. followed by blood work including complete blood count and INR, as well as a chest radiograph. Patients with concerning findings for a hemothorax should undergo CT imaging of the chest with intravenous contrast. This specific imaging study can assess for a heterogeneous fluid collection in the pleural space and contrast extravasation, which if present suggests ongoing hemorrhage.    



Option Analysis

✅ CT chest with IV contrast :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thoracentesis:
Incorrect: Thoracentesis should be considered for patients with a suspected large pleural effusion. This patient's history and physical exam findings are more consistent with hemothorax.   
❌ Ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Point of care US can be used in cases of unstable patients with suspected hemothorax. This stable patient should have CT imaging with IV contrast which has the ability to determine if IV contrast extravasation is present indicating ongoing bleeding.  
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is indicated in the management of large pericardial effusion and tamponade. This patient has opacification of the left hemithorax which is suggestive of a hemothorax.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. She has had five episodes of cystitis and an episode of pyelonephritis over the last year. The rest of the history is unremarkable, and she does not have any other medical conditions. Family history is noncontributory. She has not been sexually active for the last six months. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic tenderness. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is shown below. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathophysiology of this patient’s findings on the CT scan?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT scan shows both renal lower poles pointing medially and seen fused across the midline by an isthmus of functioning renal tissue. This abnormality is known as horseshoe kidney and affects about 1 in 500 people.  

Normally, the kidneys rest in the retroperitoneum between the T12 and L3 vertebrae after ascending from the pelvis. In some patients, the kidneys are fused mechanically at the poles where the central isthmus of the horseshoe kidney lies anterior to the aorta and posterior to the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). During fetal development, its ascent is arrested by the IMA.    

Most patients are asymptomatic, and for these patients, the horseshoe kidney is diagnosed incidentally. It, however, increases the risk of ureteropelvic junction obstruction, recurrent infections, urolithiasis, and renal tumors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Superior mesenteric artery:
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery arises from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta between the celiac trunk superiorly and inferior mesenteric artery inferiorly at the level of L1 vertebrae and does not serve as an obstacle for the ascend of the kidney.  
✅ Inferior mesenteric artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior vena cava:
Incorrect: The inferior vena cava is a large vein formed by the joining of the right and the left common iliac veins, usually at the level of the fifth lumbar vertebra. It does not prevent the normal ascent of the kidneys.
❌ Third part of the duodenum:
Incorrect: The third part of the duodenum begins at the inferior duodenal flexure and passes transversely to the left, passing in front of the inferior vena cava, abdominal aorta, and the vertebral column. The superior mesenteric artery and vein are anterior to the third part of the duodenum.  
❌ Urachal fistula:
Incorrect: A urachal fistula is a congenital disorder caused by the persistence of the allantois (later, urachus), the structure that connects an embryo's bladder to the yolk sac. It is usually diagnosed earlier in life.

questions.text: A 47-year-old presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful, erythematous nodule on the right arm. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 130/76 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination reveals a large, tender area of fluctuance and induration with associated erythematous changes. An incision and drainage is performed without complication following formal ultrasonography, which confirmed abscess formation. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on IV vancomycin. On day three of hospitalization, both the cellulitic skin changes and the patient’s pain level have improved. Culture shows Streptococcus pyogenes growth from the aspirated fluid. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a complicated skin abscess with systemic signs of infection. Given that this patient has responded well to initial treatment, it is appropriate to tailor antibiotic therapy and switch from intravenous to oral antibiotics that cover for Streptococcus pyogenes.

Management of a simple skin abscess includes incision and drainage, followed by monitoring for recurrence or worsening symptoms in 24-48 hours. However, patients like this one with large abscesses, systemic symptoms, associated cellulitis, or significant laboratory derrangements (e.g. markedly elevated leukocytosis) require formal soft tissue ultrasonography and cultures. Treatment for these cases includes intravenous antibiotics in addition to incision and drainage. Patients with clinical improvement after 24-48 hours can be switched from IV to oral antibiotics, with choice of agent guided by culture data. In contrast, patients with an inadequate response require repeat ultrasound to evaluate for any persistent abscess, followed by potential repeat incision and drainage, and tailoring of antibiotic therapy based on culture growth and susceptibilities.  

Option Analysis

✅ Switch to oral cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat incision and drainage:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and empiric antibiotics. Repeat incision and drainage is not indicated.  
❌ Continue current management:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous antibiotics. Additionally, culture data is now available. Antibiotic therapy should be tailored and deescalated.  
❌ Consult infectious disease:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous antibiotics. Additionally, culture data is now available to guide antibiotic deescalation. Infectious disease consultation is not required.  
❌ Switch to IV daptomycin:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous vancomycin. Culture data shows growth of Streptococcus pyogenes. Daptomycin is not warranted.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right elbow pain. He is bracing himself and making sure not to move his arm at the elbow. The patient tripped while running and fell onto his outstretched right arm, holding his elbow in hyper-extension. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling and tenderness at the right elbow with a limited range of motion. X-ray of the right elbow shows a supracondylar fracture with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. Based on this fracture pattern, which of the following actions is likely to be compromised?

choices.text: Adduction of the third and fourth digits

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supracondylar fracture and postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. This injury pattern is commonly associated with median nerve injury. Thus, the patient will most likely present with impaired thumb opposition due to thenar eminence paralysis   

Supracondylar fractures are the most common type of elbow fracture in pediatric patients. An extension-type supracondylar fracture (most common) is caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow hyperextended. The median nerve and brachial artery run anteromedially over the elbow and are most often injured with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus .    

In contrast, the radial nerve runs anterolaterally over the elbow. It is more commonly injured when the distal humerus is displaced postero-medially. This injury can lead to inability to extend at the wrist and hand.  



Option Analysis

✅ Thumb opposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adduction of the third and fourth digits:
Incorrect: Adduction of the third and fourth digits is controlled by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This patient has postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus which will most likely lead to medial nerve injury which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured in cases of postero-medial displacement of the distal fragment of the humerus. This patient has postero-lateral displacement with subsequent injury to the median nerve which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Sensation over the posterior forearm:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand occurs in patients with radial nerve injury. This nerve can be injured with postero-medial displacement of the distal humerus not with postero-lateral displacement as seen in this case.  
❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators at the elbow are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can be injured in patients with upper nerve trunk compression.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right elbow pain. The patient reports hearing a sudden "pop" in his right elbow immediately after falling to the ground with an outstretched hand. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates ecchymosis and pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle. He has full range of motion of the shoulders bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally. A plain radiograph of the right elbow is shown below. Based on this patient’s injury pattern, he will most likely have weakness with which of the following actions?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia

choices.text: Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a medial epicondyle avulsion fracture, which can  injure the ulnar nerve as it passes posterior to the medial aspect of the elbow. Fractures of the medial epicondyle tend to occur in children between the ages of 10 and 14 following injuries involving falling on an outstretched hand, repeated valgus stresses such as throwing a baseball, or via a direct blow. Medial epicondyle avulsion fractures can also be associated with elbow dislocations. Patients present with swelling and tenderness over the medial elbow and pain exacerbated with supination and flexion of the forearm, wrist, and digits.    

The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1). It is commonly injured at the elbow from cubital tunnel syndrome, fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, or fractures of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (causing cubitus valgus with tardy ulnar nerve palsy). Patients typically present with discomfort and loss of sensation/paraesthesias over the fourth and fifth fingers, weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger abduction/adduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits. Together, these findings are referred to as a “claw deformity.”   

Option Analysis

❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can become injured from upper nerve trunk compression. Injury to this nerve is not commonly observed in patients with medial epicondyle avulsions.  
❌ Thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Thumb opposition can become impaired in patients with underlying median nerve injury secondary to a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and lack of innervation to the thenar muscle.   
✅ Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wrist extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions controlled by the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can become damaged with supracondylar or midshaft humerus fractures. Weakness of wrist extension and a wrist drop can be seen with injury to the radial nerve.  
❌ Shoulder abduction:
Incorrect: Impaired shoulder abduction occurs with axillary nerve injury secondary to shoulder dislocation or proximal humerus fracture.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate chest pain that radiates to the back. The patient was out jogging when he suddenly experienced tearing chest pain that reached maximum intensity within seconds. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 22/min. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. A CT angiography of the chest is performed and shown below. Which of the following agents is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for acute management of this patient’s clinical condition?
 

 Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with tearing chest pain and radiographic evidence of a type A aortic dissection, which requires prompt management with intravenous ꞵ-blockers to reduce wall shear stress and risk of rupture. Of the agents listed, esmolol, a selective ꞵ1-blocker, is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy. Esmolol’s utility is largely due to its short half-life of only 10 minutes, which allows the agent to be rapidly titrated for blood pressure management.

Selective ꞵ1-blockers include acebutolol, atenolol, betaxolol, bisoprolol, esmolol, and metoprolol. These medications (aside from acebutolol, which has partial ꞵ-agonist activity) act on only ꞵ1-receptors. ꞵ1-receptors are found primarily in the heart and the kidneys, and lipocytes.

Indications for selective ꞵ1-blockers include the management of hypertension, hypertensive emergencies, chronic stable angina, heart failure, and decreased left ventricular function after a recent myocardial infarction. Specific indications for each drug in this class largely depend on the drug’s pharmacodynamics and route of administration. Moreover, ꞵ1-blockers can be used to lower the risk of cardiac events, stroke, and congestive heart failure in at-risk patients.

Finally, these medications are also used off-label to treat migraines, arrhythmias, and symptomatic management of anxiety or tremors.  

Option Analysis

✅ Esmolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: While metoprolol is also a selective ꞵ1-antagonist, it has a much longer elimination half-life (3-4 hours). Treatment of aortic dissection is best achieved via antihypertensives with rapid titratability.  
❌ Atenolol:
Incorrect: While atenolol is also a selective ꞵ1-antagonist, it has a much longer elimination half-life (6-9 hours). Treatment of aortic dissection is best achieved via antihypertensives with rapid titratability.  
❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: Carvedilol has both ɑ- and ꞵ-blocking effects. This medication is not routinely used in the management of aortic dissections.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a vasodilator that is not routinely used to manage acute aortic dissection due to its variable effects on blood pressure and association with rebound tachycardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic for increasing redness and pain at a surgery site on the left arm. He had a skin excision performed about one week ago to treat squamous cell carcinoma. The redness developed two days later and, since then, has been spreading. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and dyspepsia. Current medications include calcium carbonate, metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and aspirin. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 109/74 mmHg, pulse is 81/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. There is bright red erythema surrounding the excision site with purulent drainage and tenderness to light palpation on physical examination. A bacterial culture of the excision site grows methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is started on a 7-day course of doxycycline. Which of the following medications should not be taken concurrently with doxycycline?
questions.solution:
This patient should avoid concurrently consuming doxycycline and calcium carbonate. This precaution should be taken since the divalent calcium ions can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut and decrease the drug’s efficacy. Tetracyclines should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations.

Moreover, tetracyclines can accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old.  

Option Analysis

✅ Calcium carbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and metformin. Metformin can cause lactic acidosis and should be used with caution in patients with renal failure.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and hydrochlorothiazide. Hydrochlorothiazide is a sulfa derivative, so it should not be given to patients with sulfa allergies.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and lisinopril. There is a high risk of acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia when taken together. Lisinopril should not be taken with aliskiren, a direct renin inhibitor.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and aspirin. Aspirin should not be given to children, especially in viral infection, as it may lead to Reye syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a laceration to the right forearm. The patient was jumping over a fence when he slipped and sustained a 3 cm laceration to his right volar forearm. Prior to repair of the laceration, a local anesthetic agent is injected around the edges of the wound. Next, the physician performs a test of sensation to determine readiness for repair. Which of the following best lists the order in which sensations are lost after administration of the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is provided with a peripheral nerve block with a local anesthetic for repair of a forearm laceration. Prior to repair of lacerations it is commonplace to check for adequate regional analgesia--usually by gently tapping the wound edges with a pin, or the sharp end of scissors. The order of sensation loss following administration of a local anesthetic is Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure.     

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers and myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.    

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Temperature>Touch>Pressure>Pain:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics, not the last.   
❌ Pressure>Touch>Pain>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pressure and touch are lost after pain and temperature, not before.   
❌ Pain>Pressure>Touch>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics; however, pressure and touch are the last to be lost, not temperature.   
❌ Temperature> Pain >Touch>Pressure:
Incorrect: Pain is lost before temperature, not temperature before pain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of three days of worsening pain over the tailbone and the presence of a lump in that area. Sitting, walking, and stretching the skin over the area worsens the pain. He has noticed foul-smelling drainage on his underwear. Bowel movements are painless and non-bloody. The patient has no dysuria or urinary frequency. He has not had any recent falls or injuries. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient drives a truck for work. Temperature is 39<sup>o</sup>C (102.2 <sup>o</sup>F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. What findings are most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Erythema and a tender fluctuant mass over the top of the natal cleft
Longitudinal tear in the posterior midline of the anal mucosa
Tender purple mass in the perianal area

questions.solution:
This patient’s history is most consistent with pilonidal disease, which can present as an acute infection with associated abscess formation. Pilonidal disease occurs when a pore or pit forms at the top of the natal cleft (gluteal cleft) of the intergluteal or sacrococcygeal region.

Pilonidal disease often develops from mechanical forces causing skin irritation. Skin and hair follicles trap hair or other skin debris which can lead to infection and abscess formation.  Sinus tracts may develop and communicate to the outer skin layer with or without associated drainage which can be bloody, purulent, or mucoid.

Acute pilonidal infection presents with pain with compression and with movements that cause stretching of the overlying skin. Fever may be present. Retraction of the buttock cheeks may reveal erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the affected area along the gluteal cleft. Pits or pores may be seen. A painful fluctuant area or lump, with or without drainage, suggests that an abscess has formed.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema and a tender fluctuant mass over the top of the natal cleft:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Longitudinal tear in the posterior midline of the anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Anal fissures typically cause significant pain and associated blood with bowel movements.  
❌ Tender prostate gland:
Incorrect: Infection of the prostate gland, or prostatitis, can produce perianal pain, but the patient would be expected to have dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and cloudy urine.  
❌ Ecchymosis over the coccyx:
Incorrect: Injury to the coccyx can cause pain in the region, but the patient has not had a significant injury.  
❌ Tender purple mass in the perianal area:
Incorrect: A thrombosed external hemorrhoid would cause significant pain, especially with bowel movements. It is not typically associated with fever.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the primary care office reporting three months of mild sacral discomfort. He notes occasional yellow fluid on his underwear. He has not had fevers or recent injury to the area. He reports previously having an abscess drained in the sacral area. Temperature is 37<sup>o</sup>C (98.6<sup>o</sup>F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Physical exam reveals mild tenderness in the intergluteal region, enlarged pores along the natal cleft, and yellow drainage. Which of the following additional physical exam findings is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Large flaccid bullae over the sacrum
Grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the sacrum
A tender fluctuant lump with surrounding erythema in the natal cleft
Deep purple ecchymosis overlying the coccyx
Hair protruding from a sinus tract at the top of the natal cleft

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is most consistent with chronic pilonidal disease. Pilonidal disease is caused by a tract, cyst, sinus, pit, or other cavity that forms under the skin along the natal cleft in the intergluteal or sacrococcygeal region that can trap hair or other skin debris leading to acute or chronic disease. Sinus openings and natal cleft pores may be visible along the intergluteal cleft and hair may be seen protruding from the opening.

Risk factors for the development of pilonidal disease include male sex, obesity, trauma to the area, sedentary lifestyle, hirsute body habitus, and poor hygiene.

In chronic pilonidal disease, patients often have recurrent or persistent fluid drainage from one or more sinus tracts along the gluteal cleft. The area may be tender and painful or not painful, but signs of acute infection will be absent in chronic disease. A common feature of chronic pilonidal disease is a history of prior abscess in the area. Patients with acute pilonidal disease have signs of active infection including erythema, warmth, swelling, and tenderness with or without an abscess.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Large flaccid bullae over the sacrum:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of bullous impetigo, an acute superficial skin infection most commonly seen in children.  
❌ Grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the sacrum:
Incorrect: This finding would be consistent with herpes zoster, which typically presents acutely and follows a dermatomal pattern.  
❌ A tender fluctuant lump with surrounding erythema in the natal cleft:
Incorrect: This finding would be more consistent with acute pilonidal disease with an associated abscess. Given the long duration of symptoms, mild discomfort, and prior abscess, chronic pilonidal disease is more likely.  
❌ Deep purple ecchymosis overlying the coccyx:
Incorrect: This finding would suggest recent trauma to the area, which was not reported.  
✅ Hair protruding from a sinus tract at the top of the natal cleft:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. The patient has a past medical history of squamous cell carcinoma treated with surgical excision 8 years ago. He is taking amlodipine for hypertension. He is concerned about his risk of developing melanoma because his maternal uncle passed away from metastatic melanoma at 68. He enjoys outdoor activities and spends several hours outside hiking per week. He is a Black man of African descent. Vitals are within normal limits. He has dark skin pigmentation, dark hair, and dark eyes. There is a small, symmetric nevus present on his right arm. Which of the following features in this patient’s history should prompt an annual skin examination to reduce his risk of developing melanoma?
questions.solution:
Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States, and the incidence of melanoma is increasing. Patients at increased risk for developing melanoma include those who are over 50 years old, and patients with sun sensitivity (ie. red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, freckling). Nevi count greater than 50 with or without large atypical nevi, and family history of melanoma in one or more first-degree relatives or in more than one second-degree relative from the same side of the lineage are also risk factors. Immunosuppression and chronic immunosuppressive therapy place patients at increased risk for melanoma. A personal history of skin cancer (melanoma or nonmelanoma) as seen in this patient, is a risk factor for the development of melanoma. Patients who have had basal cell or squamous cell skin carcinomas have an increased risk of developing melanoma, as well as an increased risk of dying from it.    

Patients with any risk factor that places them at high risk should undergo regular dermatologic skin screening. Melanoma screening involves an annual comprehensive skin examination by a trained clinician skilled in melanoma identification. Patients should also be educated about melanoma risk factors and advised to inform their clinician if self-examination reveals any changes in moles or potentially concerning skin lesions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Current medication use:
Incorrect: Chronic use of medications that suppress the immune system (e.g. tacrolimus), can increase the risk of developing melanoma. Amlodipine has not been shown to increase the risk of developing skin cancers.
❌ Family history of malignant melanoma:
Incorrect: A family history of melanoma in one or more first-degree relatives or in more than one second-degree relative of the same lineage is considered a risk factor for developing melanoma. The history of melanoma in one maternal uncle does not increase his risk.
✅ Personal history of skin cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Skin tone:
Incorrect: Patients who have sun-sensitive skin are at increased risk of developing melanoma. This includes patients with red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, and freckling. However, this patient’s dark skin tone does not place him at increased risk.
❌ Presence of nevus:
Incorrect: A total nevi count above 50 and/or the presence of large (atypical/dysplastic) nevi would place a patient at high risk for developing melanoma. This patient has a single, small, symmetrical nevus and therefore not at increased risk from the presence of this nevus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for three weeks of discharge from the nipple of the left breast. The discharge is mostly clear, but it sometimes appears red. There is no associated breast pain, breast lump, fever, or weight loss. The patient’s last screening mammogram was ten months ago and was normal. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/83 mmHg. Chaperoned exam of the left breast reveals a smooth contour to the skin without erythema or warmth. No masses are palpated. Serosanguineous fluid can be manually expressed from the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unilateral serosanguineous nipple discharge and should have initial imaging with a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound.    

Patients with breast papillomas may present with clear or bloody nipple drainage, a palpable mass, or with abnormal findings detected on breast imaging. The initial step in the workup of a suspected breast papilloma is diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. Additional testing is indicated if ultrasound and mammogram are negative or do not show an area suitable for biopsy. Additional imaging may include ductoscopy, galactography, or breast MRI. A tissue sample, usually collected by core needle biopsy, is needed to make the diagnosis of a papilloma and assess for atypical or malignant cells as imaging alone cannot make this distinction.  

The classic histological findings of a breast papilloma are intraductal fibrovascular stalks lined by orderly layers of myoepithelial cells and ductal epithelial cells. Focal necrosis may or may not be present. A breast papilloma may be a benign lesion, or atypical or malignant cells may be contained within the mass. Low-grade proliferation of atypical epithelial cells within a papilloma is characterized as either atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) if the proliferation is less than 3 mm in size without malignant features, or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) when the proliferation is ≥ 3 mm. When intermediate or high-grade atypia is present within a papilloma, it is characterized as DCIS regardless of size. Malignant cells within a papilloma may extend into the adjacent breast tissue and cause localized or invasive carcinoma. Distinguishing between benign papilloma, papilloma with atypia, and papilloma with neoplasm will guide management and determine the need for preoperative staging, surgical treatment plan, and the post-surgical treatment plan.

Option Analysis

✅ Diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ductoscopy:
Incorrect: Ductoscopy is a technique where a small scope is inserted directly into the duct through its opening at the nipple and provides both a visual examination of the inside of the duct and the ability to collect a tissue biopsy. Ductoscopy is an option in the workup of a papilloma if mammography and ultrasound do not show a mass or other suspicious area to biopsy.
❌ Galactography:
Incorrect: Galactography is an option in the workup of a breast papilloma if mammography and ultrasound do not identify a mass or other suspicious area to biopsy. Contrast dye is injected into the affected duct followed by mammography images to outline the shape of the duct and evaluate for a filling defect.
❌ Breast MR:
Incorrect: MRI has a high sensitivity for detecting lesions in the breast. However, there is significant overlap in the appearance of benign and malignant lesions on MRI, often creating the need for additional workup, cost, and patient stress. MRI is typically done when other imaging modalities have failed to detect a lesion.
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Core needle biopsy is done when a mass or other suspicious finding is detected on imaging in a suspected breast papilloma. Imaging is needed to guide the location for the biopsy; therefore, an initial diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound should be performed first.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the office with a severely painful anal mass that he noticed 3 days ago. He has anal pain that is constant and is made worse with defecation. He has a history of hypertension, for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. He smokes ½ pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 6 beers on the weekends. Temperature is 38.4 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg, and respirations are 16/min. He is lying on his side and appears uncomfortable. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Anal examination reveals a focal area of fluctuance with erythema and induration overlying the perianal skin. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would support the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Large-volume bright red blood per rectum

questions.solution:
This patient has a severely painful anal mass. The pain is constant and worsens with defecation. The patient also has a fever and a focal area of fluctuance, erythema, and induration overlying the perianal skin consistent with the diagnosis of a perianal abscess. Purulent rectal drainage can also occur when a perianal abscess starts draining spontaneously.

A perianal abscess is a collection of pus that results from obstruction of glandular crypts of the anus. This allows bacterial growth (typically from a combination of aerobic and anaerobic organisms), and an abscess is formed. Perianal abscesses are often idiopathic, but they can be caused by Crohn disease, trauma, or cancer. Risk factors for the development of perianal abscesses include conditions that cause immunosuppression (e.g. HIV), certain medications, and diabetes.

Patients often present with severe, constant perianal pain that worsens with defecation. They may also develop fever and chills. Physical examination, which should include a digital rectal examination, will typically reveal a tender, fluctuant mass that may have purulent drainage and overlying skin erythema and induration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Purulent rectal drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fecal incontinence:
Incorrect: Fecal incontinence may occur from a number of anal and rectal conditions. However, it is not typically associated with perianal abscess.  
❌ Large-volume bright red blood per rectum:
Incorrect: This would be indicative of a lower gastrointestinal bleed. While some abscesses may lead to bleeding, the bleeding from an abscess is usually minimal.  
❌ Anal spasms:
Incorrect: Anal spasm is more indicative of an anal fissure. This patient’s presentation is consistent with a perianal abscess.  
❌ Prolapsed tissue from the anus:
Incorrect: This could be suggestive of a prolapsed hemorrhoid or rectal prolapse, but it is not typically seen with a perianal abscess.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents to the office with anal pain from sitting and defecation for the past 2 weeks. She also notes malodorous anal discharge. She has a history of 2 anal abscesses treated with incision and drainage in the past 6 months. Her medical history is notable for hypertension, degenerative arthritis, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen daily. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), pulse is 85/min, blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg, and respirations are 16/min. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Anal examination reveals an excoriated, erythematous perianal region associated with an external opening and drainage. Anoscopy reveals an opening in the anal wall surrounded by erythema and purulent fluid. Pelvic MRI reveals a perianal fistula involving 45% of the external anal sphincter and extending to the ischiorectal fossa. Empiric antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pelvic MRI shows a complex perianal fistula (involving > = 30% of the external anal sphincter and extension into the ischiorectal fossa). After initiating empiric antibiotics, a surgical consultation is needed for seton placement. A sphincter-sparing procedure should then be performed after the patient’s infection has cleared, typically in about 6 weeks.

The classification of a simple or complex fistula is made by determining the level of external sphincter involvement on imaging. Most simple fistulas do not involve the external sphincter, but if there is involvement, < 30% of the external sphincter is involved. Complex fistulas are diagnosed in the setting of > = 30% external sphincter involvement. A complex fistula can also be diagnosed if a fistula is proximal to the dentate line, if multiple tracts are present, if there are recurrent fistulas, or if there is a history of anal incontinence.

Both simple and complex fistulas should first be treated with empiric antibiotics. Patients with a simple fistula should be treated with incision and drainage and a primary sphincter-sparing procedure, such as a fistulotomy or fistulectomy. Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula lengthwise and destroying the internal lining of the fistula tract; this is usually performed in patients with no anal sphincter involvement. Fistulectomy involves the removal of the fistula with reconstruction of anal sphincters; this is used in patients with fistulas that involve external or internal anal sphincters.

If a patient has a complex fistula, a seton, which is a surgical thread, should be placed to aid fistula drainage, prevent premature fistula closure, and preserve the anal sphincter function. After the infection has cleared with the use of antibiotics in about 6 weeks, a sphincter-sparing procedure (e.g., an advancement flap, Modified Hanley procedure, ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract, fibrin sealant, fistula plug) should be performed. Following surgery, all patients should keep the area clean and perform Sitz baths frequently in order to help alleviate any residual pain and to prevent infection and future recurrence.  

Option Analysis

❌ Sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: Sigmoidoscopy may be used in evaluating a perianal fistula if an internal opening cannot be seen during anoscopy. In this case, anoscopy revealed an internal opening, and pelvic MRI confirmed the diagnosis of a complex perianal fistula. This patient should next have a surgical consultation for a seton placement.  
❌ Fistulotomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a complex perianal fistula, for which initial management is empiric antibiotics and a surgical consultation for seton placement. A sphincter-sparing procedure, such as fistulotomy or fistulectomy, should only be performed after the infection has cleared, typically in about 6 weeks.  
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Incision and drainage would be appropriate for a simple perianal fistula or abscess. However, this patient presents with a complex perianal fistula, for which initial management is empiric antibiotics and surgical consultation for seton placement.  
✅ Seton placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Local wound care:
Incorrect: Local wound care, consisting of keeping the area clean and taking Sitz baths, is important after perianal surgical procedures. However, this patient should first have a surgical consultation for seton placement.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for evaluation of a tender right breast lump. She noticed the lump three weeks ago right before menstruation, and it has not changed in size since that time. She does not have nipple discharge. She does not take any daily medications. She has regular menses and uses condoms for birth control. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the right breast is normal, and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1-cm smooth, mobile, mildly tender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There is no  bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat breast exam two weeks after the start of her menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
This premenopausal patient has a solitary, smooth, tender, mobile right breast mass, which is characteristic of a breast cyst. Breast ultrasound is the next step to confirm the diagnosis and to determine if aspiration or core needle biopsy is necessary.

Breast cysts are fluid filled masses that develop within the glandular tissue of the breast, usually in the upper outer quadrant, but they can appear anywhere in the breast. Breast cysts usually develop because of overproduction of estrogen and suppression of progesterone. Patients with breast cysts may present with a breast mass and localized pain that worsens prior to menstruation, or patients may be asymptomatic with a breast lump found on a routine self examination or physical examination in a provider’s office. Breast cysts are typically solitary, smooth, firm lesions that are mobile and may or may not be tender to palpation. Most breast cysts are benign, but new cysts in older postmenopausal patients pose a higher risk of malignancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Breast ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Estrogen, LH, and FSH levels:
Incorrect: Although breast cysts usually develop because of overproduction of estrogen and suppression of progesterone, obtaining hormone levels is not part of the diagnosis or treatment. This patient has symptoms and findings consistent with a breast cyst, and she should have a breast ultrasound to diagnose and classify her lesion.  
❌ Repeat breast exam two weeks after the start of her menstrual cycle:
Incorrect: Fibrocystic breast disease commonly presents with bilateral nodularity and breast tenderness that can worsen towards the end of a patient’s menstrual cycle.
