In addition to bilateral tender nodular areas in the breasts, a ropey or lumpy texture may be palpable. This premenopausal patient has a smooth, mobile, tender mass that is consistent with a breast cyst. She should have an ultrasound for diagnosis and classification.  
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: A skin biopsy is usually performed when a patient has symptoms suspicious for inflammatory breast cancer, such as pruritus, warmth, and erythema of the skin of the breast; nipple flattening or retractions; and axillary lymphadenopathy. None of these are present in this patient.  
❌ Percutaneous aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: A breast abscess or cyst may be aspirated percutaneously, which is usually done after or during a breast ultrasound. A breast ultrasound is first needed to diagnose the lesion which will, in turn, determine next steps in management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for evaluation of a tender left breast lump. She found the lump during a self-breast examination three weeks ago, and it has not changed in size during that time. She does not have nipple discharge. She has no significant past medical history. She has had irregular menses for the past year. She is not sexually active. Her paternal aunt had breast cancer when she was in her 80’s. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the breast is normal, and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1.5-cm smooth, mobile mass in the upper outer right breast that is very tender upon palpation. There is no bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Breast ultrasound reveals an irregular shaped lesion with walls that are 0.40 mm thick with posterior acoustic enhancement and no solid components. Which of the following features supports ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy as the best next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Irregular shape of the breast lump on ultrasound
Absence of solid components on ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient has a solitary, tender, mobile left breast mass that is suspicious for a breast cyst.  On breast ultrasound, the patient has a mass with irregular borders. The cyst is classified as a complex breast cyst that is considered suspicious for malignancy (BI-RAD classification 4 or 5, suspicious for malignancy or highly suggestive of malignancy). Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy should be performed next to provide histopathology to further assess the mass.

Breast ultrasound is the initial test to evaluate breast masses that are suspected to be cysts and to confirm the diagnosis of a breast cyst. Breast ultrasound can also differentiate between simple, complicated, and complex breast cysts. This determination will then guide management. Ultrasound classification of breast cysts is based on lesion shape, acoustic enhancement, internal echoes, solid components, and the thickness of the walls and septa of the mass.  

Option Analysis

✅ Irregular shape of the breast lump on ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Regardless of this patient’s family history, findings from the ultrasound, including an irregular shaped lesion, should be used to guide diagnosis and management. This patient with an irregular shaped lesion should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Absence of solid components on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Absence of solid components in a breast cyst can be found in simple, complicated, and complex breast cysts and does not differentiate between the types of breast cysts. This patient with an irregular shaped lesion should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Age of the patient:
Incorrect: Regardless of the patient’s age, a breast mass that is found to have features that are suspicious for malignancy, like lobulated, indistinct or irregular borders, solid components, or thick walls, should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Presence of pain with palpation:
Incorrect: Benign and malignant breast masses may be tender or painful; therefore, tenderness or pain alone does not determine the underlying cause of a cyst. Cysts that may be malignant should be biopsied with ultrasound guidance.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist's office for a routine gynecologic examination. She has no complaints. She has no known medical conditions. She uses a copper IUD for birth control. She has no family history of cancer. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the breast is normal and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1-cm smooth, nontender, mobile mass in the upper outer left breast. There is no bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Breast ultrasound reveals an oval-shaped lesion with posterior acoustic enhancement and walls that are 0.40 mm thick. There are internal echoes but no solid components. Her mammogram is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Clinical breast exam and breast ultrasound in six months

questions.solution:
This patient has a solitary, nontender, mobile left breast mass found on routine breast examination. Her breast ultrasound confirms that the mass is a complicated breast cyst (Bi-rads 2 or 3). Patients with complicated breast cysts should undergo a clinical breast examination, repeat breast ultrasound, and mammogram if the lesion was initially seen on mammography in six months.

Management of patients with  breast cysts is based on the type of cyst diagnosed on ultrasound. Patients with simple cysts may undergo ultrasound-guided aspiration if the patient is symptomatic. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is recommended for simple cysts if the cyst does not completely collapse after aspiration or if there is bloody aspirate. Patients with complicated cysts (Bi-rads 3) should have follow-up, including clinical breast examination and breast ultrasound in six months as well as mammogram if the lesion was seen initially on mammogram. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is recommended if the cyst increases in size on follow-up imaging or if solid components are found on follow-up imaging. Patients with complex cyst with solid components should undergo ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy due to the high risk of malignancy. If the biopsy results show atypical or malignant cells, excisional biopsy should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical breast exam and breast ultrasound in six months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided aspiration:
Incorrect: Ultrasound-guided aspiration may be used to treat patients with symptomatic simple cysts diagnosed on ultrasound. They are not used to diagnose or manage patients with complicated cysts.  
❌ Excisional biopsy:
Incorrect: Excisional biopsy is not necessary at this time since the ultrasound shows a complicated cyst that can be reassessed in six months.  
❌ Mammogram in six months:
Incorrect: Follow up for a complicated cyst includes clinical breast exam and ultrasound in six months. Mammogram can also be performed if the lesion was initially seen on mammogram. This patient’s initial mammogram was negative, so follow-up with clinical breast exam and ultrasound in six months is appropriate.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is performed in patients with breast cysts when their ultrasound and/or mammographic assessments indicate lesions that are suspicious for malignancy. When findings show a complicated cyst, assessments can be repeated in six months.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic concerned about a lesion on his upper back. He reports spending significant time outdoors due to his profession as a lifeguard, and he often forgets to reapply sunscreen after swimming. He recalls several instances of sunburns during his youth. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a number of pigmented lesions across the sun-exposed skin. The patient is fair-skinned. On his upper back, there is an asymmetrical raised lesion with irregular borders and a uniform dark color. Which of the following features is most indicative of the need for further evaluation of the lesion?

choices.text: Uniformity of the color of the lesion

questions.solution:
This patient, with significant sun exposure history and previous instances of sunburns, presents with a skin lesion that is asymmetrical with irregular borders. These features raise suspicion for melanoma, and further investigation with a biopsy is needed. Risk factors for melanoma include personal or family history of cutaneous malignancy, immunosuppression, fair skin, a tendency to sunburn, chronic sun exposure, and history of previous sunburns.

Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes that often presents with unique clinical characteristics that distinguish it from benign skin lesions. A number of factors taken together guide the decision of whether or not to biopsy a lesion in question. Clinically, the ABCDE criteria can serve as a guide for identifying suspicious lesions that need to be biopsied: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter over 6mm, and Evolution (change in size, color, or shape of a pre-existing lesion or report of a new growing lesion). Patient-reported symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or sensory changes in the lesion should heighten the suspicion of malignancy. Additionally, when a lesion looks conspicuously different (“ugly duckling” sign) from surrounding nevi (nevus phenotype) on the patient, then biopsy should be performed. Patients also may have systemic signs of malignancy including fatigue, bone pain, and unintentional weight loss.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Border irregularity of the lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patient’s occupation as a lifeguard:
Incorrect: While a lifeguard's profession increases the risk of sun exposure and potential skin malignancies, it is not part of the determination for further evaluation. The appearance and features of the lesion itself are more pertinent to the diagnosis and evaluation of suspected melanoma.  
❌ Location on the upper back:
Incorrect: While the upper back is a frequent site for melanomas, location alone is not an indication for further evaluation of lesions that are suspicious for melanoma as melanomas like acral lentiginous melanoma can appear on less sun-exposed areas, like the palms and soles.  
❌ Uniformity of the color of the lesion:
Incorrect: Uniformity of color is generally reassuring and less suspicious for melanoma. Melanomas often display a variety of colors within one lesion, including black, brown, tan, red, blue, or white. Therefore, the consistent coloration of a lesion does not typically warrant immediate concern, but other characteristics of this lesion like asymmetry and irregular borders raise suspicion for melanoma.  
❌ Raised appearance of the lesion:
Incorrect: Raised appearance can be seen in both benign and malignant lesions. In this patient asymmetry and border irregularity raise suspicion for melanoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of a bump on the front of his neck that he noticed five weeks ago. He first noticed it while shaving his beard short for the first time in years. It is not painful, and there has been no noticeable change in size since he noticed it. He has a history of Ewing sarcoma in his right leg, which is in remission after treatment as a teenager. His mother is healthy, and his father died in his 40s from colon cancer. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), pulse is 79/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg. On physical examination, he has a non-tender palpable mass over the right lobe of the thyroid that moves upward with swallowing. There is no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Which of the following, if present, would suggest an increased likelihood that this finding is malignant?

choices.text: Family history of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
Family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1)
Personal history of radiation therapy to the lower extremity
Personal history of heavy alcohol consumption

questions.solution:
This patient has an asymptomatic palpable mass at the front of his neck that moves upward when swallowing, consistent with a thyroid nodule. While there is not a clear family history of syndromes that increase the risk of cancer, his father’s early death from colon cancer could be indicative of familial adenomatous polyposis, which would significantly increase this patient’s risk of thyroid cancer.      

Most patients with thyroid nodules do not present with symptoms, and the nodule is found on a routine exam or incidentally on imaging done for another indication. When symptoms are present, patients may have signs of either hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. If the nodule is large enough, it can put pressure on surrounding structures and cause a feeling of fullness in the throat or difficulty swallowing.      

While the vast majority of thyroid nodules are benign, it is important to assess risk factors for thyroid cancer, including ionizing radiation of the head and neck, rapid nodule growth, hoarseness, and a family history of thyroid cancer or cancer syndromes. Most thyroid cancers are differentiated thyroid cancers, and an estimated 5-10% are associated with an inherited genetic syndrome, including familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Cowden disease. While rare, medullary thyroid cancer is a common manifestation of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).   

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1):
Incorrect: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), not type 1, is associated with tumors in the thyroid, parathyroid, and adrenal glands. MEN1 is instead associated with tumors in the pituitary gland, parathyroid gland, or pancreas (which can produce gastrin and lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).  
❌ Personal history of radiation therapy to the lower extremity:
Incorrect: Previous head and neck or whole-body irradiation can increase the incidence of malignancy in exposed tissues. Exposure to ionizing radiation in this patient’s leg for treatment of sarcoma should not affect the thyroid gland.
❌ Personal history of heavy alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Heavy alcohol consumption has not been shown to be associated with an increased risk of developing thyroid cancer. In fact, an inverse relationship has been found in some studies.
❌ Personal history of smoking cigarettes:
Incorrect: Smoking cigarettes has not been shown to be associated with an increased risk of developing thyroid cancer. In fact, an inverse relationship has been found in some studies.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with palpitations and unintentional weight loss for three months. She has no medical history of thyroid disorders, irradiation, or surgery. Her family history is negative for thyroid disorders and syndromes. Temperature is 37.6 °C (99.7 °F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 131/84 mmHg. On physical examination, she has a non-tender thyroid without two nodules felt and no cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiac examination is notable for tachycardia without murmurs or rubs. Pulmonary examination is normal. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 0.35 µU/L. Ultrasound shows two hypoechoic 1.5-cm nodules in each lobe of the thyroid. Radioactive iodine uptake scan demonstrates patchy uptake, and the nodules that are seen on ultrasound do not have uptake on RAIU. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the thyroid gland

questions.solution:
This patient has tachycardia and unintentional weight loss with palpable thyroid nodules on physical exam. She has a low TSH, indicating hyperthyroidism, and US shows two 1.5-cm hypoechoic nodules. The RAIU shows patchy uptake and the RAIU findings are nonconcordant with the ultrasound findings, meaning the two suspicious nodules do not have RAIU and are “cold” nodules which have a higher likelihood of malignancy. FNA is the next step to evaluate these nodules and determine if they are malignant.    

Patients with thyroid nodules who are found to be hyperthyroid require a radioactive RAIU scan. When RAIU shows a solitary focus of uptake or patchy uptake that is concordant with ultrasound findings, then treatment for hyperthyroidism is appropriate. On the other hand, patients like this one, with RAIU findings that show patchy uptake and non-concordance with the ultrasound findings (indicating “cold” nodules) should undergo FNA.    

FNA cytology uses the Bethesda System for cytopathology, with six diagnostic categories (Bethesda class I-VI). Patients with cytology that is malignant or suspicious of malignancy should be referred for primary surgical treatment, which involves lobectomy or total thyroidectomy with or without lymph node dissection. All other patients will require assessment of additional diagnostic data to determine the treatment.    

Subsequent postoperative management includes thyroid hormone supplementation for most patients. Radioiodine ablation is considered for those at higher risk of recurrence as well as those with persistent or metastatic disease. Systemic chemotherapy and external radiotherapy can also be used as adjuvant or palliative therapy to address recurrence and control disease spread when radioiodine therapy fails.  

Option Analysis

❌ Surgical resection of the thyroid gland:
Incorrect: Surgical resection may be necessary if FNA findings are malignant or suspicious for malignancy. This patient first needs histological and cytological confirmation of thyroid malignancy before surgical resection, because of the non-concordance of the ultrasound and RAIU findings.
❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: If the imaging findings were concordant with the nodules seen on US also having uptake on RAIU (hyperfunctioning (hot or toxic) nodules), then it would be appropriate to treat the hyperthyroidism with methimazole or propylthiouracil.
❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapy has a role as adjunctive therapy following thyroid resection and radioiodine therapy for the treatment of thyroid cancer. This patient first needs histological and cytological confirmation of thyroid malignancy before surgical resection.
✅ Fine-needle aspiration and cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Radioiodine therapy:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine therapy can be used to treat hyperthyroidism unrelated to malignancy, as well as for differentiated thyroid cancers after thyroidectomy. This patient needs to have an FNA first to determine if histological and cytology are consistent with thyroid cancer.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and vomiting that began 6 hours ago. He reports intermittent crampy abdominal pain and bloating over the past week. However, since the early morning, the pain has been severe and sharp in nature and associated with nausea. He has been receiving chemotherapy for a known diagnosis of colorectal cancer. Additional past medical history is significant for hypertension, controlled with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals absent bowel sounds and generalized abdominal tenderness, distension, and involuntary guarding over the lower abdomen. IV fluids are initiated. An upright chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

 Reproduced from: Openi

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Nasogastric tube placement, bowel rest, and serial monitoring

questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain, distension, nausea, tenderness, guarding, and absent bowel sounds, in the setting of known colorectal cancer, is concerning for bowel obstruction. The sudden onset of severe symptoms combined with involuntary guarding on physical examination and presence of pneumoperitoneum (i.e. air under the diaphragm) observed on upright chest x-ray, indicates bowel perforation, which is a life-threatening complication requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation.

In patients with colorectal cancer, the bowel wall can become compromised due to the pressure from tumor growth, which increases the risk of necrosis and perforation. When this occurs, bowel contents seep into the peritoneal cavity, resulting in bacterial peritonitis, requiring immediate intervention. Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics is crucial, ensuring that both gram-positive and gram-negative pathogens are targeted. Concurrently, emergent surgical consultation is necessary. Typically, an exploratory laparotomy is performed to repair or resect the perforated segment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is a diagnostic tool for colorectal neoplasms and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is contraindicated in the setting of suspected bowel perforation due to the risk of exacerbating the perforation.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While a CT scan would delineate the extent and source of the perforation and the likely obstruction, the urgency of this patient's condition (bowel perforation with pneumoperitoneum) necessitates immediate surgical intervention.  
❌ Nasogastric tube placement, bowel rest, and serial monitoring:
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression and bowel rest can be the initial steps in treatment of uncomplicated bowel obstruction, but the presence of pneumoperitoneum and associated signs of peritonitis (guarding) demands a more aggressive surgical approach.  
❌ Colonic stent placement:
Incorrect: Colonic stent placement might be utilized for palliative treatment in patients with obstructing colorectal cancer. In the case of a suspected bowel perforation and resulting peritonitis, urgent surgical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man who resides in a nursing home is brought by ambulance to the emergency department with a three-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is severe and located in the lower abdomen. His last bowel movement was four days ago. He has a history of chronic constipation for which he regularly takes colace. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 126/87 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows a distended diffusely tender tympanitic abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds without rebound or guarding. Digital rectal exam is unremarkable. Abdominal x-ray shows a coffee bean sign in the right upper quadrant and multiple air-fluid levels. Abdominal CT scan shows a whirl sign and a bird-beak sign. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent endoscopic decompression followed by elective surgical colectomy
Conservative management with placement of nasogastric tube

questions.solution:
Lower quadrant abdominal pain, obstipation, and a distended tender tympanitic abdomen in an older patient are characteristics of colonic volvulus. Abdominal x-ray findings of a coffee bean sign in the right upper quadrant and multiple air-fluid levels, and abdominal CT scan findings showing a bird-beak sign and a whirl sign confirm the diagnosis of sigmoid volvulus. Management of stable patients with sigmoid volvulus without alarm signs or complications is endoscopic detorsion (or endoscopic decompression) with rectal tube placement, followed by elective sigmoid resection.

Endoscopic detorsion is done via flexible sigmoidoscopy and restores luminal flow and blood supply to the affected sigmoid colon. Once completed, elective surgical resection is typically performed 24-72 hours later for definitive treatment, as recurrence of sigmoid volvulus is high following endoscopic detorsion.

In unstable patients or patients with a complicated sigmoid volvulus (e.g., perforation, gangrene, peritonitis, septic shock), immediate surgical management with exploratory laparotomy and colectomy is required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urgent endoscopic decompression followed by elective surgical colectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conservative management with placement of nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: In stable patients like this one who present with sigmoid volvulus, acute management via endoscopic decompression is the initial recommended treatment.  
❌ Emergent exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: Emergent exploratory laparotomy is reserved for unstable patients with colonic volvulus, and for patients with colonic volvulus who have alarm signs or symptoms (e.g., peritonitis, perforation, gangrene).  
❌ Right colectomy:
Incorrect: Right colectomy is the definitive treatment for cecal, not sigmoid, volvulus.  
❌ Sigmoid resection:
Incorrect: Sigmoid resection is the definitive treatment for sigmoid volvulus which should be performed at a later date after endoscopic decompression in this stable patient with sigmoid volvulus without complications.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and discomfort during bowel movements for the past three weeks. She has not had any significant weight loss, changes in bowel habits, or abdominal pain. She has smoked 1-pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. She has a history of high-risk HPV and prior cervical changes detected on a PAP smear. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm ulcerated perianal lesion. Biopsy of the mass reveals a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, and imaging confirms stage I disease that does not involve the sphincter. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wide surgical excision of the mass

questions.solution:
This patient with well-differentiated stage I squamous cell perianal cancer should be referred for wide surgical excision of the mass.  Due to the small size, perianal location of the tumor, and well-differentiated cell features, the likelihood of cure with surgery alone is high. If the surgical margins are positive for disease, re-excision or treatment with chemotherapy will be needed.

The first step in determining whether squamous cell anal cancer should be managed with chemoradiation versus surgery is to establish the location of the tumor. Cancers within the anal canal are managed with chemoradiation. If the tumor is located in the perianal region, as in this patient, the next step is to stage the tumor and evaluate how well the cells are differentiated to determine whether chemoradiation or surgery is indicated. For stage 1 perianal lesions that are 2 cm or smaller in size that are well or moderately differentiated, wide local excision is recommended. Surgical management can also be considered for patients with stage 2A disease (i.e. tumor greater than 2 cm but less than or equal to 5 cm) that does not involve the sphincter. More advanced cancers should be treated with chemoradiation. Systemic chemotherapy can be used to treat metastatic disease. Adenocarcinomas are treated differently based on the TNM staging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chemoradiation:
Incorrect: This patient has a small well-differentiated stage 1 perianal cancer. For perianal SCC, stage 1 tumors that are well or moderately differentiated, or stage 2A tumors not involving the sphincter, treatment is surgical resection.  
❌ Palliative care:
Incorrect: Palliative care is indicated for patients with advanced, incurable disease to provide comfort and manage symptoms This patient has a well-differentiated, stage 1 disease that does not involve the sphincter and can likely be cured with surgical excision.  
✅ Wide surgical excision of the mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunotherapy and chemotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has a small well-differentiated stage 1 perianal cancer. For perianal SCC, stage 1 tumors that are well or moderately differentiated, or stage 2A tumors not involving the sphincter, treatment is surgical resection.  
❌ Surveillance with regular imaging studies:
Incorrect: For localized, resectable stage 1 perianal cancer, the standard of care is surgical excision. Surveillance without surgery can lead to disease progression, invasion of nearby structures, and potential complications. Early intervention with surgical excision offers the best chance of cure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is 7 weeks postpartum presents to her primary care physician with a 3-day history of increasing pain, redness, and swelling in her right breast. She has been exclusively breastfeeding her infant and recently noted a decrease in milk output from the affected breast. She has not had trauma or recent surgeries. Past medical history is notable for gestational diabetes, which was managed with diet during her pregnancy. She has no known bacterial colonization. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination of the right breast reveals erythema, warmth, and tenderness to palpation noted in the upper outer quadrant. There is no fluctuance. The left breast is normal on examination. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Dicloxacillin and frequent breastfeeding or pumping
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and frequent breastfeeding or pumping
Intravenous vancomycin and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and frequent breastfeeding or pumping

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of localized pain and erythema of the breast, coupled with fever and postpartum status, strongly suggests puerperal mastitis. Puerperal mastitis commonly occurs in breastfeeding women, typically within the first 6 weeks postpartum. Management consists of antibiotic therapy and continuation of breastfeeding or pumping.    

Antibiotic treatment should target common pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus. Dicloxacillin is the preferred antibiotic due to its efficacy against penicillinase-producing staphylococci and its safety with breastfeeding. In addition to antibiotic therapy, continued breastfeeding or pumping from the affected breast should be encouraged in order to prevent milk stasis which could worsen the infection. Additionally, pain control with NSAIDs is recommended to alleviate inflammation and discomfort. If there is no improvement with initial treatment, or if an abscess is suspected, a breast ultrasound should be considered for further evaluation. Detection of an abscess necessitates drainage, which may be done surgically or with ultrasound guidance. In such cases, antibiotic therapy may need adjustment to cover potential methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

Option Analysis

✅ Dicloxacillin and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cephalexin and discontinuation of breastfeeding :
Incorrect: Dicloxacillin or cephalexin are appropriate antibiotics to treat mild mastitis infection when there are no MRSA risk factors, however, continued milk drainage is recommended to prevent milk stasis.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Incorrect: Although NSAIDs can help with pain and inflammation with mastitis, this patient has fever and chills suggestive of a bacterial infection and needs antibiotic therapy.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration:
Incorrect: This approach is too aggressive for initial management of mastitis in a lactating woman without confirmation of abscess or risk for resistant bacteria.
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is appropriate treatment for puerperal mastitis in patients with risk factors for MRSA like recent hospitalization or colonization with MRSA which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for low blood pressure several hours after an elective left hemicolectomy for malignant-appearing polyps in the descending colon. His past medical history is significant for alcohol-induced cirrhosis and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine and propranolol. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 76/42 mmHg. The patient is given 3 liters of IV 0.9% saline. Repeat blood pressure after fluids is 80/44 mmHg. On examination, the patient is ill-appearing with significant pallor. The abdomen is firm and diffusely tender to palpation. CT imaging of the abdomen shows retroperitoneal fluid with heterogeneous high attenuation. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is found to have postoperative hypotension that is refractory to IV fluid administration. The patient’s underlying cirrhosis (which causes coagulopathy), pallor, and retroperitoneal fluid suggestive of blood on CT imaging indicate retroperitoneal bleeding. This patient has developed postoperative hemorrhagic shock and needs emergent surgical evaluation. The patient should also receive blood products and vasopressors.

Hemorrhagic shock can occur postoperatively, especially after intra-abdominal or lower extremity surgery as these areas can accommodate a large amount of blood. Severe blood loss after surgery manifests as hypotension, which can be associated with weakness, lethargy, and pallor depending upon the amount and speed of blood loss. Laboratory evidence of decreased serum hemoglobin can significantly lag behind the actual degree of blood loss. Therefore, blood products should be transfused in cases of suspected severe blood loss, even if the hemoglobin is not significantly lower than previous measurements or laboratory studies have not yet returned.  

Option Analysis

✅ Return to the operating room:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV fluid bolus:
Incorrect: This patient has already received several liters of IV fluids without meaningful improvement in blood pressure, therefore another IV fluid bolus is unlikely to be of benefit. Instead, this patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the source of bleeding is located in the operating room.  
❌ Octreotide infusion:
Incorrect: Octreotide infusions are indicated in some cases of bleeding esophageal varices. This patient’s CT imaging shows retroperitoneal bleeding for which octreotide would not provide significant benefit. This patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the bleeding source is located in the operating room.  
❌ Paracentesis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture of refractory hypotension, pallor, and retroperitoneal fluid after surgery is highly suggestive of retroperitoneal bleeding. A diagnostic paracentesis is not necessary, and a therapeutic paracentesis would not address the source of bleeding.  
❌ Ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient already has CT imaging highly suggestive of retroperitoneal bleeding, so an ultrasound is not necessary at this point. This patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the bleeding source is located in the operating room.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for retrosternal chest pain. The pain started four hours ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or position changes. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Cardiac catheterization is performed via the femoral artery and demonstrates stenosis of the following arteries: 70% left main coronary artery, 90% proximal left anterior descending artery, and 80% right coronary artery. Six hours following catheterization, the patient states that he is experiencing generalized weakness and back pain. Temperature is 37.1℃ (98.8℉), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates cold and clammy extremities. A 5 cm area of ecchymosis is noted surrounding the femoral puncture site. Palpation and auscultation of catheter access sites are unremarkable. The patient has palpable, thready dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset back pain, generalized weakness, and hypotension with cold and clammy extremities after cardiac catheterization is consistent with retroperitoneal hemorrhage. This patient’s condition likely occurred secondary to accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery.   

The common femoral artery serves as the continuation of the external iliac artery as it crosses the inguinal ligament and is often used as a site for vascular access. Retroperitoneal bleeding is frequently related to artery puncture above the inguinal ligament, as this portion of the vessel lies directly inferior to the peritoneum. Accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery can cause blood to track along the vascular fascial sheath into the retroperitoneum or rectus sheath.  

Due to the size of the retroperitoneal space, significant hemorrhage can occur before the development of any clinical signs or symptoms. Back pain, hypotension, and a significant drop in hemoglobin after a procedure are signs of a retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Diagnosis is confirmed via computed tomography imaging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudoaneurysm:
Incorrect: A pseudoaneurysm is associated with clinical findings of pain at the access site combined with ecchymosis and subcutaneous hematoma. It is often recognized by the presence of a pulsatile mass with a systolic bruit overlying the catheter insertion site. This patient does not have symptoms or signs on physical examination of a pseudoaneurysm. Pseudoaneurysms do not typically lead to loss of a large volume of blood and hypotension. 
❌ Arteriovenous fistula:
Incorrect: Bleeding from the arterial puncture site may fistulize into the adjacent femoral vein. It may be recognized clinically by the presence of a thrill or continuous bruit. The time of symptom onset ranges from two days to several months after catheterization.
❌ Allergic reaction to iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: An allergic reaction to iodinated contrast typically presents with urticaria, pruritus, facial edema, as well as transient warmth or chills. Allergic reactions usually occur within twenty minutes of exposure. Anaphylaxis from contrast media occurs within minutes of exposure.
✅ Retroperitoneal hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Arterial thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with lower extremity arterial thrombosis present with pain or paresthesias in the affected leg, as well as reduced or absent distal pulses.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment after having a recent right total hip arthroplasty due to long-standing osteoarthritis. His postoperative course was unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Vitals are within normal limits. With standing the patient is able to comfortably bear weight on each leg. He leans towards his right side with ambulation. The patient’s left pelvis tilts downwards when asked to stand on the right leg. The surgical site over the lateral hip appears to be healing well, and there are no signs of infection. Hip range of motion does not cause pain and is as expected at this post-operative stage. The remainder of his physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the hip joint

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness from injury to the superior gluteal nerve. The superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1) can be injured in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty where the gluteus medius is split and retracted.  

The superior gluteal nerve is responsible for innervating the gluteus medius and maximus which abduct the thigh when a person is standing on one foot or during normal ambulation. Weakness of these muscles results in sagging of the pelvis to the unaffected side while standing on the affected leg (positive Trendelenburg sign). When ambulating, the patient will lean toward the affected side to compensate for the hip drop (gluteus medius march).



Common causes of Trendelenburg gait include superior gluteal nerve injury, tendinitis or penetrating injury of the lateral glutei, greater trochanteric avulsion, or fracture of the femoral neck.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior gluteal nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adductor muscle strain:
Incorrect: Adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction. This patient has evidence of a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness suggestive of superior gluteal nerve injury.  
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect:  Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis muscle spasms and irritates or compresses the sciatic nerve. Hip flexion, external rotation, or passive internal rotation exacerbate pain. A Trendelenburg gait suggests gluteus muscle weakness.
❌ Septic arthritis of the hip joint:
Incorrect: This condition presents severe joint pain (especially with range of motion), erythema, warmth, and tenderness over the affected joint. Patients are almost always unable to bear weight. A Trendelenburg gait suggests an alternative etiology.
❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh and inguinal region. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. A Trendelenburg gait results from superior gluteal nerve injury and abductor weakness.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right knee pain and swelling. The patient participated in a soccer match when she jumped and landed on her right foot with her right knee partially flexed. She subsequently heard a “pop” and developed swelling around her knee. Past medical history is significant for recent urinary tract infections treated with ciprofloxacin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a large effusion over the right knee. The patient is unable to bear weight or extend the knee. X-ray of the knee shows a large effusion with a low-lying patella. Which of the following additional findings will likely be seen on physical examination?

choices.text: Anterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur
Palpable defect superior to the patella
Palpable defect inferior to the patella
Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur

questions.solution:
This patient presents with limited knee extension and an inability to bear weight following a sudden forceful contraction of the quadriceps while landing on a partially flexed knee. This, combined with a low-lying patella seen on radiograph, suggests a quadriceps tendon tear (proximal to the patella in the rectus femoris tendon).  

Quadricep tendon tears usually occur in athletes following a sudden, strong contraction of the quadriceps muscles, such as when landing from a high jump or making a sudden change in direction at high speed. Patients often experience an audible pop followed by a sharp pain at the knee, rapid swelling, and limited knee extension. There is often a palpable defect above the patella indicative of the quadriceps tendon tearing from the superior portion of the patella. Risk factors for this injury pattern include chronic kidney disease and fluoroquinolone or anabolic steroid use. Diagnosis and extent of the injury can be assessed on MRI. Initial management consists of rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE therapy), analgesics, non-weight bearing, and prompt orthopedic referral. Patients should be placed in a knee immobilizer to minimize repeated flexion at the knee.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur:
Incorrect: Forward movement of the tibia against a fixed femur is seen with an anterior cruciate ligament tear. Knee extension is generally preserved in patients with this condition. Sudden pivoting or twisting maneuvers are typically the cause of anterior cruciate ligament tears.
✅ Palpable defect superior to the patella:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Palpable defect inferior to the patella:
Incorrect: A palpable defect below the patella suggests patellar tendon rupture. Radiographs in these patients will demonstrate a high riding patella. 
❌ Posterior knee and calf swelling:
Incorrect: Swelling in the posterior knee and calf suggests popliteal cyst rupture. It commonly affects patients with pre-existing knee pathology (e.g. osteoarthritis). 
❌ Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur:
Incorrect: Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur is seen in patients with posterior cruciate ligament tears. This condition commonly results from hyperextension or an anterior blow to the proximal tibia with the knee flexed. A low riding patella seen here is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the office to discuss next steps after a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer. She recently presented to the emergency department with refractory dyspepsia and weight loss and underwent an upper endoscopy with biopsies. The endoscopy was notable for a fungating mass in the gastric antrum, and biopsies showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Endoscopic ultrasound was performed and showed invasion into the muscularis propria and no suspicious lymph nodes. She was prescribed treatment for H. Pylori. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast

questions.solution:
After a tissue diagnosis of gastric cancer has been made, additional workup is necessary to complete TNM staging of the tumor. The T stage of gastric cancer correlates with the depth of tumor penetration into the layers of the gastric wall (see table below). Generally, depth of tumor penetration is determined via endoscopic ultrasound. This patient underwent endoscopic ultrasound during an upper endoscopy for presumed gastric cancer. Her lesion extends into the muscularis propria, making it a T2 lesion. Surrounding lymph nodes are also assessed on endoscopic ultrasound - when suspicious, they are biopsied via FNA. However, no suspicious nodes were noted in this patient. The most appropriate next step is to complete a metastatic workup with computed tomography of the chest, abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast.

CT is widely available, noninvasive, and is well suited for evaluating widely metastatic disease, especially hepatic or adnexal metastases, ascites, and distant nodal spread. Patients who have CT-defined visceral metastatic disease can avoid unnecessary surgery, although biopsy confirmation is recommended because of the risk of false-positive findings.

The goal of the initial staging evaluation is to stratify patients into two clinical groups in order to guide initial management: those with locoregional, potentially resectable (stage I to III) disease and those with either locally advanced, unresectable or metastatic (stage IV) disease. The most common sites for metastasis are the liver, peritoneum or distant lymph nodes. Once staging is complete, the patient can be referred to obtain the appropriate treatment.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: While this patient most likely will require treatment with chemotherapy, appropriate staging with a metastatic workup is needed prior to initiating treatment.  
❌ Obtain CEA, CA 19-9 and CA 125:
Incorrect: Serum tumor markers are included in the workup for several cancers, including colon cancer (CEA), pancreatic cancer (CA 19-9) and ovarian cancer (CA 125). However, they are not included in the staging workup of gastric cancer. There are currently no tumor markers used commonly to evaluate disease burden in gastric cancer.  
✅ CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ FDG-PET Scan:
Incorrect: PET-CT is reserved for those patients who have equivocal findings on CT imaging or patients with clinical indications of possible metastatic disease and otherwise negative imaging. This patient still requires initial imaging with CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast for staging.  
❌ Diagnostic laparoscopy:
Incorrect: Staging laparoscopy is used to detect occult peritoneal dissemination in patients with more than a T1a lesion on EUS, and no histologic confirmation of stage IV disease, who would not otherwise require palliative gastrectomy because of symptoms. Diagnostic laparoscopy should also be undertaken in any patient who is being considered for neoadjuvant therapy. This patient first needs staging with CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a skin lesion on his cheek that has been present for the last six months. The lesion is painless and has not changed since he first noticed it, but it bleeds easily if he scratches it or it rubs on something. He has worked as a roofer for the last 30 years with frequent and prolonged sun exposure. Pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Examination of the right cheek reveals a 1.7 mm raised, symmetrical, pearly pink skin lesion with smooth borders and overlying telangiectasias. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a smooth, pearly pink skin lesion with overlying telangiectasias that bleeds easily and has not changed notably in six months most likely has basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinomas are common in sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the face; and this patient’s work as a roofer likely contributed to his risk given the high amount of UV light exposure.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a malignant skin lesion, which typically does not metastasize but can cause significant morbidity due to local tissue destruction. The primary risk factor for basal cell carcinoma is UV light exposure with high intensity of sun exposure. A history of early childhood or adolescent burns; tanning bed use; and prolonged sun exposure, such as with working outdoors, all increase the risk. Other risk factors include patient-specific factors, such as being sun sensitive with fair skin, light-colored eyes, and red hair; being immunosuppressed; exposure to ionizing radiation; and genetic predisposition.

Basal cell carcinoma commonly presents on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the head and neck. The appearance can vary, but the most common type is the nodular type; which presents with a pink or flesh-colored “pearly” papular lesion with smooth edges, a raised or “rolled” border, and occasionally a central ulceration. If left untreated, these lesions may enlarge and develop a fungating appearance with erosion into the skin surface.  

Option Analysis

✅ Basal cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Melanoma:
Incorrect: Classic features of melanoma include notable changes to an existing lesion over time, asymmetry, irregular borders, more than one color, and size larger than 6mm. This patient’s lesion is symmetrical with smooth borders; a single color; and has classic features of a basal cell carcinoma, such as a pearly appearance.  
❌ Actinic keratosis:
Incorrect: An actinic keratosis is a premalignant lesion with a dry, rough, or scaly appearance. This patient’s lesion is smooth and pearly, which is more characteristic of a basal cell carcinoma.  
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: A seborrheic keratosis is a benign lesion with a dry, rough, “stuck-on” appearance. The color can vary, but they are often shades of brown. This patient’s lesion is smooth, pearly, and pink in color with telangiectasias, which is more characteristic of a basal cell carcinoma.
❌ Keratosis pilaris:
Incorrect: Keratosis pilaris is a benign skin condition characterized by clusters of flesh-colored small papules surrounded by dry skin, usually on the cheeks, upper arms, thighs, or buttocks. It is more common in younger patients. This patient’s age and the presence of a single lesion makes basal cell carcinoma much more likely.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the clinic with a three-day history of fever, chills, and discharge from a surgical wound. The patient was hospitalized two weeks ago and underwent a right total hip arthroplasty. The patient smokes two packs of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.94°F), pulse 100/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 98% on room air. Physical examination shows an open wound with purulent drainage at the right hip surgical site. The purulent drainage is swabbed and sent for culture. Twenty-four hours later, wound cultures begin growing methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is initiated on an antibiotic that disrupts cell membranes of gram-positive cocci by creating transmembrane channels. Which laboratory values must be monitored during this patient’s treatment?

choices.text: C. difficile toxin PCR in stool

questions.solution:
This patient with skin and soft tissue infection from methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) was likely started on daptomycin. While vancomycin is the most commonly used parenteral antibiotic for MRSA, daptomycin is also frequently used. Other antibiotics with MRSA coverage include linezolid, ceftaroline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, doxycycline, and clindamycin.

Daptomycin disrupts the cell membrane integrity of gram-positive cocci (including MRSA) by creating transmembrane channels. It is generally used as second-line therapy for patients whose MRSA cultures demonstrate high resistance to vancomycin. Of note, daptomycin is inactivated by the lungs' surfactant; thus, daptomycin cannot be used to treat pneumonia due to MRSA.

Daptomycin can cause profound adverse effects involving muscular tissue. These can include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. Rhabdomyolysis manifests as elevated creatinine kinase, elevated serum creatinine, and often a urinalysis indicative of acute tubular injury (e.g., muddy casts, blood (+) without RBC). Monitoring creatine kinase is necessary while patients are on daptomycin therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum creatine kinase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Elevated lactate dehydrogenase can indicate many things, such as hemolysis. Hemolysis can occur in patients with G6PD deficiency who take dapsone. Dapsone inhibits folate synthesis and does not inhibit cell membrane integrity.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Hepatotoxicity is very rarely associated with daptomycin use. Elevations of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) may be from muscle breakdown rather than hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Complete blood counts:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression can manifest as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia and is associated with chloramphenicol. Chloramphenicol binds to the 50S subunit of ribosomes and does not cause transmembrane channels.  
❌ C. difficile toxin PCR in stool:
Incorrect: C. difficile infections are primarily associated with clindamycin and long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic use. C. difficile toxin should not be routinely monitored for antibiotic therapy and is not commonly associated with daptomycin use.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to the emergency department due to wounds on the thighs and palms of the hands after a motor vehicle accident. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, blood pressure 105/75 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows several abrasions from ankle to mid-thigh bilaterally and abrasions on both palms. The patient is treated with a topical ointment containing an antibiotic that binds to phospholipids on cell membranes and disrupts the membrane integrity. Which of the following agents did this patient most likely receive?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained multiple abrasions after a motor vehicle accident and is being treated with a topical antibiotic agent that inhibits bacterial cell membrane integrity. Polymyxin B is an antibiotic used topically in treating partial thickness burns and superficial skin infections. It is nearly identical to polymyxin E (also known as colistin) but differs slightly in a side chain and, thus, its activation pathway.

Polymyxins are bactericidal agents that bind to lipopolysaccharides and phospholipids in the outer cell membrane of gram-negative bacilli. The binding of these agents disrupts the membrane integrity, causing bacterial contents leakage and cell death. The spectrum of activity of polymyxins is limited to gram-negative bacteria. Polymyxin B is frequently mixed with bacitracin and neomycin in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments, as this combination has a much broader spectrum of activity.

Systemic use of polymyxins is rare these days and is reserved for treating severe infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria, as they are associated with systemic toxicity. Adverse effects from systemic use include nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, and even respiratory failure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gentamicin:
Incorrect: Gentamicin can be used in the treatment of superficial dermatologic infections. It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis and does not disrupt cell membrane integrity.  
❌ Nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is indicated in the treatment of staphylococcal skin and soft tissue infections. It inhibits cell wall synthesis by inhibiting transpeptidases, not by disrupting phospholipid integrity.  
❌ Daptomycin:
Incorrect: Daptomycin is generally used to treat gram-positive organisms (including MRSA) resistant to vancomycin, though it cannot be used to treat MRSA pneumonia. It disrupts cell membrane integrity by creating transmembrane channels. It is used intravenously, not topically.  
✅ Polymyxin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oxacillin:
Incorrect: Oxacillin is penicillinase-resistant penicillin that is used in the treatment of superficial skin infections. It inhibits cell wall synthesis by inhibiting transpeptidases, not by disrupting phospholipid integrity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) after being struck by a car while cycling. He was unhelmeted and was thrown at least ten feet. Emergency responders report that he was unconscious when they arrived at the scene, and he has not regained consciousness. The patient arrives with a cervical collar and backboard in place and one large-bore IV in his left arm. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 10, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on a non-rebreather. On primary survey, the patient’s airway is unobstructed, equal breath sounds are auscultated bilaterally, distal pulses are palpable and symmetric, and a second large-bore IV is placed in the right arm. Pupils are 3mm and reactive bilaterally. The patient does not open his eyes to voice or sternal rub, moans incomprehensibly in response to sternal rub, and withdraws each extremity in response to nail bed pressure. What is the patient’s Glascow Coma Score (GCS), and what is the best next step in management?

choices.text: GCS 7, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury
GCS 8, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury
GCS 9, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury

questions.solution:
This unconscious patient presents after a motor vehicle collision while cycling without a helmet and likely has a traumatic brain injury. The disability assessment in the primary survey (ABCDEs) reveals zero eye-opening, incomprehensible moaning, and the withdrawal of his extremities to painful stimuli. Therefore, he has a Glascow Coma Score (GCS) of 7, and the next step in management is endotracheal intubation.   

The initial management of any traumatically injured patient should begin with the Primary Survey, which consists of assessing the ABCDEs. First, secure the Airway and consider endotracheal intubation or a surgical airway if the patient cannot protect or maintain their airway. Be sure to immobilize the cervical spine and maintain immobilization during endotracheal intubation until a cervical spine fracture has been ruled out. Next, ensure adequate Breathing (or ventilation). Then, assess Circulation and place 2 large bore IVs or IO access while continuously monitoring vitals. Next, assess the patient’s Disability and neurologic status by calculating their GCS and assessing pupillary reflex. Keep in mind that the patient’s GCS can change rapidly. Also, remember that a GCS of 8 (or lower) means that you should intubate if you haven’t already. Finally, Expose the patient and remove all clothing to assess for any other associated injuries, and then cover the patient with warm blankets to prevent hypothermia.  

Traumatic brain injury is caused by penetrating or blunt force trauma to the head, resulting in temporary or permanent impairment of brain function. The degree of injury ranges from mild to severe as classified by the Glasgow Coma Scale. This scale measures eye-opening, verbal, and motor responses to stimuli on a scale from 3 to 15, with 3 representing a comatose state, and 15 being normal. Traditionally, a GCS score of 13 to 15 represents mild TBI, 9 to 12 indicates moderate injury, and a score of 8 or below is considered to be severe.   

This patient was noted to have no eye-opening, even to painful stimuli (e.g. sternal rub), meaning his score on the “Eyes” component of the GCS was 1 (1 is the lowest score for each component of the GCS and 3 is the lowest overall GCS score). The patient moaned incomprehensibly but did not form any words, giving him a score of 2 on the “Verbal” component of the GCS. Finally, he withdrew his extremities from painful stimuli (e.g. nail bed pressure), giving him a score of 4 on the “Motor” component of the GCS. Taken together, his total GCS is 7. With a GCS of 7, this patient is at risk for aspiration or apnea and is therefore considered to have an unprotected airway. Therefore, the best next step in management is to intubate the patient before moving on to the rest of the primary survey.



Option Analysis

❌ GCS 6, intubate the patient:
Incorrect: While it is true that if this patient had a GCS of 6, the best next step would be to protect his airway with intubation and mechanical ventilation; however, this patient has a GCS of 7. 
✅ GCS 7, intubate the patient:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ GCS 7, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury :
Incorrect: This patient has a GCS of 7 and the next step should be to intubate the patient. The primary survey aims to identify and address any immediate life-threatening issues. A GCS of 7 indicates an unprotected airway, so a secure airway must be obtained before moving on to the rest of the primary survey. 
❌ GCS 8, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury :
Incorrect: This patient has a GCS of 7. However, even if this patient did have a GCS of 8, the best next step would be to intubate, not to move on to the “E” of the primary survey (Exposure). Remember, “GCS 8 (or less) -> INTUBATE.” 
❌ GCS 9, remove the patient’s clothing and assess for signs of injury :
Incorrect: While it is true that if this patient had a GCS of 9, the best next step would be to move on to the “E” of the primary survey and expose the patient fully to assess for signs of injury; however, this patient has a GCS of 7.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department from a rehabilitation facility for evaluation of a wound on her left heel. She was hospitalized and received IV antibiotics for the same issue three weeks ago. Her symptoms resolved and she was discharged to rehab. However, she was brought back to the ED today because the wound care nurse felt that her left heel was re-infected. She has not had fevers or chills. She takes insulin for IDDM and rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. Labs are pending. Physical exam is notable for a pressure ulcer on her left heel that has subcutaneous fat present and tunnels 3 cm in all directions. There is surrounding erythema and induration but no purulence. What is the stage of this ulcer, and what is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Stage 2 → bedside debridement and moist dressings
Stage 3 → operative debridement, moist dressings, and consider skin grafting
Stage 3 → bedside debridement and moist dressings
Stage 4 → bedside debridement to properly stage

questions.solution:
This patient has a Stage 3 pressure ulcer on the bony prominence of her left heel. Stage 3 ulcers require operative debridement, moist dressings, and planning for future wound coverage, which may include skin grafting.

Pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries are localized areas of damage to the skin and underlying tissue that usually occur over bony prominences as a result of pressure or pressure in combination with shear forces (eg, sacrum, calcaneus, ischium). Lesions are typically related to immobility but can also result from poorly fitting casts or other medical equipment or devices. The management of pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries begins with a clinical assessment of the wound and a comprehensive assessment of the patient's general medical condition and risk factors to identify reversible conditions that can be managed.

Signs and symptoms of pressure ulcers can include pain, infection, subcutaneous tracking, and there may rarely be underlying malignancy. Several staging systems have been developed to describe the extent of pressure-induced injury to the skin. The most commonly used system is the National Pressure Injury Advisory Panel (NPIAP) (see table above). Staging the pressure injury helps guide treatment.

In general, treatment of pressure injuries should address the following: pain control, treatment of infection if present, redistribution of pressure, optimization of nutrition, and local wound care. Stage 1 ulcers require local wound care. Stage 2 ulcers require bedside debridement, and Stage 3 and 4 ulcers require operative debridement and potential wound coverage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Stage 2 → bedside debridement and moist dressings:
Incorrect: Stage 2 pressure ulcers have partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, moist, and may also present as an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister. There is no fat showing typically. While bedside debridement and moist dressings is appropriate management for stage 2 ulcers, this patient has exposed fat, making her ulcer Stage 3.  
❌ Stage 2 → cover for protection:
Incorrect: Management of stage 2 ulcers requires debridement of infected and necrotic tissue with subsequent moist dressing coverage. Moreover, this case depicts a Stage 3 ulcer as fat is showing.
✅ Stage 3 → operative debridement, moist dressings, and consider skin grafting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stage 3 → bedside debridement and moist dressings:
Incorrect: While this patient does have a Stage 3 ulcer, the management of stage 3 ulcers is operative debridement and potential skin coverage with either synthetic or autologous grafts. Bedside debridement is inappropriate for Stage 3 ulcers.  
❌ Stage 4 → bedside debridement to properly stage:
Incorrect: Stage 4 ulcers involve full-thickness skin and tissue loss with exposure of bone, muscle, tendon and/ fascia. This patient’s ulcer is Stage 3. Moreover, the treatment of Stage 4 ulcers is the same as for Stage 3 ulcers – operative debridement and wound coverage.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by EMS for right foot pain. The patient states that he has had right foot pain for “weeks” and that it has progressively worsened. The patient is unsure whether there has been drainage from the wound, and given that it's on the underside of his right foot, he has not been able to visualize it. He has no pain in his legs or feet when walking. He has a history of substance use disorder. He is currently experiencing homelessness. He does not have access to healthcare or medication, but he knows that he should be on medication for one of his health conditions. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Physical exam of the right foot is notable for a clean-based ulcer on the bony prominence of the first toe of the right foot with surrounding induration - a probe reaches the bone. There is no lower extremity edema and pulses are intact bilaterally. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform at this time?  

Labs

WBC  
 15.1 x 109/L  
Hgb
 13.2 g/dL  
Hct
 37.1  
PLT
 553/µL  
CRP
 135 mg/L  
ESR
 95 mm/h  
 Hgb A1c  
 9.2%  


Image Courtesy of Wikimedia

choices.text: CT-A of the bilateral lower extremities
No further testing as clinical exam is sufficient for diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with risk factors and a physical exam consistent with a diabetic foot ulcer. Given his fever, elevated inflammatory markers, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (Hgb A1c > 6.5%), and probe extending to the bone, he likely has underlying osteomyelitis and an MRI of the right foot should be performed for diagnosis.

Ulceration in diabetic patients can result from neuropathy alone or a combination of neuropathy and ischemia. Diabetic ulcers commonly occur in locations that experience repeated trauma, such as the plantar metatarsal heads and dorsal interphalangeal joints. When evaluating diabetic foot ulcers, it is important to determine the extent and depth of the wound, the presence of ischemia, and the presence of infection, all of which will help determine which diagnostic studies and treatments are appropriate. Approximately 60% of diabetic foot ulcers are complicated by infection.

Osteomyelitis is a common complication of diabetic foot ulcers. Certain clinical findings should raise suspicion of osteomyelitis. These include grossly visible bone or probe-to-bone, large and deeper ulcers, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (70 mm/h). MRI is the diagnostic modality of choice - it is highly sensitive and specific for osteomyelitis and superior to radiographs, three-phase bone scans, and white blood cell scans.  

Option Analysis

❌ X-Ray of the right foot  :
Incorrect: Plain radiographs can detect structural foot deformities, soft tissue gas, and foreign bodies and may be able to detect osteomyelitis. However, radiologic changes in osteomyelitis typically occur late in the course of the disease, and negative radiographs do not exclude the diagnosis. MRI of the foot should be performed for diagnosis, especially in early disease.  
❌ Tagged WBC Scan:
Incorrect: A tagged WBC, also known as a tagged leukocyte scan, uses radioactive WBCs to identify areas of inflammation. Tagged WBC scans have similar sensitivity to bone scans for evaluation of osteomyelitis. However, they are time-consuming, require complex preparation, and are expensive. They are not the first-line diagnostic test for osteomyelitis, but they are sometimes useful in patients with Charcot arthropathy.  
✅ MRI of the right foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT-A of the bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: CT-A would be useful in cases where there is suspected arterial insufficiency. The locations of ischemic ulcers are typically in the most distal part of the toes. This patient does not have a history or physical exam findings consistent with arterial insufficiency, but instead has signs of infection and poorly controlled diabetes, making an infected diabetic ulcer the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ No further testing as clinical exam is sufficient for diagnosis:
Incorrect: This patient has systemic signs of infection and an ulcer where the probe extends to the bone, which raises suspicion of osteomyelitis. While a clinical exam is sufficient to diagnose the type of ulcer present, it is insufficient to rule out underlying osteomyelitis. MRI is required.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with voice hoarseness and dysphagia. She palpated a lump in the anterior neck that was not present before her symptoms began. She has not had odynophagia or weight loss. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a palpable, solitary anterior neck mass. No lymphadenopathy is detected. Ultrasound of the neck reveals a solid lesion measuring 2.35 cm in diameter with microcalcifications, irregular margins, and extrathyroidal extension with local invasion and compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration reveals malignant cells. Histology shows papillae lined with differentiated epithelial cells, which appear pale Orphan-Annie nuclei. Calcific concretions with a circular, laminated appearance are seen in the stroma. CT scan shows no lymph node involvement and no metastasis. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with postoperative thyroid hormone replacement
Parathyroidectomy with postoperative parathyroid hormone replacement

questions.solution:
This patient’s history, clinical presentation, and histopathological findings are consistent with papillary carcinomawith extrathyroidal extension. The treatment of choice for papillary carcinoma with extrathyroidal extension is total thyroidectomy with lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Total thyroidectomy is recommended in cases of differentiated thyroid cancer where the primary tumor is 4 cm in diameter or greater, there is extrathyroidal extension of the tumor, or there are metastases to lymph nodes or distant sites. Thyroid lobectomy is typically performed for non-metastatic low-risk disease following CT-assisted TNM staging. Lobectomy with an intraoperative frozen section is usually done first, and if capsular invasion is seen, then total thyroidectomy is performed. In metastatic disease after treatment with total thyroidectomy, patients may need radioactive iodine, radiation, or targeted systemic therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Total thyroidectomy with postoperative thyroid hormone replacement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid lobectomy:
Incorrect: Patients at low risk for recurrent or metastatic disease without extrathyroidal extension can undergo thyroid lobectomy. Because of this tumor’s extrathyroidal extension and impingement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a lobectomy would not be appropriate treatment; total thyroidectomy is required.  
❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Medical treatment with chemotherapy is typically reserved for more aggressive forms of thyroid carcinoma, such as anaplastic carcinoma or when metastasis is present in differentiated thyroid cancer. This patient has localized/non-metastatic papillary thyroid cancer for which surgery is the mainstay of treatment.  
❌ Radioactive iodine:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine, radiation, and targeted systemic therapy are used in the treatment of thyroid carcinoma when metastasis is present. Since this patient does not have metastatic disease, this is not an appropriate treatment.  
❌ Parathyroidectomy with postoperative parathyroid hormone replacement:
Incorrect: Medullary thyroid carcinoma that is positive for the RET mutation is strongly associated with other endocrine carcinomas. Evaluation and treatment for parathyroid carcinoma (via serum calcium) and pheochromocytoma (via plasma metanephrines) with appropriate treatment, which may include parathyroidectomy, should be performed. However, this patient has features consistent with papillary and not medullary thyroid carcinoma

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty swallowing, initially with solid foods but now also with liquids. She describes a sensation of food 'sticking' in her throat and pain with swallowing. She has also experienced occasional regurgitation of undigested food, unintentional weight loss (baseline BMI of 20.7), and a persistent dry cough, especially at night. She has a history of H. pylori infection that was treated one year ago and resolved. She has a 30-pack year smoking history and currently smokes a pack a day. She drinks one alcoholic drink every few months when she meets up with friends. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 76/min, blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. BMI is 19. Oral examination is unremarkable. Neck examination shows no lymphadenopathy. Abdominal examination is significant for mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy reveals an esophageal lesion. Which of the following most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) first to solids and then to liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, pain with swallowing (odynophagia), significant weight loss, and a persistent dry cough and is found to have an esophageal lesion on EGD. This patient likely has esophageal cancer and smoking likely contributed to the development of esophageal cancer in this patient.    

Many patients with esophageal cancer are asymptomatic or symptoms are subtle. Patients may present with iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss. Patients with advanced disease may present with progressive dysphagia (initially to solids, then to liquids), odynophagia (painful swallowing), unexplained weight loss, and possibly regurgitation of undigested food. Patients may also have persistent cough or hoarseness, reflecting the tumor's impact on adjacent structures.      

Smoking and chronic alcohol use are significant risk factors for esophageal cancer, and they act synergistically, particularly for squamous cell carcinoma.
