Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is another risk factor. It can lead to Barrett esophagus, predisposing individuals to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Dietary factors, such as consumption of very hot beverages, poor intake of fresh fruits and vegetables, and intake of preserved foods, can also contribute. Additionally, a history of head and neck cancers, exposure to certain chemicals (like lye), and genetic predispositions can increase the risk as well.  

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: This patient with dysphagia, odynophagia, unintentional weight loss, and persistent cough likely has esophageal cancer. While chronic alcohol consumption is a risk factor for esophageal cancer, it is usually in the context of heavy, long-term use. Her occasional alcoholic drink has not likely contributed to the development of esophageal cancer.
❌ BMI at baseline:
Incorrect: This patient had a normal BMI at baseline. A high BMI is associated with the development of esophageal cancer.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: This patient likely has esophageal cancer. Esophageal cancer, especially squamous cell carcinoma, is more common in men than women. 
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: This patient likely has esophageal cancer. Although Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with gastric cancer, its role in esophageal cancer is less clear. Studies have shown that it is protective for esophageal adenocarcinoma. The patient's smoking history is a more direct and significant risk factor for esophageal cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of difficulty swallowing that began with solids and has progressed to liquids over the past three months. Additionally, he reports a recent onset of voice hoarseness and chest pain when eating. He has unintentionally lost 10 kg (22 lbs) during the past three months. He has no significant past medical history. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and consumes 3 drinks of alcohol approximately 5 nights a week. BMI is 21 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 88/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. He appears pale and thin. There is no palpable lymphadenopathy in the neck. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make a diagnosis?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive dysphagia, unintentional weight loss, voice hoarseness, and a history of smoking and excessive alcohol use. Progressive dysphagia, progressing from dysphagia with solids to dysphagia with liquids can be seen in esophageal cancer as the lumen narrows due to a growing tumor.  When esophageal cancer is suspected, esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsies should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.    

EGD with biopsy, allows for direct visualization of the esophagus, assessment of tumor extent, and tissue sampling for histological evaluation. Histopathology will differentiate between the two main types of esophageal cancer: adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma, often located in the distal esophagus, is commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and Barrett esophagus. In contrast, squamous cell carcinoma typically arises in the upper and middle esophagus and is strongly linked to smoking and alcohol use.    

Following diagnosis, staging should be done with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scans of the chest and abdomen (+/- pelvis) to assess for local invasion and distant metastases. Endoscopic ultrasound is used to evaluate tumor depth and nearby lymph node involvement, and a PET scan may be performed to assess for metastatic disease. Accurate staging is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which may vary significantly based on the stage and histological subtype.  

Option Analysis

✅ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Barium swallow study:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having esophageal cancer. A barium swallow can delineate structural abnormalities of the esophagus but lacks specificity and is not able to provide a histological diagnosis. It may be useful in the initial evaluation of dysphagia but is not the best next step in suspected esophageal cancer.
❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: While a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is part of the staging for esophageal cancer, particularly for assessing metastasis, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis or histological classification. 
❌ Esophageal manometry:
Incorrect: Esophageal manometry is used for diagnosing motility disorders, which typically cause dysphagia in both solids and liquids from the start, unlike this patient’s progressive dysphagia. Given his clinical presentation and risk factors, esophageal cancer is more likely, and should be diagnosed with EGD with biopsies.
❌ 24-hour pH monitoring:
Incorrect: This test evaluates for gastroesophageal reflux disease, which can be a precursor to adenocarcinoma, but it cannot make a histological diagnosis of esophageal cancer. This patient’s symptoms suggest esophageal cancer and EGD with biopsies is necessary for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with two days of sharp abdominal pain and vomiting. Past medical history includes bipolar disorder and pituitary microadenoma without laboratory abnormalities. His only medication is valproic acid. Past surgical history includes appendectomy, cholecystectomy, and inguinal hernia repair. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, there is diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation and hypoactive bowel sounds. There is no abdominal rigidity or guarding. Computed tomography of the abdomen reveals a high-grade small bowel obstruction without any intra-abdominal masses. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm with a QT interval of 420 ms. A nasogastric tube is placed and the patient is started on intravenous fluids. The patient requests an anti-nausea medication. Which of the following is a contraindication to metoclopramide use?
questions.solution:
This patient has small bowel obstruction, likely due to prior abdominal surgery. Bowel obstruction is a contraindication to metoclopramide therapy.      

Metoclopramide blocks dopamine receptors in the brain. Moreover, it facilitates muscarinic receptor-mediated gastric emptying and increases lower esophageal sphincter tone. It is commonly used for gastroparesis in patients with diabetes mellitus.    

Metoclopramide is contraindicated in patients with bowel obstruction since the medication promotes gastrointestinal motility and can worsen the symptoms of obstruction. The medication should be avoided in patients with Parkinson’s disease due to its anti-dopaminergic properties.    

Metoclopramide can precipitate tardive dyskinesia in patients on other anti-dopaminergic agents (e.g., haloperidol, aripiprazole) and thus concurrent administration should be done with caution. It can also elevate prolactin levels and should be avoided in patients with hyperprolactinemia. Finally, the medication can prolong the QT interval.

Option Analysis

❌ Pituitary microadenoma:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide can raise prolactin levels and should be avoided in patients with hyperprolactinemia. However, this patient has a clinically silent pituitary microadenoma, which implies that prolactin and other pituitary hormone levels are normal.
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide should be avoided in patients taking antipsychotics as the combined anti-dopaminergic effects can precipitate tardive dyskinesia. However, bipolar disorder itself is not a contraindication to metoclopramide, and valproic acid does not have significant effects on dopaminergic pathways.
❌ Presence of nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: The presence of a nasogastric tube is not a contraindication to promotility agents (e.g., erythromycin, metoclopramide).
✅ Small bowel obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ QT interval of 420 ms:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide should be used cautiously in patients with slight QT interval prolongation and avoided in patients with significant QT prolongation. Definitions of normal QT intervals vary slightly by source, but in general, less than 430-450 in males and less than 450-470 in females is considered within normal range.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is seen on morning rounds reporting fevers, chills, and generalized abdominal pain. Five days ago, the patient sustained a gunshot wound to the abdomen that required exploratory laparotomy and resection of damaged portions of the bowel. The patient has not yet had a post-op return of bowel function. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals extreme abdominal tenderness to palpation and rebound tenderness that is most prominent in the lower abdomen. The abdomen is also mildly distended and bowel sounds are decreased. The surgical incision site and bullet wounds appear unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a leukocytes count of 17,000/mm3. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 cm abscess in the lower abdomen. The abscess is drained and fluid culture reveals methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria. Which of the following antibiotics should be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with peritonitis and an intra-abdominal abscess. Culture of the abscess fluid reveals methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria. Among the answer choices, the most appropriate treatment option is cefoxitin, a second-generation cephalosporin.

Second-generation cephalosporins include cefaclor, cefprozil, cefuroxime, cefotetan, and cefoxitin. This subgroup usually has slightly less activity against Gram-positive organisms when compared to first-generation cephalosporins. However, second-generation cephalosporins are more resistant to beta-lactamase and have greater Gram-negative coverage. They can be used to treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Serratia marcescens, Enterobacter aerogenes, and some Neisseria species. In addition, cefotetan and cefoxitin are the only cephalosporins that provide coverage against anaerobic bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis, which cause peritonitis and intra-abdominal abscesses.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Cefazolin:
Incorrect: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin. It does not have coverage against anaerobic bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis.  
✅ Cefoxitin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Penicillin G:
Incorrect: Penicillin G is the first-line medication for the treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis and provides prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever. It can also be used to treat infections caused by organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Treponema pallidum. It is, however, not effective against Bacteroides fragilis.  
❌ Aztreonam:
Incorrect: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is effective against aerobic Gram-negative rods. It is not effective against Gram-positive bacteria or anaerobes.  
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It can be used in the management of Borrelia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia infections. However, it is not effective against Bacteroides fragilis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician's office for evaluation of a dark brown skin lesion on his left upper extremity as seen in the image below. He states that he has had this lesion for several years, but his partner thought that it appeared different and suggested that he have it evaluated. The patient has a significant history of sun exposure. He was a swimmer and lifeguard throughout his childhood and into his young adulthood. He rarely used sunscreen and had several bad burns in his youth. He has a history of basal cell carcinoma on his face that was removed. His only medication is lisinopril for high blood pressure. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following physical examination findings would prompt a further diagnostic evaluation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
This man presents to the primary care office with a concerning skin lesion in the setting of a significant history of sun exposure and prior burns. The patient’s wife believes that the lesion is evolving over time. Given his age and risk factors, he is at high risk for melanoma. The finding of a lesion with a diameter of 9 mm is concerning for melanoma and should prompt further evaluation with a biopsy.

Melanoma is the most serious form of skin cancer and the fifth most common cancer in males and females in the United States. When patients present with concerning lesions they should be questioned about whether, and how the lesion has changed over time, when it was first noticed, and whether the patient has a personal or family history of melanoma or other skin cancers. Additional questions should focus on the patient’s history of sun exposure, tanning bed use, severe sun burns, and immunosuppression.

Physical examination should evaluate for concerning findings which are included in the ABCDE criteria: asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter > 6 mm, and evolution over time. If any of these criteria are met, further diagnosis should be pursued. It is also important to include a thorough examination of the adjacent lymph node basins when malignancy is suspected.  

Option Analysis

❌ Uniform color:
Incorrect: Uniform color without any color variation would be more suggestive of a nevus, opposed to a melanoma, which can exhibit various color shades. Uniform color would not be an indication for further workups.  
❌ Well circumscribed borders:
Incorrect: In general, lesions or masses that are well-circumscribed are typically benign. Lesions that have irregular borders are typically more worrisome for melanoma. A lesion having well-circumscribed borders would not prompt further evaluation.  
✅ Diameter of 9 mm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Symmetrical lesion:
Incorrect: Symmetrical lesions are most likely benign and would not require further workup. Asymmetrical lesions are more worrisome for melanoma and would prompt further diagnostic evaluation.  
❌ Soft, rubbery, mobile mass:
Incorrect: This description matches that of a lipoma. While an ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis, it is usually unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician's office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the abdomen. The patient noticed the lesion while showering 3 weeks ago. He has no significant past medical history. Physical exam shows a 3 mm dome-shaped, red lesion on the abdomen that does not blanch with pressure as seen in the image below. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the likely diagnosis?
 
Wikipedia

choices.text: Increase in size of the lesion after weight loss
Multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time

questions.solution:
This man presents to the office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on his abdomen that appears as a 3 mm dome-shaped, red lesion on the abdomen that does not blanch with pressure. This description is typical of a cherry angioma. The finding of multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time would be consistent with the diagnosis, as cherry angiomas typically increase in number and size as patients age.

Cherry angiomas (Campbell de Morgan spots) are made up of mature capillary proliferations that are common in middle-aged and older adult patients. They are benign vascular tumors. They tend to be less conspicuous in patients with darkly pigmented skin and are most common on the trunk. They may bleed significantly with trauma.

Cherry angiomas appear as dome shaped red to dark red lesions that are typically 0.1 to 0.4 cm in diameter, and they do not blanch with pressure. Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance. Examination with a dermatoscope will show characteristic red, purple, or blue-black lagoons. They do not need to be treated unless patients are bothered by them.  

Option Analysis

❌ Associated pruritus:
Incorrect: Cutaneous warts are caused by infection with the human papillomavirus, or HPV. They typically appear on the fingers of children or young adults and may cause mild pain or pruritus. Cherry angiomas as seen in this patient do not typically cause pruritus.  
❌ Increase in size of the lesion after weight loss:
Incorrect: Lipomas are fatty tumors that typically reside in the subcutaneous space. They are soft, rubbery, round, mobile masses located on the head, neck, shoulders, and back. They can become more prominent after weight loss due to a reduction in subcutaneous fat levels.  
✅ Multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Associated purulence:
Incorrect: Epidermoid or sebaceous cysts can have purulent discharge if they become infected. Cherry angiomas do not typically develop a purulent discharge.  
❌ Associated pain:
Incorrect: Painful tumors of the skin typically present as dermal or subcutaneous nodules. They can originate from many sources including eccrine glands, fibrous tissue, infiltration of benign (endometrium) or malignant (metastatic neoplasm) tissue, muscle, nerve, or vascular structures. Cherry angiomas are not typically associated with pain.

questions.text:
A 5-week-old boy presents to the emergency department (ED) with 3 days of vomiting. His parent reports that he was born at term via vaginal delivery and was discharged within 24 hours. Since then, he has been feeding, voiding, and stooling normally. Over the last few days, however, he has developed projectile, non-bilious emesis after each feeding. His last wet diaper was approximately 12 hours ago. In the ED, his temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 172/min, respirations are 52/min, blood pressure is 62/25 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. On physical examination, the patient has a sunken anterior fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, and capillary refill in 6 seconds. His abdomen is non-distended, and on palpation, a small round mass in the right upper quadrant is felt. Bloodwork and intravenous (IV) access is obtained, and the results are shown below. What is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Serum chemistry

Sodium
137 mEq/L
Potassium
3.1 mEq/L
Chloride
85 mEq/L
CO2
34 mEq/L
Creatinine
0.31 mg/dL
BUN
10 mg/dL
Complete blood count

Leukocyte Count
8.2 g/dL

15.4 g/dL
Hematocrit
46 %  
Platelet Count
225,000/mm3
Venous Blood Gas

pH
7.52
PCO2

PO2
33 mmHg
HCO3
40.8 mmol/L

choices.text: IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion

questions.solution:
This 5-week-old boy’s history of new-onset non-bilious, post-prandial, projectile vomiting, physical exam with signs of hypovolemia and a palpable round abdominal mass, and hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, are consistent with pyloric stenosis. In this patient, initial assessment demonstrates hemodynamic instability (tachycardia and hypotension), so the next steps in management are to provide IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion.

Pyloric stenosis most commonly presents in patients between 2 and 6 weeks of age with forceful vomiting due to partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. Oral intolerance and vomiting result in dehydration, which can range from mild to severe, sometimes even resulting in hypovolemic shock. Excessive vomiting can also cause metabolic abnormalities, most commonly hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

The acute management of a patient with suspected pyloric stenosis consists of assessing and addressing the ABCDE’s. If the patient is unstable, the airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. Stabilizing circulation includes obtaining IV access and providing IV fluid resuscitation. It is also essential to correct electrolyte abnormalities in these patients. Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, abdominal ultrasound can be obtained to confirm the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.Once electrolyte abnormalities and fluid status are corrected, the patient can proceed to the operating room for surgical pyloromyotomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral rehydration with electrolyte-containing solution:
Incorrect: While oral rehydration is a reasonable starting point for certain patients with dehydration, this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and he should therefore be kept nil per os (NPO) until the diagnosis is confirmed. Furthermore, given that he has findings consistent with severe dehydration/hypovolemia, and he has electrolyte abnormalities. He should receive IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and abdominal ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice to confirm this diagnosis, he is currently hemodynamically unstable due to hypovolemia, and must first be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion.
❌ Fluoroscopic upper-gastrointestinal (GI) series:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and imaging should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis, abdominal ultrasound, not upper GI series, is the initial imaging modality of choice. This hemodynamically unstable patient should be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion before imaging is obtained.  
❌ Urgent pyloromyotomy:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, for which pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment, this diagnosis has not been confirmed with imaging, and the priority in the management of this hemodynamically unstable patient is IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old girl presents to the emergency department (ED) with recurrent postprandial emesis. She was born at term via cesarean section, has no known medical conditions and is primarily formula-fed. Her parents report that she has had intermittent episodes of non-bilious postprandial emesis since birth, but over the last several days they have become more frequent and forceful, even “shooting across the room” per her parent. She was seen by her pediatrician two days ago and an alternative formula was recommended; however, her symptoms have persisted. Her last wet diaper was approximately 8 hours ago and her last bowel movement occurred yesterday and was normal in character. In the ED, her temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 165/min, blood pressure is 68/35 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99%. Results of laboratory studies are shown. Abdominal ultrasound shows a target sign. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?  

Laboratory value
Result
Complete Metabolic Panel  

Sodium
138 mEq/L
Potassium
3.4 mEq/L
Chloride
88 mEq/L
CO2
30 mEq/L
Creatinine
0.29 mg/dL
BUN
9 mg/dL
Total bilirubin
4.9 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin
0.1 mg/dL
Complete blood count

Leukocyte Count
6.3 g/dL
Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL
Hematocrit
39.6 %
Platelet Count
270,000/mm3

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus
Incomplete counterclockwise rotation of the midgut around the superior mesenteric pedicle

questions.solution:
In this 6-week-old girl with persistent postprandial emesis that is forceful, non-bilious, and not accompanied by other gastrointestinal or systemic symptoms, pyloric stenosis should be suspected. Laboratory studies demonstrating hypokalemia, hypochloremia, elevated bicarbonate, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia support the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, and the finding of a thickened pylorus (target sign) confirms it. Pyloric stenosis is caused by hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus.

The circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus act as a muscular valve between the stomach and the duodenum. Hypertrophy of these muscles can result in pyloric stenosis. This most commonly presents between 2 and 6 weeks of age. Pyloric stenosis often leads to complete or near-complete gastric outlet obstruction, which can present as forceful postprandial vomiting that is non-bilious, as the stomach fills with ingested liquid that is unable to pass into the duodenum. Excessive vomiting in turn causes dehydration and metabolic abnormalities like hypokalemic and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. Ultrasound may show evidence of a thickened and elongated pylorus that can be seen as a “target sign”.
 

Transverse ultrasound of pyloric stenosis shows a cross-sectional view of the thickened pylorus (“target sign”). The diameter is measured between the 1 calipers, and the single wall thickness is measured between the 2 calipers.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Viral infection can cause Gastroenteritis with emesis and dehydration in infants. However, it is typically accompanied by diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis.  
❌ Incompetent lower esophageal sphincter:
Incorrect: Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is a common cause of emesis in infants and is in part caused by the incompletely developed lower esophageal sphincter. However, emesis is typically intermittent and does not cause significant dehydration or electrolyte abnormalities.  
❌ Incomplete counterclockwise rotation of the midgut around the superior mesenteric pedicle:
Incorrect: Intestinal malrotation results from the partial or complete failure of the midgut to rotate 270 degrees around the superior mesenteric pedicle during fetal development. This can lead to volvulus, which can cause recurrent emesis and significant dehydration. However, emesis is typically bilious.  
❌ Type I hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Milk protein allergy can result from an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction and cause emesis in infants. However, emesis is often accompanied by respiratory and/or cutaneous symptoms and does not cause significant dehydration or electrolyte abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old boy was transferred from an outside hospital to a pediatric tertiary care center yesterday with a suspected diagnosis of pyloric stenosis based on history and physical exam. The prior emergency department physician reported that the patient was initially tachycardic and hypotensive, and his parents stated that he had not voided in at least 12 hours. IV access was obtained, IV fluid resuscitation was initiated, and his hemodynamics began to improve prior to transfer. After transfer to the pediatric hospital, an abdominal ultrasound was obtained and findings confirmed the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis. Today, his temperature is 36.8 °C (98.2 ºF), pulse is 140/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Laboratory results from this morning are shown below. He has had 2 wet diapers in the last 12 hours, no bowel movements, and no further episodes of emesis. He remains nil per os (NPO) with weight-based maintenance IV fluids running. What is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Serum Chemistry

Sodium
136 mEq/L
Potassium
4.1 mEq/L
Chloride
95 mEq/L
CO2
33 mEq/L
Creatinine
0.31 mg/dL
BUN
9 mg/dL
Venous Blood Gas

pH
7.48
PCO2
47 mmHg
PO2
35 mmHg
HCO3
38.2 mmol/L

choices.text: Fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work
Resumption of oral feeding once the patient has flatus/bowel movement

questions.solution:
In this patient with a confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis by abdominal ultrasound, the definitive treatment is surgical pyloromyotomy. However, the initial step in management is holding oral feeds, correcting hypovolemia through IV fluid resuscitation, and correcting metabolic abnormalities. While this patient is no longer tachycardic, hypotensive, oliguric, or hypokalemic, he has persistent hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis that must be corrected preoperatively. Therefore, the next step in management is to continue appropriate IV fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work later in the day, targeting Cl >/=100 and CO2 (bicarbonate) </= 30.

Patients with pyloric stenosis typically present with some degree of dehydration, ranging from mild dehydration to hypovolemic shock. This is often accompanied by metabolic abnormalities, most commonly hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to prolonged persistent vomiting. In these patients, surgical pyloromyotomy is needed, but it is safest and best for the patient to ensure adequate resuscitation and medical optimization before surgery. In addition to normalization of vital signs and urine output, surgeons and anesthesiologists want to see a resolution of hypokalemia, to prevent cardiac arrhythmias, and metabolic alkalosis, to prevent depressed respiratory drive leading to prolonged postoperative intubation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immediate surgical pyloromyotomy:
Incorrect: While surgical pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment for pyloric stenosis and should be performed in this patient, his blood work demonstrates a persistent hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis which should be corrected prior to surgery.  
❌ Trial of oral feeding:
Incorrect: While a trial of oral feeding would be appropriate for patients with certain conditions like gastroenteritis, this patient has a radiographically confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, and should not be given oral feeds until the problem is surgically corrected.  
❌ Nasogastric tube placement:
Incorrect: Nasogastric (NG) tubes can be placed for gastric decompression or for enteral feeding. In patients with pyloric stenosis, NG tubes are not typically required for gastric decompression preoperatively, and this patient has not vomited since oral feeds were stopped. Additionally, enteral feeds (either oral or via NG tube) should not be started until the existing gastric outlet obstruction is surgically corrected with pyloromyotomy.  
❌ Resumption of oral feeding once the patient has flatus/bowel movement:
Incorrect: This patient has a confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, meaning a complete or near-complete gastric outlet obstruction is present which will need to be surgically corrected. Passage of flatus may occur if the obstruction is incomplete, and bowel movements may occur even in the presence of a complete obstruction. However, neither of these indications of bowel function beyond the pylorus would suggest that the patient will tolerate oral feeding.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a rash on her left breast. The patient first noticed a scaly, itchy rash that began on her left nipple two weeks ago and now has spread to the lateral aspect of the breast. Before the appearance of the rash, she experienced some burning pain on the left nipple. There is no significant family medical history. Vital signs are unremarkable. Physical exam is notable for an eczematous lesion involving the left nipple with several excoriations extending laterally. No nipple discharge is noted, and the lymph node basins are unremarkable. A full-thickness punch biopsy is taken, and several days later it shows malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) occurring singly or in small groups within the epidermis of the nipple. A diagnostic mammography shows a 3 cm lesion in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, and a biopsy of the lesion shows ER+/PR+/HER2- invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following is the correct stage of this patient’s breast cancer?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an eczematous lesion involving her left nipple and lateral breast associated with pain and itching. Biopsy reveals Paget cells, and diagnostic mammography with biopsy diagnoses the patient with hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative, invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3 cm. Given that the lymph node exam is negative, this makes her T2cN0MX or Stage IIA.  

Patients with Paget disease of the breast typically present with a scaly, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion that begins on the nipple and spreads to the areola. Bloody nipple discharge may be seen. Pain, burning, and pruritus are commonly associated and often experienced before the lesion appears. It is typically associated with an underlying breast cancer in that breast.  

Patients with Paget disease of the breast have underlying breast cancer (in situ or invasive) in 85 to 88 percent of cases, although often without an associated palpable breast mass or screening mammographic abnormality. Therefore, all patients require a full-thickness skin biopsy and diagnostic mammography. Staging for breast cancer involves the TNM system: tumor, node, and metastasis. Early-stage breast cancer includes patients with stage I, IIA, and a subset of stage IIB, while locally advanced breast cancer includes patients with a subset of stage IIB, IIIA to IIIC.  

Most patients with early-stage disease can be offered surgery +/- chemotherapy/hormone therapy depending on the receptor status. Whereas, for locally advanced breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is usually recommended before surgery. Metastatic workup is only completed in locally advanced (disease that is T3 or greater, N2 or N3, M0), cases of inflammatory breast cancer, and in any patients with signs or symptoms suspicious of metastatic disease. 

Option Analysis

❌ Stage IA:
Incorrect: Stage IA patients are T1 (< 2cm) and cN0 (no palpable nodes). This patient’s lesion is larger than 2cm. Therefore she is stage IIA.
❌ Stage IIB:
Incorrect: Stage IIB is T2N1 or T3N0 disease; N1 disease means metastasis to ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes. This patient has T2N0 disease without lymph node spread and therefore is stage IIA. 
✅ Stage IIA:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Stage IIIA:
Incorrect: This involves T0-3 with N2 disease or T3N1 disease. T3 is > 5 cm. This patient’s lesion is 3 cm. 
❌ Stage IV:
Incorrect: Stage IV disease is any metastatic disease and/or inflammatory breast cancer, which involves the overlying skin.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department with anal discharge. He states that about two months ago, he had a painful bump near his anus that expressed fluid and then went away within a week. However, two days ago, he noticed that he had brown discharge in his underwear, and his perianal region has been itching. He does not have fevers, chills, or pain in the perianal region. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 65/min, blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Examination reveals no evidence of an abscess but shows an external opening on the left lateral surface of the peri-anal region. Slight pressure expresses scant brown discharge. Anoscopy does not show an internal opening. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with anal pruritus and discharge in the setting of a recently resolved peri-anal abscess has a peri-anal fistula, or fistula-in-ano. The incidence of an anal fistula developing from an anal abscess ranges from 15 to 38%. Over 90% of fistulas are cryptogenic, but the remaining 10% are due to Crohn’s disease, obstetric injuries, foreign bodies, or malignancy. To further examine a fistula and characterize the tract, patients require an exam under anesthesia (EUA).  

Patients with an anorectal fistula usually present with a "nonhealing" anorectal abscess following drainage or with chronic purulent drainage and a pustule-like lesion in the perianal or buttock area. It can be painless or patients may experience intermittent rectal pain, particularly during defecation, or with sitting and activity. Patients may also experience intermittent and malodorous perianal drainage and pruritus. Physical examinations vary, but typically the external opening can be seen.  

To further examine the fistula and characterize the tract prior to surgery, patients require an exam under anesthesia (EUA). Anal fistulas are classified in terms of their relationship to the anal sphincter muscles (see image above). Complex anal fistulas include high transsphincteric fistulas that involve ≥30 percent of the external sphincter; suprasphincteric, extrasphincteric, or horseshoe fistulas; and fistulas associated with Crohn’s disease, radiation, malignancy, or existing fecal incontinence. Simple anal fistulas do not have any of the above attributes and generally include superficial, intersphincteric, and low transsphincteric fistulas that involve <30 percent of the external sphincter. 

Option Analysis

❌ Fistulotomy:
Incorrect: A fistulotomy is a surgical procedure for simple fistulas that unroofs the fistula and allows the tract to scar over and heal within a matter of weeks. This patient needs to have their fistula characterized into simple or complex via an exam under anesthesia (EUA) prior to treatment.
❌ MRI of the pelvis:
Incorrect: In patients with complex or recurrent fistulas, as in patients with Crohn’s disease, imaging evaluation of the fistula tract is done with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). There are several options for imaging, including fistulography and computed tomography (CT). This patient does not have a history of recurrent or complex fistulas or Crohn’s disease, so the first step would be an EUA.
✅ Exam under anesthesia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Draining seton placement:
Incorrect: Placement of a draining seton is a treatment option for complex fistulas prior to definitive management. In order to determine if there is a simple or complex fistula, however, an exam under anesthesia is required.
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Incision and drainage is the appropriate treatment for a peri-anal abscess, and not a fistula. If this patient had presented with signs of an abscess like erythema and pain, and physical examination revealed an area of fluctuance and erythema consistent with an abscess, incision and drainage would need to be performed.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the office after an episode of bleeding per rectum. He states that he has always had issues with constipation, and often strains to use the bathroom. He has tried Miralax in the past, but it has made his stools “too loose,” so he stopped using it. Yesterday, when he got up from the toilet, he noticed blood in the toilet bowl, which alarmed him. He did not experience dizziness or lightheadedness. In the office, he is hemodynamically stable and afebrile. External anal exam shows no masses or lesions. Labs are pending. Which of the following characteristics would be most consistent with this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with painless rectal bleeding and a history of constipation without masses seen on external examination of the anus most likely has internal hemorrhoids. While internal hemorrhoids are typically not painful, they can be painful or achy when they are in the process of thrombosing or have already thrombosed. Thrombosed internal hemorrhoids typically present as tender palpable bluish external anal masses  

There are two types of hemorrhoids, external and internal. External hemorrhoids arise from the inferior hemorrhoidal plexus and are distal to the dentate line, so they are often located outside the anal opening. They are typically significantly painful. On the other hand, internal hemorrhoids arise from middle and superior hemorrhoidal veins and are located proximal to the dentate line and are typically painless.  

Risk factors for developing internal hemorrhoids include prolonged straining, sitting, or heavy lifting, pregnancy, and chronic constipation. Physical exam typically does not show an external mass except when hemorrhoids have prolapsed or thrombosed. Skin tags from old hemorrhoids may also be seen. 

Option Analysis

❌ PainfulPalpable MassDrainageYesYesYes:
Incorrect: These symptoms are characteristic of an abscess with a fistula. However, this patient likely has internal hemorrhoids, so no drainage would be expected, and internal hemorrhoids that are not thrombosing or thrombosed are painless.
❌ Painful Palpable Mass Drainage NoNoYes :
Incorrect: A fistula typically presents with drainage but without pain or a mass. Patients may  describe it as uncomfortable. This patient likely has internal hemorrhoids, so no drainage  would be expected, and internal hemorrhoids that are not thrombosing or thrombosed are  painless. 
❌ Painful Palpable Mass Drainage Yes Yes No :
Incorrect: This is a correct answer choice for patients with thrombosed or thrombosing  internal hemorrhoids where there can be pain and an external mass that can be palpated or  for patients with external hemorrhoids who typically have more severe pain and a palpable  mass. 
✅ Painful Palpable Mass Drainage No NoNo:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Painful Palpable Mass Drainage Yes No No:
Incorrect: This is a correct choice for patients with anal fissures which can present with rectal  bleeding and pain. Anoscopy would be painful for patients with anal fissures and would show  longitudinal tears, usually in the posterior midline, but not masses.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from an assisted living facility with shooting pain down his legs. His caregiver states that for the past three weeks, he has had pain at rest and with movement which the patient describes as a jolt of pain down his legs. The patient has also felt feverish in the last three weeks but has not had chills or weight loss. He has a history of Parkinson disease and has a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) for total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He has a remote history of intravenous (IV) drug use 20 years ago, but none since. His HbA1c is 5.4%, last checked two months ago. Temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has a PICC line in place with surrounding erythema, without drainage or fluctuance. Midline lumbar tenderness to palpation and 4/5 weakness in the lower extremities bilaterally. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging shows a fluid collection in the lumbar epidural space with rim enhancement and a hypointense center. Which of the following most likely led to this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Prior History of IV drug use

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of neuropathic leg pain and low-grade fevers. The exam findings of fever, focal lumbar tenderness, and bilateral lower extremity weakness suggest spinal epidural abscess (SEA), as confirmed by MRI. The presence of a PICC greatly predisposes this patient to SEA.

Spinal epidural abscess can develop in days or months and be a secondary complication of any condition that results in bacteremia. For example, injection drug use, dental abscess or manipulation, infective endocarditis, and indwelling catheters are all risk factors for SEA. Spinal trauma and medical interventions can directly cause SEA, including epidural catheter placement, lumbar puncture, and spinal surgeries. Spinal epidural abscess can also be caused by contiguous spread from a local infection, such as osteomyelitis of the vertebrae or abscess in a muscle.

The classic triad of clinical findings in a patient with SEA includes fever, back pain, and neurologic deficit; however, this triad is only initially present in a small number of patients. A high index of suspicion is needed to diagnose SEA, and cases often progress significantly before detection. Physical exam findings may reveal spinal tenderness and neurological deficits such as sensory loss, motor weakness, radiculopathy, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and even paralysis.

Option Analysis

❌ Prior History of IV drug use:
Incorrect: While current IV drug use significantly increases the risk of spinal epidural abscesses, a remote history of IV drug use does not.
❌ Parkinson Disease:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease is a risk factor for a multitude of psychiatric, motor, and autonomic conditions, but it is not a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess.
✅ PICC line:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes is a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess, however, this patient’s recent HbA1c level indicates he likely does not currently have diabetes since he is not on any diabetes medications.
❌ TPN:
Incorrect: TPN is a risk factor for metabolic dysfunction, including hyperglycemia, cirrhosis, and refeeding syndrome. It is not, in itself, a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of low back pain and fever. He has had chronic pain in the lower back for many years and received a lumbar facet joint injection with his pain specialist three months ago. Six weeks ago, he began noticing persistent pain in the lower back, different from his usual symptoms and unrelieved by medication or rest. The day before admission he developed a fever. The patient has a history of diabetes treated with Metformin and rheumatoid arthritis treated with daily prednisone. Temperature is 38.6oF (101.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 134/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Exam is notable for midline tenderness over L1. Neurological exam is nonfocal. X-ray reveals destructive changes in the body of L1 and L2 with the collapse of the disc space between the vertebrae. Which of the following next steps would be best to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with six weeks of lower back pain and new onset fever. The tenderness to palpation noted at L1, along with the destructive changes seen in the body of L1 and L2 on imaging make vertebral osteomyelitis the most likely diagnosis. Image-guided biopsy and culture are the preferred methods of confirming this diagnosis and will help guide antibiotic therapy. This patient’s recent facet injection may have led to his infection, especially with the additional risk factors of diabetes and immunosuppression from chronic steroid use.

Vertebral osteomyelitis should be suspected in the setting of new or worsening back or neck pain, especially with fever, and/or the presence of bloodstream infection or infective endocarditis. It should also be suspected in patients with fever and new peripheral neurologic symptoms (with or without back pain), and in patients with new back or neck pain following a recent episode of bacteremia (especially with S. aureus) or fungemia. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast should be ordered when vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected MRI. Results that are consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis include vertebral body bone marrow signal abnormality, loss of intervertebral disc space height, loss of margins between the vertebral body and disc space, vertebral body end plate destruction, and surrounding bone marrow and soft tissue edema. MRI in patients with a spinal epidural abscess would show fluid collection with rim enhancement and a hypointense center, dural enhancement, paraspinal and bone marrow edema, with longitudinal extension along the spinal column.

The diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis is established based on positive cultures obtained from an image-guided biopsy of the involved vertebra(e) and/or disc space. The diagnosis may be inferred in the setting of clinical and radiographic findings typical of vertebral osteomyelitis and positive blood cultures with a likely pathogen such as S. aureus. Similarly, the diagnosis may be inferred in the setting of histopathologic findings consistent with infection in the absence of positive culture data, particularly in the setting of recent antibiotic administration.

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most sensitive radiographic technique for detecting vertebral osteomyelitis; however, it cannot confirm the diagnosis. Confirmation requires biopsy and culture.
❌ Computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: Computed tomography (CT) is a reasonable alternative imaging modality when magnetic resonance imaging is not available and vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected; however, it cannot confirm the diagnosis. Confirmation requires biopsy and culture.
✅ Image-guided biopsy and culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: If a patient is unable to undergo an image-guided biopsy and culture, the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis may be inferred in the setting of clinical and radiographic findings typical of vertebral osteomyelitis and positive blood cultures with a likely pathogen such as Staphylococcus aureus.
❌ Operative exploration:
Incorrect: Taking a patient to the operating room for the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis is an unnecessary risk in this patient and not the preferred modality for confirming the diagnosis. Image-guided biopsy and culture are preferred for confirming the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the trauma bay of the emergency department (ED) after involvement in a motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver in a head-on collision with a truck traveling approximately 50 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the ED, the patient is intubated for airway protection, and shortly thereafter he becomes pulseless. Three rounds of CPR are administered with a return of spontaneous circulation. Massive transfusion protocol (MTP) is initiated. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room and undergoes an uncomplicated splenectomy and liver laceration repair. He is admitted to the ICU for further management. 12 hours after his presentation to the ED, there is blood oozing from multiple lines and wounds. Lab work reveals prolonged aPTT and PT decreased fibrinogen level, and elevated d-dimer. Which of the following physical exam findings would be expected based on this patient’s likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented as an unstable trauma patient requiring immediate intubation and initiation of massive transfusion protocol. Within 12 hours, he is noted to have oozing from multiple sites and lab work reveals prolonged clotting times, decreased fibrinogen and increased d-dimer indicating disseminated intravascular coagulation likely from trauma and massive transfusion. Patients with DIC may exhibit jaundice, petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, as well as hematuria and hemoptysis.       

Massive transfusion protocol (MTP) is a treatment for massive ongoing hemorrhage. It has been arbitrarily defined as the replacement by transfusion of ≥10 units of whole blood (WB) or red blood cells (RBCs) in 24 hours as an approximation of the replacement of at least one blood volume. In patients who have experienced trauma, MTP is indicated for active bleeding requiring surgery or angioembolization or for persistent hemodynamic instability.         

Traumatic DIC is characterized by microvascular oozing, prolongation of the PT and aPTT more than would be expected by dilution, significant thrombocytopenia, low fibrinogen levels, and increased D dimer. This is sometimes referred to as "traumatic disseminated intravascular coagulation" (traumatic DIC), although this is a misnomer, as there are several differentiating factors when compared to DIC. One of which is that antifibrinolytics (tranexamic acid) are beneficial in treating trauma patients with massive transfusion and DIC, and they are not recommended for use in other cases of DIC.   

Option Analysis

❌ Wheezing :
Incorrect: Patients with anaphylactic reactions to transfusions can exhibit wheezing. Given the oozing and abnormal coagulation studies, this patient is likely experiencing a consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma. Wheezing is not an associated symptom of this condition.  
❌ Rigid abdomen  :
Incorrect: Patients who are unstable with peritonitis can develop a rigid abdomen. Based on the clinical scenario, this patient is likely experiencing consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma, and the presence of petechiae, and not a rigid abdomen, would be expected.       
✅ Petechiae :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urticaria  :
Incorrect: Urticaria can be seen in anaphylactic or hypersensitivity reactions to transfusions. It is not seen with consumptive coagulopathy, which this patient likely has. Petechiae would be expected with consumptive coagulopathy. 
❌ Edema in the extremities  :
Incorrect: Edema in the extremities is commonly seen in patients who have been in the ICU 24-48 hours after they have been over-resuscitated with IV fluids. This patient is experiencing consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma. Edema of the extremities is not a specific finding in this condition.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the trauma bay after being struck by a cyclist while she was walking. Her primary survey was initially intact, but shortly after the secondary survey, her blood pressure drops to 62/30 mmHg. Intravenous (IV) access is obtained, and a massive transfusion protocol is initiated. Focused assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) examination is positive, and the patient is taken to the operating room where a grade IV liver laceration is identified and repaired. Her abdomen is temporarily closed, and she is taken to the trauma intensive care unit (ICU) for additional resuscitation. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 87/67mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient remains intubated and sedated with a wound vac in place over the temporary laparotomy incision. Initial labs are pending. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc of 510ms. Which of the following contributed to this patient’s ECG findings?

choices.text: Transfusion of Packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay after being struck by a cyclist while walking, resulting in a clinically significant liver laceration and initiation of a massive transfusion protocol (MTP). In the ICU, an ECG reveals a prolonged QTc interval. Given the recent MTP, this is likely due to the transfusion of packed red blood cells leading to hypocalcemia.       

Packed red blood cells are anticoagulated with sodium citrate and citric acid. Each 450 mL unit of blood contains 9 mmol of citrate. Massive transfusion leads to infusion of a large amount of citrate. Infused citrate can lead to a clinically significant fall in plasma-free calcium (ionized calcium) concentration, resulting in paresthesias and/or cardiac arrhythmias like prolonged QTc intervals.        

The risk of transfusion-induced hypocalcemia can be reduced by slowing the rate of transfusion and following physiologic markers such as blood pressure and corrected QT interval. Measuring the ionized calcium concentration with the ion-specific electrode on a blood gas machine is common. Calcium should be administered if patients are symptomatic from hypocalcemia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Transfusion of Prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is administered to reverse vitamin K antagonists in patients with major bleeding or those who need an urgent surgery/invasive procedure. It is not part of a massive transfusion protocol and would not lead to QTc prolongation. 
❌ Transfusion of Plasma:
Incorrect: Plasma is given to correct coagulation abnormalities. While it is part of the massive transfusion protocol, it would not lead to prolonged QTc of 510ms which is more likely caused by hypocalcemia.  
✅ Transfusion of Packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transfusion of Platelets:
Incorrect: Platelets are part of the massive transfusion protocol. Transfused platelets do not contain binding agents that would lead to clinically significant metabolic abnormalities like hypocalcemia.  
❌ Administration of Tranexamic Acid :
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that forms a reversible complex that displaces plasminogen from fibrin, resulting in the inhibition of fibrinolysis. TXA is often used for trauma patients with suspected moderate to severe hemorrhage who present within three hours of injury. It does not lead to QTc prolongation, nor is it part of the massive transfusion protocol.

questions.text: A 28-month-old girl is brought by her parent to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. She has had intermittent, crampy abdominal pain associated with nausea and bloody stool since the morning. She has not had a fever but recently recovered from an upper respiratory infection. She was born via an uncomplicated cesarean delivery and has no significant past medical history. The mother has a past medical history of bipolar disorder for which she takes medication. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 118/min, blood pressure is 104/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the right mid-abdominal area that is tender to palpation. There is no rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies and imaging are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and bloody stools, along with examination findings of a palpable tender “sausage-shaped” mass in the right mid-abdominal area, are consistent with a diagnosis of intussusception.        

Patients with intussusception are typically infants and toddlers who present with sudden onset intermittent, severe, crampy, abdominal pain. They may exhibit inconsolable crying and drawing up of the knees toward the abdomen (to relieve pain). Vomiting (either bilious or non-bilious) can be a prominent symptom, often starting shortly after the first episodes of abdominal pain. Stool is grossly bloody in up to 50 percent of cases. “Currant jelly” stools can be observed which contain a combination of mucous and blood. Abdominal examination may show no tenderness or point tenderness in the mid or lower right abdomen. A “sausage-shaped” abdominal mass may be palpated on the right side of the abdomen.        

The majority of cases of intussusception are idiopathic, although an increasing body of evidence suggests that viral triggers may play a role in some cases. Viral illnesses can stimulate the growth of Peyer’s patches in the terminal ileum which may create lead points for ileo-colic intussusception. This patient recently recovered from an upper respiratory infection which was likely the trigger for intussusception.    

Option Analysis

❌ Appendicitis :
Incorrect: Appendicitis can present with crampy abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting; however, it usually presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain and tenderness. This patient’s presentation and examination findings including the sausage-shaped mass are consistent with intussusception.  
❌ Ovarian torsion :
Incorrect: Although ovarian torsion is typically associated with acute, crampy abdominal pain, it is not associated with bloody stools. Additionally, while ovarian torsion can occur at any age, it typically happens in women of childbearing age.  
✅ Intussusception :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Toxic ingestion :
Incorrect: Toxic ingestion should always be in the differential diagnosis for children presenting with vague, crampy abdominal pain. There should be a review conducted of all the prescribed medications and over-the-counter medications in the home. 
❌ Gastroenteritis  :
Incorrect: Gastroenteritis is a common etiology for children presenting with abdominal pain. Typically, patients with gastroenteritis present with vomiting, diarrhea, and/or fever; all of which are absent in this patient. The bloody stool and palpable sausage-shaped mass are consistent with intussusception.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after being stabbed in the neck. The patient was at a party when an altercation ensued, and he was stabbed with a knife. The knife was withdrawn prior to EMS being called. In the field, his primary survey was intact, and a cervical collar was placed. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, there is profuse bleeding from the stab site and a rapidly expanding hematoma. The patient also has stridor and is anxious. The stab site appears to be superolateral to the cricoid cartilage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Immediately transport to the operating room

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay with a penetrating neck injury (PNI) in Zone 2 with a sign of hard injury (i.e., rapidly expanding hematoma). They are unstable and require immediate treatment. The management of patients with penetrating neck injuries is the same regardless of the type of trauma - the ABCs of Airway, Breathing, and Circulation should be followed. This patient’s airway should be secured with intubation prior to advancing in the primary survey.        

When evaluating a patient with a penetrating neck injury (PNI), the patient should be assessed for hard and soft signs of injury (table above). Hard signs reflect the presence of a severe injury. Unstable patients, including those with airway injury requiring immediate intervention, hemodynamic instability, or other severe injury from a penetrating neck wound, should be resuscitated and transferred expeditiously to the operating suite.        

When evaluating patients with a penetrating neck injury, focus should be on rapid stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients with PNI may initially appear stable but can decompensate rapidly. Surgical consultation should be obtained for all PNIs unless the wounds are determined to be superficial (ie the platysma muscle is not violated). Patients with PNI who are in obvious distress (eg, respiratory distress, severe hemorrhage, extensive or sucking neck wound, shock) require immediate stabilization of the airway.    

Option Analysis

❌ Control the bleeding :
Incorrect: Despite the desire to intervene and control bleeding, the A-B-C protocol must be followed with unstable patients. In the setting of a hard sign of injury (i.e. rapidly expanding hematoma), the patient’s airway needs to be secured before any other interventions.  
❌ Being massive transfusion protocol :
Incorrect: Given the degree of bleeding and hard signs of penetrating neck injury, massive transfusion will likely be initiated during acute management. However, it should occur after an airway has been established.  
✅ Secure the airway :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Establish IV access :
Incorrect: IV access should be established as soon as possible for resuscitation and lab draws, but it should not precede establishing an airway. 
❌ Immediately transport to the operating room  :
Incorrect: Patients with signs of hard injury to the neck, such as an expanding hematoma, require expeditious treatment in the operating room. However, this patient might not make it to the operating room if their airway is not secure at first.

questions.text: A 37-year-old cyclist presents to the trauma bay with part of a steel rod protruding from his neck. The patient was cycling down a hill when he lost control of his bike and hit a stake in the ground. He lost consciousness, and when he awoke, he realized that he had something sticking out of his neck and called 911. In the trauma bay, his primary survey is intact. Temperature is 36 °C (98 °F), heart rate is 106, blood pressure is 142/80 mm/Hg, and respiratory rate is 34/min. Labs are drawn and sent off. Secondary survey reveals a protruding metal object located just superior to the sternal notch with associated crepitus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT-A of the neck and chest

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay with a penetrating neck injury (PNI) from a metal rod that penetrated zone 1 of his neck while cycling. His primary survey is intact, but the secondary survey reveals tachypnea and crepitus, which is a sign of subcutaneous emphysema. These are both signs of soft injury and require further investigation with a CT-A of the neck and chest.        

When performing a secondary survey for a patient with PNI, it is crucial to understand the zones of the neck. Zone 1 extends from the sternal notch to the cricoid cartilage; Zone 2 from the cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible; Zone 3 from the angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Zone 1 injuries can involve the mediastinum, where vascular control can be difficult. Zone III vascular injuries, especially those that are more cephalad, can also pose a significant surgical challenge. Penetrating neck injuries (PNIs) can cross zone boundaries based on the implement or projectile and its angle of penetration.         

In addition to identifying the zones of the neck involved, the patient should be assessed for soft signs of injury.  These include non-expanding hematoma, minor hemoptysis, minor hematemesis, dysphonia, dysphagia, tachypnea, and signs of subcutaneous emphysema (ie crepitus). If a soft sign is identified, a CT-A of the chest and neck should be ordered.       

Option Analysis

❌ Remove the metallic object :
Incorrect: Until the extent and depth of the injury is explored, removing the object is not recommended. CT-A of the neck and chest should be performed next. 
❌ Proceed to the operating room :
Incorrect: In patients with hard signs of injury after a penetrating neck wound, proceeding to the operating room would be the next step. This patient, however, does not have any of these signs and imaging can be obtained with a CT-A of the neck and chest. 
✅ Obtain CT-A of the neck and chest :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intubate the patient :
Incorrect: While this patient is tachypneic, there is no evidence to suggest that the airway is not intact. Therefore, intubation is not indicated and imaging with CT-A of the neck and chest can be performed. 
❌ Observe for 4 hours  :
Incorrect: Clinical observation in a patient with soft signs of neck injury is not appropriate. Further investigation of the wound with CT-A is required.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after a gunshot wound to the neck. Primary survey is intact, and secondary survey reveals two bullet wounds. One is 2cm superior and lateral to the sternal notch, and the other is on the posterolateral aspect of the neck. The patient is hemodynamically stable. The remainder of the secondary exam is unremarkable, and the bullet wounds are hemostatic. CT-A is obtained of the head, neck and chest which reveals no sign of laryngotracheal or vascular injury; however, there is soft tissue edema on the right anterior cervical esophagus. In addition, the patient has started to spit up bloody saliva. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a CXR to evaluate for pneumomediastinum
Transport to the operating room for exploration

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay after a penetrating neck injury (PNI) from a gunshot wound. The primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey does not reveal signs of hard or soft injury. Initial CT-A scan shows peri-esophageal soft tissue edema. This finding, in combination with bloody saliva and an anatomic Zone 1 wound, is suspicious for an esophageal injury. The next step in management is to obtain a gastrografin swallow evaluation.         

Although relatively uncommon, penetrating esophageal injuries are insidious, and delays in diagnosis carry mortality rates as high as 20 percent. Delays over 24 hours further increase the mortality rate. If pharyngoesophageal trauma is suspected, CT alone is inadequate for definitively ruling out injury, although it often identifies some signs of injury.       

Practice guidelines from the Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma (EAST) recommend that either endoscopy of the esophagus or esophagography be used to rule out significant esophageal injury in stable patients with PNI. If the patient can cooperate, a gastrografin or thin barium swallow can be performed first, and if nondiagnostic, flexible esophagoscopy can then be performed, increasing sensitivity to nearly 100 percent.    

Option Analysis

❌ Make NPO and observe for 24 hours :
Incorrect: In patients like this one with a suspected esophageal injury, delays in diagnosis significantly increase morbidity and mortality. This patient requires a diagnostic evaluation of the esophagus. 
❌ Obtain a CXR to evaluate for pneumomediastinum :
Incorrect: Pneumomediastinum would have been identified on CT-A scan, so CXR is unnecessary. While the presence of air in the mediastinum can suggest a pharyngoesophageal injury, it is not diagnostic and a diagnostic study like a gastrografin swallow evaluation should be performed. 
✅ Perform a gastrografin swallow evaluation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transport to the operating room for exploration :
Incorrect: In patients with hard signs of injury after a penetrating neck injury, operative exploration is the definitive management. However, this patient does not have hard or soft signs of injury, so operative exploration is unnecessary and further diagnostic imaging of the esophagus should be performed. 
❌ Perform a bronchoscopy :
Incorrect: In patients with suspected laryngotracheal injury, CT-A is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosis. In cases where CT is equivocal and an injury is suspected, a bronchoscopy or flexible nasopharyngosocpy can be performed. This patient does not have signs of a laryngotracheal injury and further evaluation of the esophagus should be performed.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe right leg pain. The patient normally has pain after ambulating about 100 meters, but this morning she began having pain at rest. She tried to avoid coming to the hospital, but after seven hours, the pain never went away. Her last ankle brachial index was 0.8 on the left and 0.5 on the right. Past medical history is significant for bilateral lower extremity peripheral arterial disease and diabetes-associated peripheral neuropathy. Temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 141/92 mmHg. On physical exam, the right leg is cool and pale without palpable pulses or doppler signals. She cannot move the right foot, and there is numbness up to the mid-calf. CT angiography is ordered and pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment and subsequent study for this patient?

choices.text: Below the knee amputation; CT Chest with IV Contrast
Below the knee amputation; Carotid duplex ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient presents with pallor, pain, pulselessness, poikilothermia, paresthesia, and paralysis of the right leg. Given the absent pulses and duration of symptoms (> 6 hours) she can be diagnosed with a non-viable limb. The next step in management is below the knee amputation followed by a subsequent evaluation with echocardiogram to determine the source of the embolus.        

Patients with nonviable extremities should undergo prompt amputation. Vascular imaging prior to surgery is usually not necessary since the level of amputation is determined by clinical findings and by the viability of tissues at the time of surgery. Every effort should be made to preserve as many joints as possible to decrease the work of ambulating with a prosthesis, which improves the likelihood for successful rehabilitation. Delays in amputation of a nonviable extremity can result in infection, myoglobinuria, hyperkalemia, and acute kidney injury.       

Echocardiography is an integral part of the subsequent evaluation to determine the source of the embolus. It can generally be performed after the intervention for acute ischemia and should not delay treatment. Echocardiography can detect the presence of residual thrombus in the left atrium as well as evaluate for possible valvular pathology. Telemetry monitoring should also be used to evaluate for atrial fibrillation.   

Option Analysis

❌ Below the knee amputation; CT Chest with IV Contrast :
Incorrect: This patient has a non-viable limb and requires amputation (likely below the knee). She also needs an echocardiogram to help determine the source of embolism, likely from a cardiac thrombus or atrial fibrillation. CT Chest with IV contrast can be used to diagnose a pulmonary embolism but would not help determine the source of this patient’s embolism. 
❌ Below the knee amputation; Carotid duplex ultrasound :
Incorrect: This patient has a non-viable limb and requires amputation (likely below the knee). Carotid duplex ultrasound is used to evaluate patients after episodes of syncope or transient ischemic attack. This patient should have an echocardiogram to help determine the source of embolism. 
✅ Below the knee amputation; Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Open embolectomy; Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: An open embolectomy would be the preferred treatment for a threatened limb, but this patient with a non-viable limb requires amputation. Echocardiogram is needed postoperatively to determine the source of embolism. 
❌ Diagnostic angiogram with thrombectomy; Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: In patients with a proximal thrombus and threatened limb, revascularization with thrombectomy is a potential treatment option. However, this patient has a non-viable limb and is not eligible for revascularization. Echocardiogram should be performed postoperative to evaluate for the source of embolism.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic for a follow-up after a motor vehicle collision that occurred one week ago and resulted in a fractured left wrist without other injuries. As part of the trauma evaluation, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was done and revealed a hepatic lesion in segment 4 of the liver. The patient’s only past medical history is hypertension, which is well controlled with amlodipine. He does not have abdominal pain, jaundice, or recent weight loss. Physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following findings on initial imaging would prompt further diagnostic workup with multiphase contrast CT of the abdomen/pelvis?

choices.text: Lesion that is 6 cm with irregular margins
Small lesions showing no growth when compared to prior CT done one year ago
Lesion < 1 cm with smooth borders and multiple subcentimeter gallstones in the gallbladder

questions.solution:
This patient is asymptomatic with an incidental hepatic lesion found on abdominal CT with contrast. In asymptomatic patients without risk factors for malignant hepatic lesions, characteristics of the lesion on CT can be used to determine if further diagnostic evaluation is necessary. Features indicating the need for further diagnostic imaging include lesion size ≥ 1 cm, irregular borders/margins, and findings on initial CT that are consistent with malignancy or with benign lesions that would require treatment. Contrast-enhanced, multiphase imaging of the abdomen/pelvis with either CT or MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) should be ordered when further workup is required. A lesion that is 6 cm in size with irregular margins is suspicious for malignancy and warrants further diagnostic evaluation.

Hepatic lesions can be solid or cystic, and arise from benign, malignant, or infectious etiologies. Most patients with an incidental hepatic mass are asymptomatic, but patients with symptomatic lesions can present with fever, chills, and right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain. Physical examination may reveal abdominal distension, RUQ tenderness, a palpable liver edge (i.e., hepatomegaly), or scleral icterus and jaundice.

Patients with incidental hepatic lesions who have cirrhosis or risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g. alcoholism, chronic hepatitis B) should have further diagnostic workup regardless of the characteristics of the lesion on the initial CT. Additionally, patients with alarm features (e.g., weight loss, RUQ pain, prior malignancy that can metastasize to the liver) should have further imaging with multiphase contrast-enhanced imaging regardless of the initial CT findings.
 
    

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion < 1 cm with smooth margins  :
Incorrect: Typically, lesions < 1 cm in size with smooth margins are benign and can be followed yearly with history, physical, and imaging. These lesions do not require immediate diagnostic workup.  
❌ Lesion < 3 cm that is well-demarcated, homogenous, and hyperechoic  :
Incorrect: In patients with these CT findings and no history of cirrhosis or malignancy, hepatic hemangioma can typically be diagnosed without the need for further diagnostic imaging.  
✅ Lesion that is 6 cm with irregular margins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Small lesions showing no growth when compared to prior CT done one year ago :
Incorrect: Hepatic lesions that are stable or regress on subsequent CT are benign and do not require further workup.  
❌ Lesion < 1 cm with smooth borders and multiple subcentimeter gallstones in the gallbladder :
Incorrect: While this patient should be offered a surgery consultation for elective cholecystectomy. This lesion that is <1 cm with smooth borders is most likely benign and does not require further diagnostic workup at this time.

questions.text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of feeding intolerance for the past 3 days. His parents state that he has had projectile vomiting with non-bloody and non-bilious emesis immediately after feeding. Previously, his feeding schedule and tolerance have been normal. He has had three wet diapers in the last 24 hours. Rectal temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, blood pressure is 85/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examinations show no abnormalities. An olive-shaped mass is palpated in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following, if present, would be a known risk factor for the likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Second born child in the family birth order

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with projectile vomiting, feeding intolerance, and an olive-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant suggesting a diagnosis of pyloric stenosis. This patient is hemodynamically stable, though dehydrated with dry mucous membranes. The use of macrolide antibiotics is associated with increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis, particularly when these antibiotics are administered to infants younger than two weeks of age.
