Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) refers to a disorder of young infants caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus, which can progress to near-complete obstruction of the gastric outlet and forceful vomiting. IHPS usually develops in patients between three and five weeks of age and rarely occurs after 12 weeks. It is more common among boys than girls. The vomiting is nonbilious and forceful ("projectile") (or may become more forceful over time), with associated weight loss if symptoms progress. While an "olive-like" mass may be palpated in the epigastric region or right upper quadrant, more often patients do not have this finding, especially if the diagnosis is made early.

Several risk factors are associated with IHPS including maternal smoking during pregnancy and bottle feeding. There is also a genetic component to IHPS, as approximately 6% of siblings of an affected patient develop IHPS. Patients who are firstborn have a higher risk of IHPS than those born later in the birth order. IHPS can also be associated with several other conditions, including hyperbilirubinemia, esophageal atresia, malrotation, and hypoplastic frenulum, so careful history should be obtained to rule out associated diagnoses.    

Option Analysis

❌ Rotavirus vaccination:
Incorrect:  Rotavirus vaccination is typically associated with an expansion of Peyer’s patches within the terminal ileum, which can create a lead point for intussusception. Patients with intussusception typically exhibit periods of intense abdominal pain followed by “red currant jelly” stools.  
❌ Exclusively breastfeeding:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with pyloric stenosis. Bottle feeding, unlike breastfeeding, is associated with an increased risk for pyloric stenosis. One study showed that bottle feeding during the first four months of life was associated with a more than fourfold increase in the risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
✅ Macrolide antibiotic use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Second born child in the family birth order:
Incorrect: Being firstborn, not second born, has been associated with an increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
❌ Full-term at birth:
Incorrect: Preterm birth increases the risk of pyloric stenosis. Full-term birth generally confers an advantage due to the ability to fully develop organ systems before birth.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parent for evaluation of fever and abdominal pain for two days. Her parent states that two days ago, she began complaining of vague abdominal pain. Today the pain worsened and migrated to the lower right quadrant. She also began experiencing fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting. She had three episodes of watery diarrhea and has a decreased appetite. She recently arrived back from a family vacation to Mexico, but the rest of her family remains healthy. Approximately 18 months ago, she had a right ovarian torsion that required surgical management. Temperature is 38°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20 per minute, blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is uncomfortable and in pain. Abdominal exam is notable for tenderness over the right lower abdomen with rebound and guarding. Which of the following findings on ultrasound would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Enlarged right ovary with diminished or absent doppler flow
Spiral appearance of the duodenum and jejunum

questions.solution:
This eight-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and migratory right lower quadrant abdominal pain. She has evidence of an acute abdomen on exam with tenderness over McBurney’s point. Given these findings, acute appendicitis is the most likely diagnosis. Ultrasound is the diagnostic modality of choice for appendicitis in children given the lack of radiation. Ultrasound findings that support a diagnosis of appendicitis include a noncompressible tubular structure in the right lower quadrant, wall thickness greater than 2 mm, and diameter greater than 6 mm. These findings indicate a thickened and enlarged appendix.

Many conditions can cause acute abdomen in pediatric patients. The most likely causes differ based on age. In infants, intestinal malrotation and intussusception should be suspected. In older pediatric patients, gonadal torsion and appendicitis are more likely. Careful history and physical examination may not lead to a specific diagnosis and diagnostic imaging is typically necessary. 

In children, non-invasive and non-radiation-based imaging modalities are preferred. Ultrasound is typically the first-choice imaging modality. CT (Computed Tomography) imaging may be considered in some cases.    

Option Analysis

❌ Colonic inflammation with large, watery stool burden :
Incorrect: Patients with viral gastroenteritis or enterocolitis may have findings of intestinal/colonic inflammation or large watery stool burden on ultrasound. While this patient recently traveled to Mexico, none of her family members are sick and gastroenteritis would not typically present with acute abdomen. This patient with migratory abdominal pain and acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
❌ Enlarged right ovary with diminished or absent doppler flow :
Incorrect: These are classic ultrasound findings seen with ovarian torsion. This patient has a history of right ovarian torsion, and recurrent torsion is possible, but diarrhea and migratory abdominal pain are not usually seen with ovarian torsions. Additionally, recurrent torsion on the same side as the repair would be unlikely. This patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
✅ Thickened and enlarged appendix  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Spiral appearance of the duodenum and jejunum :
Incorrect: These findings are known as the “corkscrew” sign and can be seen with intestinal malrotation. Patients with intestinal malrotation typically present in the first two years of life with bright red blood per rectum and bilious vomiting. This 8-year-old patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
❌ Target sign :
Incorrect: A target sign on ultrasound is often associated with intussusception, which typically presents in patients between the ages of 6 and 36 months. Patients typically present with lethargy, irritability, colicky abdominal pain, and “red currant jelly.” stool. This 8-year-old patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with flank pain. He says he developed malaise three days ago. Then two days ago, he noticed a burning sensation along his left flank, extending from his mid-back to under his armpit. And then he developed a rash. He has not had any recent trauma and has not traveled anywhere in the past year. He has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. He is noticeably distressed and wearing loose-fitting clothing because any contact with his left flank is painful. Which of the following physical examination findings would be most consistent with the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe burning pain in a dermatomal distribution (acute neuritis) followed by development of a rash. These symptoms were preceded by malaise. The most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster infection. The rash associated with herpes zoster is a vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.       

Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, results from the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV) that has gained access to the sensory ganglia. Herpes zoster is characterized by a painful and unilateral vesicular eruption, which usually occurs in a single or two contiguous dermatomes. Most patients describe the pain as a deep burning, throbbing, or stabbing sensation, and the pain typically precedes the development of the rash. Patients may also have a prodrome of headache, fever, or malaise.        

Option Analysis

❌ Crepitus :
Incorrect: Crepitus is most often associated with necrotizing infections like fasciitis. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
❌ Fluctuance :
Incorrect: Fluctuance is a tense area of skin with a “wave-like” or “boggy” feeling upon palpation and is present when there is an accumulation of fluid or pus in the underlying tissue. This is commonly associated with abscesses. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
✅ Vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Erythematous Rash with honey-colored crust :
Incorrect: This examination finding is usually associated with impetigo, which is a superficial soft tissue infection found most often in children caused by Group A Streptococcus or Staphylococcus Aureus. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a maculopapular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
❌ Sharply demarcated erythema   :
Incorrect: Sharply demarcated erythema is associated with erysipelas. Erysipelas is a non-purulent superficial soft tissue infection associated with Group A Streptococcus. Patients typically have erythema that is not in a dermatomal distribution. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a maculopapular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office after recent blood work which revealed a microcytic anemic (hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL). She has a past medical history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and atrial fibrillation and takes omeprazole, metoprolol, and apixaban. She has mild dyspnea with activity and occasional dysphagia with solids. She also has postprandial mid-epigastric pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a soft nontender abdomen without palpable masses. Chest x-ray shows a retrocardiac air-fluid level. Upper endoscopy reveals a foreshortened esophagus with the entire stomach herniated through the hiatus. A Cameron ulcer is seen at the level of the diaphragm. Colonoscopy shows no masses or polyps. Which of the following types of paraesophageal/hiatal hernia does this patient have?
questions.solution:
This 71-year-old woman presents with microcytic anemia, dyspnea, dysphagia with solid food, and post-prandial mid-epigastric pain. Chest X-ray shows a retrocardiac air-fluid level which is concerning for a paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. Given that this patient has microcytic anemia, upper and lower endoscopies are performed. Upper endoscopy showed a Cameron ulcer, the likely source of bleeding, and a foreshortened esophagus with herniation of the entire stomach, consistent with a type III hernia. A type III paraesophageal/hiatal hernia occurs when there is migration above the diaphragm of the GEJ and a portion of the stomach through the hiatus.        

Paraesophageal hernias can be diagnosed with upper endoscopy; however, barium swallow is the most sensitive diagnostic test. Barium swallow can determine the anatomy and size of the hernia, orientation of the stomach, and location of the GEJ. In patients with a paraesophageal /hernia, a retroflexed view on upper endoscopy will show a portion of the stomach herniating upward through the diaphragm adjacent to the endoscope.        

Esophageal manometry should be performed in patients diagnosed with paraesophageal/hiatal hernias for whom a wrapping of the stomach (fundoplication) will be performed. It measures the esophageal pressure and coordination at rest and with swallowing. The presence or absence of dysmotility is used to determine the type of fundoplication needed for operative repair.    



Option Analysis

❌ Type I  :
Incorrect: A type I paraesophageal/hiatal hernia or sliding hernia occurs when the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) migrates superiorly above the diaphragm.  
❌ Type II  :
Incorrect: A type II paraesophageal/hiatal hernia occurs when part of the gastric fundus has herniated through the hiatus with a normally located gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).  This patient has a foreshortened esophagus indicating that the GEJ has migrated upward, as well as indicating a type III hernia.  
✅ Type III  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type IV :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy shows herniation of the stomach and GEJ junction, but no other organs have herniated through the hiatus. This is consistent with Type III paraesophageal /hiatal hernia and not a type IV hernia. 
❌ Type V:
Incorrect: There are only 4 types of paraesophageal/hiatal hernias, and this patient has a type III hernia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with diarrhea. He has a history of Crohn disease, for which he underwent small bowel resection 3 weeks ago due to complications from strictures. He is unsure as to the extent of the resection, but states, “It was a lot.” Since his discharge, he has lost 10 pounds and has experienced 3-5 episodes of diarrhea each day. This past week, he began feeling lethargic. He has not had any urine output in the past 36 hours, which prompted him to present for evaluation. Vitals are notable for a temperature of 37 ℃ (98.6℉), heart rate of 112 /min, blood pressure of 85/50 mm Hg, and respiratory rate of 20 /min. Physical examination is notable for dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Labs are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and admission to the hospital for monitoring

questions.solution:
Given this patient’s history of extensive bowel surgery and current clinical presentation, he likely has short bowel syndrome. He is tachycardic and hypotensive, indicating hemodynamic instability, and he has signs of volume depletion (e.g., reduced urine output, dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor). Thus, the best next step in management is to obtain IV access and provide crystalloid fluid resuscitation.       

Short bowel syndrome is characterized by insufficient length or function of the small intestines, resulting in malabsorption of water and electrolytes. The physiologic course of short bowel syndrome is characterized by two phases, the acute and adaptation phases. This patient is in the acute phase, which starts immediately after resection and lasts 3-4 weeks.        

The first step in management is to determine the stability of the patient. The predominant goals of management are to stabilize large fluid and electrolyte losses and maintain fluid and acid/base balance. Once that is achieved, acid suppression can be provided, followed by a thorough nutrition assessment. Typically, a combination of enteral and parenteral nutrition is recommended. Establishing contact with the patient’s operating surgeon is also imperative during the patient’s hospital course.    

Option Analysis

❌ Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and admission to the hospital for monitoring :
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, secondary to volume depletion from short bowel syndrome. Prior to initiating TPN, this patient should have a full assessment and be stabilized with intravenous fluid resuscitation.  
❌ Enteral access and nutrition  :
Incorrect: Enteral access is a vital component of managing the acute phase of short bowel syndrome. A combination of both enteral and parenteral nutrition is usually required to re-establish adequate nutrition. However, this patient is unstable and first requires resuscitation. 
✅ Intravenous (IV) access and crystalloid resuscitation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consultation with the operating surgeon :
Incorrect: The operating surgeon should be contacted regarding the care of their patient, but fluid resuscitation is the priority at this time.  
❌ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy :
Incorrect: A PPI can be used in the acute phase of short bowel syndrome to suppress gastric hypersecretion and reduce fluid losses. However, prior to this, the patient needs to be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with diarrhea. She has a history of Crohn disease complicated by strictures, for which she underwent an extensive small bowel resection two weeks ago. Since her discharge, she has experienced persistent diarrhea, which has recently increased in volume. Today, she began feeling weak, prompting her visit to the ED. On review of systems, she reports no fevers or chills, but she has lost 7 lb. in the past two weeks. She has not had any other surgeries. Temperature is 37 ℃ (98.6 ℉), heart rate is 84 /min, blood pressure is 110/76, and respiratory rate is 20 /min. On examination, she appears distressed, and her abdomen is mildly distended with recent surgical scars and a stoma without signs of infection. A rectal exam reveals no blood or masses. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following lab values would be consistent with the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given this patient’s presentation of diarrhea following recent, extensive bowel resection, she is at substantial risk of developing short bowel syndrome. The primary clinical concern in short bowel syndrome is significant malabsorption due to the reduced absorptive surface area of the intestine. An elevated fecal fat level would indicate malabsorption of fat and would be consistent with this syndrome.       

Initial evaluation of patients with likely short bowel syndrome aims to confirm malabsorption, assess its breadth (selective or global), and identify the underlying cause. The etiology of this patient’s short bowel syndrome can be elicited from history, but it should be confirmed by reviewing the operative reports to determine the length of the small bowel resected. If this information is unavailable, high-resolution computed tomography (CT) imaging can provide a detailed assessment of the patient’s anatomy. Laboratory tests might reveal microcytic anemia from iron deficiency or macrocytic anemia due to folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. There are also often electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia. Additionally, fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) will likely be low. Fecal fat analysis is a practical initial test for assessing fat malabsorption. It is cost-effective and simple for both patients and laboratories to perform. In cases like this, where extensive bowel resection has occurred, an elevated fecal fat count is indicative of significant fat malabsorption, consistent with the diagnosis of short bowel syndrome.   

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated serum prealbumin :
Incorrect: Prealbumin is a measure of a patient’s nutritional status over the last several days. This patient likely has short bowel syndrome and would be expected to have poor nutritional status with a low prealbumin.  
❌ Normal serum vitamin D :
Incorrect: Patients with short bowel syndrome have malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. These include vitamins A, D, E, and K. A low vitamin D level would be expected in this case. 
✅ Elevated fecal fat :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated serum potassium :
Incorrect: Patients with malabsorption usually experience hypokalemia due to the loss of potassium-rich fluid from the colon. 
❌ Elevated serum phosphate :
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia, rather than hyperphosphatemia, is expected in patients with malabsorption syndromes, such as short bowel syndrome.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is referred to the cardiology clinic after moderate aortic stenosis is diagnosed by transthoracic echocardiogram. She can walk up one flight of stairs before needing to stop to catch her breath. She reports no chest discomfort and has never lost consciousness. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medication includes empagliflozin, lisinopril, and metformin. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 127/83 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing without jugular venous distention. There is no peripheral edema bilaterally. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following is likely to be heard on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Fixed splitting of S1 and S2

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the cardiology clinic for evaluation of moderate aortic stenosis. As the left ventricle works harder to push against a narrowed aortic orifice, left ventricular hypertrophy may develop, and can lead to ventricular failure. Consequently, an S4 heart sound may be heard on cardiac auscultation, indicating the atrium is forcefully pushing blood into a stiffened or hypertrophied ventricle.   

Aortic stenosis refers to the narrowing of the aortic valve, which impedes blood flow from the left ventricle into the aorta. The increased resistance causes the left ventricle to hypertrophy, potentially leading to ventricular dysfunction and a reduced ejection fraction. While patients with mild aortic stenosis are often asymptomatic, symptoms may develop in patients like this one with moderate aortic stenosis as the valve becomes narrower, including dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance. Severe cases can present with pronounced dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope.    

On physical examination, patients with aortic stenosis may have no abnormal findings until the disease reaches a moderate or severe stage. A slow rising carotid pulse and a loud mid-to-late peaking systolic murmur, best heard in the 2nd right intercostal space, are characteristic findings. An S4 sound (“atrial gallop”) can also be heard as the left ventricle becomes increasingly hypertrophic and stiff. If heart failure develops due to severe aortic stenosis, classic heart failure findings such as pulmonary crackles may be present.   

Option Analysis

✅ S4 heart sound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fixed splitting of S1 and S2:
Incorrect: Persistent splitting of heart sounds is more likely to be heard in patients with an atrial septal defect. It is not usually associated with aortic stenosis. 
❌ S3 heart sound:
Incorrect: An S3 heart sound (“gallop”) occurs due to rapid filling of the ventricles during ventricular diastole and is associated with heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, and aortic regurgitation. It is less commonly associated with aortic stenosis, unless the stenosis is accompanied by heart failure due to significant ventricular systolic dysfunction, which is not evident in this patient.  
❌ Midsystolic click:
Incorrect: A midsystolic click is typically heard with prolapse of the mitral valve and is not associated with aortic stenosis. 
❌ Friction rub:
Incorrect: A friction rub occurs with pericarditis due to inflammation between the two layers of the pericardium and is not associated with aortic stenosis.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the cardiology clinic for evaluation of aortic stenosis diagnosed by transthoracic echocardiogram. The patient experiences intermittent chest pain, although cardiac catheterization last year showed no significant coronary artery stenosis. He can only walk about 20 feet before needing to stop to catch his breath. He has experienced spontaneous loss of consciousness twice in the past six months. The patient has no other significant past medical history, and he is currently taking metoprolol. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud systolic murmur in the second right intercostal space and an S4 heart sound. Mild non-pitting bipedal edema is present bilaterally. Transthoracic echocardiogram shows an aortic valve area of 0.8 cm2, a transvalvular velocity of 4.5 m/s, and a mean pressure gradient of 45 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the cardiology clinic for evaluation of aortic stenosis. This patient’s dyspnea, chest pain (notably in the absence of coronary artery obstruction), and syncope all indicate severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis. This is confirmed by the echocardiogram findings (aortic valve area <1 cm2, transvalvular velocity >4 m/s, and mean pressure gradient >40 mmHg).    

Patients with mild aortic stenosis are often asymptomatic, as are many patients with moderate aortic stenosis. Patients with severe aortic stenosis may develop dyspnea and chest pain due to the reduced ejection fraction. In addition, syncope may result either due to mechanical outflow tract obstruction or arrhythmias. An echocardiogram (generally transthoracic) is used to evaluate the aortic valve area, as well as transvalvular velocity and mean pressure gradient across the aortic valve to determine if the aortic stenosis is mild, moderate, or severe.   

Option Analysis

✅ Severe aortic stenosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Moderate aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Patients with moderate aortic stenosis are often asymptomatic though they can have symptoms. This patient exhibits severe symptoms and has a significantly reduced aortic valve area (<1.0 cm2), indicating severe aortic stenosis. 
❌ Mild aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Patients with mild aortic stenosis are usually asymptomatic. This patient’s severe symptoms and significantly reduced aortic valve area (<1.0 cm2) indicate severe aortic stenosis. 
❌ Low-flow, low-gradient aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: This condition is characterized by a lower-than- expected valvular gradient (low gradient) due to a depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (low flow). This vignette does not provide information on the ejection fraction or stroke volume index, so determination of the flow (“low” or “normal”) cannot be made, but the significantly reduced aortic valve area (<1.0 cm2), indicates severe aortic stenosis. 
❌ Normal-flow, low-gradient aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: This condition involves a less severe than expected valvular gradient (low gradient) with a normal left ventricular ejection fraction (normal flow). This vignette does not provide information on the ejection fraction or stroke volume index, so determination of the flow (“low” or “normal”) cannot be made., but the significantly reduced aortic valve area (<1.0 cm2), indicates this severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation after being involved in a motorcycle accident. EMS reports the patient hit a curb at high speed and flew over the handlebars. The patient was wearing a helmet, and a cervical collar was placed in the field. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 36°C (96.5°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 177/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient appears anxious but can state his name and speak in clear full sentences. The patient states he has pelvic discomfort. He is moving all extremities spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally. There are breath sounds bilaterally and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. GCS is 14 with one point subtracted due to mild confusion. IV access is established. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Remove all clothing from the patient
Roll the patient and examine the back
Administer one unit of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trauma in the setting of a motorcycle accident. The initial trauma screening examination, or the primary survey has been started. The patient has had all major components of the exam performed thus far, except for exposure. Exposure involves removing all the patient's clothing to expose the skin and evaluate for injuries.

Trauma is one of the major causes of mortality and morbidity worldwide, and a standardized approach to trauma, known as the “trauma protocol” allows providers to systematically assess and quickly identify potentially life-threatening injuries, while simultaneously initiating resuscitation. The trauma protocol is composed of primary, secondary, and tertiary surveys, performed in that order.

The goal is to first identify life-threatening injuries and stabilize the patient, which is best accomplished by performing a careful primary survey. This examination involves 5 components: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure. The primary survey must be completed in sequential order, and the patient should receive stabilizing measures at each step, if necessary (e.g., if the patient arrives obtunded an airway should be secured before moving on to breathing assessment), before moving on to the next step.

Option Analysis

✅ Remove all clothing from the patient:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform an E-FAST examination:
Incorrect: An E-FAST examination (focused assessment sonography for trauma) can be part of the secondary survey. This patient has not yet received a comprehensive primary survey as he has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Roll the patient and examine the back:
Incorrect: Examining the back for injuries (step-offs, deformities, rectal tone) is not performed until the primary survey is complete. This patient has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Order Pelvic x-ray:
Incorrect: A pelvic x-ray is not indicated until after the patient has received a complete primary survey. This patient has not undergone proper exposure to assess for traumatic injuries.
❌ Administer one unit of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient does not exhibit findings of significant bleeding or hemodynamic instability on the primary survey thus far. Administration of packed red blood cells is not clinically indicated. And the patient should have proper exposure first.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Upon arrival, the patient appears anxious but speaks in full, clear sentences. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 150/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. There are bilateral breath sounds and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15 and is freely moving all extremities. Pupils are 2-3 mm, equal round, and reactive bilaterally. The patient is exposed, and warm blankets are applied.  IV access is established. The secondary survey reveals four gunshot wounds: one entry wound lateral to the umbilicus on the left, one entry wound inferior to the left clavicle, and corresponding exit wounds over the left flank and medial scapula on the left. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST exam
Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of penetrating trauma and is found to have evidence of two gunshot wounds. Primary survey is completed. as part of the secondary survey. Chest x-ray, pelvis x-ray, and FAST exam should be performed next.

To assess for retained bullet fragments, pneumothorax, and free fluid before proceeding to CT imaging. The presence of any of these findings may change management (e.g., chest tube placement, pericardiocentesis, expeditious transport to the operating room).

The secondary survey should include a detailed history, a thorough but efficient physical examination, and targeted diagnostic tests. Typically blood work will include type and screen, complete blood count (CBC), and complete metabolic profile (CMP). Additional tests can include a coagulation profile, EtOH level, pregnancy test in biologically female patients, and urine toxicology screen. Next, patients should have an ultrasound examination called the FAST exam to assess for free fluid in the pericardium, hepatorenal space on the right, splenorenal space on the left, and pelvis. Patients should also have a chest x-ray and/or pelvis x-ray performed depending on the mechanism of injury. Finally, patients should have CT imaging performed based on the mechanism of injury and injury pattern

Option Analysis

✅ Chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST exam:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis should be performed; however, this patient should first undergo immediate evaluation with a chest X-ray, pelvis X-ray, and FAST examination to rule out pneumothorax, hemothorax, or free intraperitoneal fluid which would require urgent interventions (e.g., chest tube placement, pericardiocentesis) before proceeding to CT.  
❌ Diagnostic peritoneal lavage:
Incorrect: A diagnostic peritoneal lavage is an uncommonly performed procedure used to assess for intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is not indicated as part of a standard trauma workup.  
❌ EKG and troponin:
Incorrect: An electrocardiogram should be obtained for all trauma patients presenting with blunt cardiac injury. This patient has gunshot wounds and therefore Chest x-ray, pelvis x-ray, and FAST exam should be performed next.
❌ Bedside thoracotomy:
Incorrect: A bedside thoracotomy is reserved for patients with penetrating cardiac trauma, cardiac tamponade on FAST, or pulseless individuals who received CPR within 15 minutes of traumatic thoracic injury. This patient does not indicate this highly invasive procedure.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds. According to the patient's friend, he has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Upon arrival, the patient appears pale and confused. Temperature is 36°C (96.5°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 81/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient has bilateral breath sounds and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Capillary refill is 4-5 seconds. The patient has a GCS of 9. Pupils are 2-3 mm, equal round, and reactive bilaterally. The patient is exposed, and warm blankets are applied. IV access is established, and supplemental oxygen is applied. O-negative blood is administered. The secondary survey reveals a single gunshot wound just inferior to the sternum. A chest x-ray and pelvic x-ray are obtained and unremarkable. A FAST examination is performed showing free fluid. Blood work is obtained and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with the following penetrating trauma and has evidence of a gunshot wound to the upper abdomen. This patient has evidence of hemodynamic instability (i.e., hypotension, delayed capillary refill) and concern for hemorrhagic shock. Additionally, free fluid is identified on FAST examination. He should be immediately transfer red to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy and hemorrhage control.  

Once patients are stabilized and initial treatments are performed (i.e., laparotomy in this case), all trauma patients should receive a tertiary survey. A tertiary survey includes re-assessment of the patient’s history and physical exam within 24 hours of presentation and a review of lab tests and imaging. Performing a repeat trаսma survey (or tertiary survey) on all trauma patients decreases the frequency of missed iոϳսries.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient presents with hemodynamic instability and free fluid identified on FAST examination. He should be transferred to the operating room for immediate laparotomy
❌ Chest tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of free fluid on FAST examination. There is no evidence of pneumothorax. Therefore, a chest tube is not indicated.
❌ Pelvic binder :
Incorrect: This patient has a stable pelvis. Application of a pelvic binder is indicated for patients with evidence of pelvic instability and concern for exsanguination from pelvic vasculature.
❌ Bedside thoracotomy:
Incorrect: A bedside thoracotomy is a high-risk procedure reserved for patients with penetrating cardiac trauma, cardiac tamponade identified on FAST, or pulseless individuals who have received CPR for less than 15 minutes following traumatic thoracic injury. This patient does not meet these criteria.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents with his parents to the pediatrician for evaluation of dark-colored stools for the past two weeks. The patient has not had constipation, diarrhea, abdominal pain, pain with defecation or mucous in stools. Family history is notable for the biological father who has vascular malformations. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/62 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On examination, the child appears pale with several dilated blood vessels visible on the cheeks bilaterally. Abdominal examination is normal. No hemorrhoids are visible on rectal examination. Fecal occult blood test is positive, and the rest of the laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is likely associated with this patient’s underlying condition? 

 Laboratory value      Results      
 Hemoglobin       9 gm/dL     
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)      72 fL     
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH)      23 pg     
 Red cell distribution width (RDW)      51 fL     
 Platelets       170,000 /μL     
 Prothrombin time (PT)      11     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)      28
questions.solution:
The patient presents with melena and is found to have a family history of vascular malformations, telangiectasias on exam, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is the most likely diagnosis. The common complications of HHT include еpiѕtахis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and iron deficiency anemia.        

Several types of vascular malformations can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding in pediatric patients, including hemangiomas, blue rubber bleb nevus syndrome, gastric antral ectasia, and hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.       

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) (also called Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome) refers to an autosomal dominant vascular disorder associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasia, epistaxis, GI bleeding, and arteriovenous malformations. Arteriovenous malformations may affect many parts of the body. Patients may present with melena and hematemesis. GI bleeding in HHT typically causes iron deficiency anemia as seen in this patient.    

Option Analysis

❌ Eczema  :
Incorrect: Eczema may be seen in infants with cow milk protein allergy, which can present with vomiting, abdominal pain, blood and mucous in stool, and diarrhea. This patient most likely has hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia associated with epistaxis.  
✅ Epistaxis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Jaundice  :
Incorrect: Jaundice may be seen in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding from liver disease. The findings of melena, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, family history, and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, which is associated with epistaxis.  
❌ Petechiae  :
Incorrect: Petechiae can be seen in patients with Henoch-Schönlein purpura, which presents purpuric rash, abdominal pain, and hematuria. The findings of melena and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, associated with epistaxis.  
❌ Pyoderma gangrenosum  :
Incorrect: Pyoderma gangrenosum may be seen in patients with Crohn disease, which presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, blood and mucous in stool, and diarrhea. The findings of melena and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, associated with epistaxis.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the primary care clinic with nausea and abdominal pain for one month. The pain localizes to the epigastrium and improves with eating and drinking milk. He has had two episodes of coffee ground emesis and one episode of black stool in the past 24 hours. The patient has not had diarrhea, mucous in stools, weight loss, or fever. Parents report he frequently takes ibuprofen for pain related to sports injuries. Family and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37° C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/61 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness, but no rigidity, rebound, or guarding. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis with mucosal lesions and a punched-out, smooth ulcer base. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Results      
 Hemoglobin       10.5 gm/dL     
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)      70 fL     
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH)      22 pg     
 Platelets       230,000 /μL     
 Prothrombin time (PT)      11     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)      28
questions.solution:
This patient presents with epigastric pain, coffee ground emesis and melena and is found to have iron deficiency anemia. Endoscopy shows findings consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Peptic ulcer disease is commonly caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which this patient has been taking. Treatment involves acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).   

PUD can be caused by Helicobacter pylori, NSAIDs, stressors like trauma or burns, and binge-drinking in adolescents. Complications of PUD include upper gastrointestinal bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, and perforation. Patients usually report retrosternal chest or epigastric pain and dyspepsia that may improve after eating, milk consumption, or antacids. Physical exam may be normal but may reveal epigastric tenderness. Upper endoscopy may show erythema, erosions, or subepithelial hemorrhage of the gastric mucosa with ulceration. In addition to addressing the underlying cause (e.g., stopping NSAIDs, antibiotics for H. pylori), treatment of peptic ulcer disease involves acid suppression using proton pump inhibitors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Endoscopic band ligation :
Incorrect: Endoscopic band ligation is used to treat acutely bleeding esophageal varices. This patient has no history of liver disease and is stable. The findings on endoscopy are consistent with peptic ulcer disease for which proton pump inhibitors are the most appropriate treatment. 
❌ Intravenous octreotide infusion  :
Incorrect: Octreotide is used to treat gastrointestinal bleeding from esophageal varices. However, the findings on this patient’s endoscopy are consistent with peptic ulcer disease. 
❌ Observation for one month :
Incorrect: This patient presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia likely secondary to peptic ulcer disease from ibuprofen use. Treatment with proton pump inhibitors should be initiated. 
✅ Oral proton pump inhibitors :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Packed red blood cell transfusion :
Incorrect: Packed red blood cell transfusion is indicated in patients with acute gastrointestinal bleeding when they are hemodynamically unstable or have severe anemia. This patient is clinically stable with mildly decreased hemoglobin, and findings consistent with peptic ulcer disease, for which proton pump inhibitors should be started.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The patient was riding his motorcycle when he struck a light pole, landing directly on his back. The patient was helmeted and did not lose consciousness. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. A cervical collar was applied in the field. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 92/64 mmHg, heart rate is 52 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On primary survey, the patient is yelling and endorsing mid-back pain. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and there is no evidence of obvious bleeding. The patient is not able to move his lower extremities bilaterally. The secondary survey reveals point tenderness and a bony-step off at the T10 level and scattered abrasions over the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in an unstable condition after a motor vehicle accident with evidence of neurogenic shock (i.e., focal deficits, autonomic instability). He is also found to have point tenderness and a step-off at the T10 level. These findings are consistent with a spinal fracture and associated spinal cord injury, requiring emergency neurosurgical consultation for decompression surgery.

Spinal fractures refer to breakage of the spinal vertebrae in the cervical, thoracic, or lumbar spinal columns which can occur from traumatic injuries such as blunt trauma (e.g. falls or sports injuries) or rapid deceleration from motor vehicle collisions. Spinal fractures can also be pathologic from underlying conditions like osteoporosis or metastatic cancer. Regardless of the cause, timely diagnosis and treatment are important for preventing spinal cord injury and neurologic impairment.

The acute management of a spinal fracture should follow the standard approach for all trauma patients, including a primary survey that includes ABCDE assessment (airway, breathing, circulation, disability, and exposure). Specific acute management strategies should include cervical spine stabilization, as well as spine immobilization by securing the patient in a supine position on the spine board. Patients should have a detailed neurologic examination performed, specifically assessing for focal weakness, paresthesia/numbness, and respiratory monitoring (specifically for higher level C-spine fractures due to phrenic nerve involvement), and the patient’s Glasgow coma scale (GCS) should be calculated.

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent neurosurgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous dexamethasone:
Incorrect: Steroids are often indicated in the management of patients with acute spinal cord injury (e.g., cauda equina syndrome). However, while steroids should be considered as a management strategy, an emergent neurosurgical consultation should be called first.
❌ Thoracic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: While an MRI is useful for detailed spinal cord imaging, it should not delay the emergent neurosurgical consultation in a patient presenting with an acute spinal cord injury.
❌ Rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: This patient does not show signs of respiratory compromise or airway obstruction; therefore, intubation is not indicated at this time.
❌ Thoracic brace:
Incorrect: Bracing is often indicated for non-operative vertebral body compression fractures. This patient has evidence of neurogenic shock and requires emergency operative decompression.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall. The patient was walking his dog when he tripped and fell directly on his back. He did not hit his head. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and multiple myeloma. He takes amlodipine and rivaroxaban daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 92/64 mmHg, heart rate is 52 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On primary survey, the patient appears uncomfortable and has severe lower back pain. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and there is no evidence of obvious bleeding. The patient can move both lower extremities; however, he cannot lift his legs off the bed. Sensation in the perinium is diminished. The secondary survey reveals point tenderness at the L4-L5 level. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of multiple myeloma presents for evaluation of low back pain after a fall from standing height. Physical examination reveals saddle anesthesia, lumbar tenderness, and the inability to lift both legs. Together, these findings are concerning for cauda equina syndrome, likely secondary to a pathologic fracture from lytic myeloma lesions in the spine. In addition to saddle anesthesia and bilateral lower extremity weakness, the third component of the cauda equina triad is bowel or bladder dysfunction – urinary retention is often seen in patients with cauda equina syndrome due to involvement of the S2-4 spinal nerve roots.  

Following the primary survey, all patients with suspected spinal fractures should undergo a secondary survey, which includes a careful history and physical examination. The history should include past medical/surgical history as well as allergies and medications. Patients should be carefully screened for conditions that predispose them to pathologic fractures (e.g., malignancy, osteoporosis). In addition, the mechanism of injury should be clarified (e.g., fall, motor vehicle accident). Careful examination should include skin examination of the back, direct palpation of the spine, and testing strength, sensation, and reflexes. Physical examination may reveal posterior midline tenderness, neck spasms, bony step offs, or limited range of motion. Neurologic deficits that may be seen with spinal fractures, including quadriplegia or paraplegia, loss of rectal tone, or urinary retention.

Patients with cauda equina syndrome typically present with bilateral leg weakness in multiple root distributions (L3-S1). They may have associated findings of perineal sensory symptoms and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction due to involvement of the S2-4 spinal nerve roots.   

Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Unilateral upper extremity numbness:
Incorrect: Unilateral upper extremity numbness may occur in conditions like herniated discs or nerve root compression at the level of the cervical or thoracic spine. However, this patient has findings consistent with cauda equina syndrome, which presents with the triad of bilateral lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel or bladder dysfunction (e.g. urinary retention).
❌ Absent ankle reflexes:
Incorrect: Absent ankle reflexes are associated with peripheral neuropathies or advanced age, but they are nonspecific and do not indicate cauda equina syndrome, which instead presents with the triad of bilateral lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel or bladder dysfunction (e.g. urinary retention).
❌ Lumbar step off:
Incorrect: A lumbar step off, while highly suggestive of a spinal fracture, is not necessarily associated with cauda equina syndrome. The classic triad of cauda equina syndrome is bilateral lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel or bladder dysfunction (e.g. urinary retention).
❌ Increased rectal tone:
Incorrect: While patients with cauda equina syndrome classically have bowel and/or bladder dysfunction, they are typically found to have decreased or absent rectal tone due to sacral nerve root dysfunction. In contrast, a finding of increased rectal tone suggests an alternative diagnosis, such as conditions causing hypertonia (e.g. upper motor neuron lesions).

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after experiencing a fall. The patient was seated in a chair and fell when she was getting up. She fell directly onto her back and landed on the tile floor. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and osteoporosis. She takes lisinopril daily. Due to multiple side effects, she has not consistently taken medication to treat the osteoporosis. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 188/64 mmHg, heart rate is 72 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On primary survey, the patient endorses moderate mid-back pain. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and there is no evidence of obvious bleeding. The patient has no neurologic deficits. Examination of the back reveals mild point tenderness at the T8 level without step off deformity. The lower extremities have normal strength, reflexes, and sensation bilaterally. The patient can ambulate without significant pain. Computed tomography (CT) imaging is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Spinal fracture with unstable ligamentous injury

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of osteoporosis presents for evaluation of mid back pain after a fall from seated height. The patient is neurologically intact, with stable vital signs, no neurologic deficits, and mild point tenderness at one vertebral level (T8). She most likely has an isolated compression fracture involving only one vertebral column. Vertebral compression fractures secondary to osteoporosis typically involve only the front of the vertebrae and are therefore considered stable fractures.

Spinal fractures are breakages of the spinal vertebrae in the cervical, thoracic, or lumbar spinal columns; they can occur from traumatic injuries such as blunt trauma (e.g., falls or sports injuries) or rapid deceleration from motor vehicle collisions. Spinal fractures can also be associated with an underlying pathology; for example, patients with underlying osteoporosis can have compression fractures from minor falls, and patients with metastatic cancer may have fractures at points of metastasis.

Following the primary survey, all patients with suspected spinal fractures should undergo a secondary survey, which includes a careful history and physical examination. Standard trauma laboratory studies be obtained (i.e., complete blood count (CBC), basic metabolic panel (BMP), type and screen, and coagulation studies). Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the spine at the suspected level of injury should also be performed. CT imaging helps differentiate isolated fractures from multi-level or ligamentous injuries, which have different managements and prognoses. Injury patterns can then be better characterized as isolated fractures vs. multi-level fractures vs. ligamentous injury. In general, patients with isolated fractures of the spine present without significant neurologic deficits, bony deformities, or significant pain/discomfort. In contrast, patients with multi-level fractures or ligamentous injuries are more likely to have spinal cord injuries; therefore, they typically present with debilitating pain, bony deformities, or focal neurologic deficits.

Option Analysis

✅ Compression fracture at T8:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Multilevel spinal fractures:
Incorrect: When spinal fractures involve 2 or more spinal columns, it is considered an unstable fracture pattern with an elevated risk of spinal cord injury. Such injuries typically present with severe pain, bony deformity, difficulty with ambulating, and focal neurologic deficits may be seen, none of which are present in this patient.
❌ Burst fracture at T8:
Incorrect: Burst fractures are high-energy traumatic vertebral fractures leading to bone fragments being scattered into the spinal canal with compression of neural elements and resultant neurological deficits. This patient is more likely to have a pathological compression fracture secondary to osteoporosis.
❌ Bony fragments in the spinal cord:
Incorrect: Fragments in the spinal cord are typically seen with burst fractures and can lead to spinal cord injury. This patient has a normal neurologic examination and only mild tenderness to palpation. Therefore, given the underlying osteoporosis, this patient most likely has a compression fracture.
❌ Spinal fracture with unstable ligamentous injury:
Incorrect: When spinal fractures involve 2 or more spinal columns, they are considered unstable fractures that pose an increased risk of spinal cord injury. Definitive ligamentous injuries cannot be diagnosed with CT imaging alone but can be suggested when there are fractures involving multiple spinal columns. This patient with osteoporosis who has no neurologic deficits most likely has a compression fracture of T8.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after experiencing a fall. The patient slipped while walking and fell directly onto her back, hitting the hard-wood floor. The patient has low back pain that worsens with movement, and she has trouble walking secondary to the pain. She has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes, and she takes lisinopril and metformin daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 157/64 mmHg, heart rate is 82 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. The patient endorses lower back pain. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and there is no evidence of obvious bleeding. The neurological exam is within normal limits. Examination of the back reveals point tenderness at the L4 level. The patient is unable to ambulate due to pain. Computed tomography (CT) of the lumbar spine is obtained, which demonstrates a compression deformity of the L4 vertebral body. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Admit for observation and pain control
Discharge with outpatient spine follow up
Transfer to the operating room for decompressive surgery
Admit to the surgical intensive care unit (SICU) for frequent neurologic checks
Transfer to the operating room for kyphoplasty

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of low back pain after a fall from standing height. On physical examination, the patient is neurologically intact, in no significant distress, with point tenderness at one vertebral level, suggesting an isolated compression fracture. This diagnosis is subsequently confirmed via CT imaging of the lumbar spine. Management of isolated compression fractures includes observation and medication for pain control. Management may also include bracing, neurologic consultation, and initiation of physical/occupational therapy.

Following the primary survey, all patients with suspected stable spinal fractures should undergo a secondary survey, which includes a careful history and physical examination. Standard trauma laboratory evaluation (i.e., complete blood count (CBC), basic metabolic panel (BMP), type and screen, and coagulation studies) and CT imaging of the spine at the suspected level of injury should also be performed. CT imaging helps differentiate isolated fractures from multi-level or ligamentous injuries, which have different management strategies and prognoses.

In general, patients with isolated spinal fractures can be managed conservatively, with pain management, bracing, and physical/occupational therapy. In contrast, patients with evidence of multiple fractures, ligamentous injury, or spinal cord injury should have prompt neurosurgical consultation, strict spinal precautions, frequent neurologic examinations, as well as continuous vital sign monitoring with avoidance of hypotension. These patients are typically admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU). Like other trauma patients, all patients with spinal fractures should undergo a detailed tertiary examination to assess for missed injuries not noted on primary or secondary surveys.

Option Analysis

✅ Admit for observation and pain control:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Discharge with outpatient spine follow up:
Incorrect: This patient has significant pain limiting her ability to ambulate due to a spinal fracture. Admission for observation, neurosurgical consultation, and pain management is the most appropriate management.
❌ Transfer to the operating room for decompressive surgery:
Incorrect: This patient has a stable compression fracture without evidence of neurological impairment or spinal cord compression. Decompressive surgery is reserved for patients with unstable fractures or those showing signs of spinal cord compression, such as patients with neurological deficits.
❌ Admit to the surgical intensive care unit (SICU) for frequent neurologic checks:
Incorrect: This patient has a stable spine fracture with no signs of spinal cord involvement. SICU admission and frequent neurologic checks are only required in cases of spinal cord compression or unstable injuries with an elevated risk of neurologic deterioration.
❌ Transfer to the operating room for kyphoplasty:
Incorrect: Kyphoplasty is a treatment modality for patients with refractory pain secondary to compression fractures after conservative management fails. The procedure involves injection of bone cement to “reinflate” the compression fracture, providing additional spinal support and alleviating pain. This patient has not yet undergone an adequate trial of conservative therapy, which should include pain control and bracing.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of two days of persistent nausea and vomiting. She reports fatigue and intermittent, crampy lower abdominal pain. She has been taking ibuprofen daily for the pain. She has no fever, diarrhea, or history of recent travel, but she does have a history of kidney stones. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, heart rate 96 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft with mild diffuse abdominal tenderness and without rebounding, guarding, or costovertebral angle tenderness. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) discontinuation and discharge

questions.solution:
This young woman of reproductive age who is sexually active with a male partner presents with acute vomiting and crampy lower abdominal pain, which could stem from various conditions. The history of kidney stones and NSAID use raises suspicion for urological or medication-related etiologies; however, pregnancy should always be ruled out first in biologically female patients of reproductive-age presenting with these symptoms. A urine β-hCG test is the fastest, non-invasive, and cost-effective way to confirm or exclude pregnancy, which could explain the symptoms and direct further workup for conditions such as hyperemesis gravidarum, ectopic pregnancy, or spontaneous abortion.

Formulating and prioritizing a differential diagnosis for an adult with acute vomiting involves considering gastrointestinal, gynecological (if biologically female), and extra-abdominal causes based on clinical presentation. Gastrointestinal etiologies include infectious gastroenteritis, appendicitis, bowel obstruction, and pancreatitis, while gynecological causes include pregnancy ectopic pregnancy, and ovarian torsion. Extra abdominal causes include increased intracranial pressure and metabolic disturbances such as diabetic ketoacidosis. Diagnostic testing (e.g., serum electrolytes, liver function tests, urinalysis, β-hCG, and imaging (e.g., CT scan, ultrasound)) should be based on the most likely causes.

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominopelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominopelvic ultrasound can be used to evaluate potential gynecological or urological causes of vomiting and abdominal pain such as ectopic pregnancy or hydronephrosis; however, a urine β-hCG test should first be performed in this patient who is of reproductive age.  
✅ Urine β-hCG test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis :
Incorrect: CT imaging is not appropriate as the initial step due to the risks of radiation exposure if the patient is pregnant. CT of the abdomen/pelvis is less specific for gynecological causes of vomiting and abdominal pain than a pelvic ultrasound, and it should only be performed after first ruling out pregnancy.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) discontinuation and discharge:
Incorrect: Discontinuing NSAIDs would be appropriate if gastritis was the cause of this patient's vomiting and abdominal pain. However, pregnancy or another gynecologic condition is more likely in this case, and pregnancy should always be ruled out in a biologically female patient of reproductive age prior to considering discharge.
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: Abdominal X-rays would have limited diagnostic utility in this scenario and would not effectively identify pregnancy or other gynecologic causes of her symptoms. Additionally, pregnancy should be ruled out in a biologically female patient of reproductive age to avoid unnecessary radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the right upper extremity. He describes severe right upper extremity pain. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On primary survey, the patient speaks in clear, full sentences, has bilateral breath sounds, and shows no evidence of significant bleeding. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 15. On exposure, there is a deformity to the right mid-upper extremity with two bullet wounds. There is a pulsatile hematoma over the right humerus, and the right radial pulse is absent. A plain radiograph demonstrates a displaced mid-humeral shaft fracture with retained bullet fragments. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Computed tomography with angiography (CTA) of the right upper extremity
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the humerus
Computed tomography (CT) without contrast of the right upper extremity
Arterial Doppler of the right upper extremity

questions.solution:
This hemodynamically stable patient presents with a humeral fracture and clinical findings suggestive of vascular injury (i.e., pulsatile hematoma, pulse deficit). Of the options listed, computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the most appropriate diagnostic test to better characterize the underlying injury pattern. If an arterial injury is present, CTA will reveal vessel cutoff or a vascular “blush” (focal contrast extravasation).

Extremity injuries may result from blunt mechanisms such as falls, crush events, and high-speed motor vehicle collisions or from penetrating trauma such as gunshot or stab wounds. Although many of these injuries are managed nonoperatively, those involving vascular disruption can be life- or limb-threatening and require urgent surgical intervention.

After completing primary and secondary surveys, adjunctive imaging should be used to clarify the pattern of injury. For most patients, a plain radiograph of the affected limb is obtained first to identify fractures, dislocations, or soft tissue swelling. Further imaging depends on the suspected pathology. For example, CTA would be appropriate for a suspected arterial injury, whereas an MRI is preferred when ligamentous or soft tissue injury is the primary concern.   

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography with angiography (CTA) of the right upper extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the humerus:
Incorrect: While this patient has evidence of a humeral shaft fracture, physical examination is also concerning for a vascular injury. An MRI of the humerus is not indicated for vascular trauma and would be contraindicated when metallic fragments (i.e. bullet fragments) are present. The best next step is CTA to evaluate for contrast extravasation or vessel cutoff.
❌ Creatine kinase (CK) level:
Incorrect: Although CK may rise in compartment syndrome, the examination findings do not support this diagnosis. Instead, the clinical presentation indicates vascular injury from penetrating trauma, most likely involving the brachial artery. CTA would be appropriate to identify contrast extravasation or vessel cutoff.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) without contrast of the right upper extremity:
Incorrect: A CT without contrast will better define the bony elements of the fracture pattern but will not provide information about vascular injury. CTA would be appropriate to identify contrast extravasation or vessel cutoff.
❌ Arterial Doppler of the right upper extremity:
Incorrect: Although Doppler ultrasound can offer some information on vascular injury, CTA provides more detailed arterial mapping for surgical planning and is the preferred imaging modality in this scenario.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall while intoxicated. The patient was found down at the bottom of a stairwell, having tripped while trying to walk to the restroom after sleeping in a chair all night. The patient drinks 8-10 beers daily and has a history of prior hospitalizations for alcohol withdrawal. Otherwise, there is no significant past medical history and no home medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 108/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 154/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On primary survey, the patient speaks in full sentences. Bilateral breath sounds are clear, and there is no active bleeding. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 15. Scattered abrasions are noted over the legs and back, and there is a soft tissue hematoma over the forehead. A full trauma workup, including radiographs and computed tomography, reveals four left rib fractures and a 3 mm left fronto-temporal subdural hemorrhage without midline shift. The patient is admitted to the trauma intensive care unit and is later observed to have impaired left wrist extension without overlying evidence of injury, deformity, or sensory loss. Neurological examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management of the wrist?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the wrist

questions.solution:
This patient has clinical findings suggestive of “Saturday night palsy” on tertiary survey, in which impaired wrist extension indicates a radial nerve injury. This condition most commonly follows prolonged pressure on the radial nerve at the spiral groove of the humerus, such as when the upper arm is draped over an armchair. Management is conservative, and most patients recover with a wrist splint and physical therapy.

Extremity injuries commonly result from blunt trauma, including falls, crush injuries, and high-speed motor vehicle collisions, or penetrating trauma such as gunshot or stab wounds. Although many of these injuries can be managed nonoperatively, some are life- or limb-threatening and require emergent surgical intervention.

After completing primary and secondary surveys, adjunctive evaluation should be tailored to the suspected injury. Plain radiography of the affected limb is the usual first step to identify fractures, dislocations, or significant soft tissue swelling. Further imaging depends on clinical suspicion (e.g., CT angiography for possible arterial injury or MRI for ligamentous injury). However, certain injuries such as nerve palsies are diagnosed primarily by history and examination and do not routinely require advanced imaging. All trauma patients require a tertiary survey to detect any injuries missed during the initial assessments.

Option Analysis

✅ Soft wrist splint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urgent electromyography (EMG):
Incorrect: EMG can be performed when a diagnosis of radial nerve injury is unclear or symptoms persist, but it is typically not performed immediately after trauma. Compressive radial nerve palsy (which is suspected in this case) usually resolves with conservative management and rarely requires further workup.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the wrist:
Incorrect: MRI of the wrist can be considered if there is concern for ligamentous or other significant soft tissue injury. This patient has no clinical evidence to suggest a localized wrist injury; instead, the history and wrist drop point to a radial nerve injury.
❌ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR):
Incorrect: Inflammatory markers are not necessary in the evaluation of a radial nerve injury. They would be more appropriate for infectious or inflammatory conditions, such as osteomyelitis or suspected myopathy.
❌ Ulnar gutter splint:
Incorrect: An ulnar gutter splint is used for ulnar-sided hand injuries (e.g., metacarpal or ulnar styloid fractures) but is not indicated in the management of radial nerve injury.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of large-volume bright red blood per rectum for 4 hours and lethargy. A caregiver reports that the bleeding began suddenly and soaked through two diapers. There is no history of fever, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, trauma, or recent illness. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 66/34 mmHg, heart rate is 142 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The extremities are cool with a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness or guarding. There are no visible anal fissures or signs of external trauma. A chaperoned digital rectal examination reveals bright red blood. Initial laboratory studies are displayed below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

 Laboratory Value Result
 Hemoglobin 6.8 g/dL
 Hematocrit 23%
 Platelet count 310,000/µL
 White blood cell count 12,000/µL
 Blood urea nitrogen 7 mg/dL
 Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL
 Prothrombin time (PT) 12.1 seconds
 Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 33 seconds

choices.text: Intravenous (IV) fluids and transfusion of packed red blood cells (RBCs)

questions.solution:
This child presents with large-volume hematochezia, severe anemia, and hemodynamic instability, as evidenced by hypotension, tachycardia, and delayed capillary refill. The sudden onset of painless, bright red rectal bleeding in a well-nourished toddler without fever, diarrhea, or abdominal pain is suggestive of Meckel diverticulum, the most common cause of significant lower gastrointestinal bleeding in this age group. The immediate priority is fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloids and transfusion of packed red blood cells to restore oxygen delivery and maintain tissue perfusion.

The ABCDE approach to acute hematochezia in pediatric patients emphasizes systematic assessment and stabilization. Management begins with securing the airway, assessing breathing, and supporting circulation. Intravenous access should be established promptly, and fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion should be initiated in children with signs of shock. Continuous vital sign monitoring is essential, and supplemental oxygen should be administered if indicated. Children with brisk gastrointestinal bleeding can deteriorate rapidly, so close monitoring for signs of hemorrhagic shock, such as tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension, is critical.

Option Analysis

❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: Endoscopy can help identify and treat gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly from upper sources. However, it is not appropriate as the initial step in an unstable patient. Stabilization must precede diagnostic procedures.  
✅ Intravenous (IV) fluids and transfusion of packed red blood cells (RBCs):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fecal occult blood testing:
Incorrect: Occult blood testing is unnecessary when gross blood is visible on examination. In the setting of hemodynamic instability and anemia, immediate resuscitation is essential.
❌ Intravenous (IV) proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy:
Incorrect: PPIs are indicated for suspected upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which can present with hematochezia in cases of brisk bleeding. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, and IV fluid resuscitation and transfusion take precedence.
❌ Observation and monitoring:
Incorrect: Observation alone is inappropriate for a patient with signs of shock. Immediate fluid resuscitation and transfusion are necessary to prevent clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of vague left upper abdominal discomfort for two weeks. The patient describes an intermittent dull ache without any identifiable exacerbating or alleviating factors. There is no recent trauma, travel, weight loss, night sweats, chest pain, or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for cirrhosis due to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, coronary artery disease, peripheral arterial disease, and portal hypertensive gastropathy. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, furosemide, lactulose, pantoprazole, and propranolol. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is left upper quadrant abdominal tenderness to palpation, but no palpable mass is noted. Computer tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen is ordered. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on CT imaging?

choices.text: Contrast-enhancing mass continuous with the splenic artery
Hypodense round fluid collection with rim enhancement

questions.solution:
This 61-year-old man presents with portal hypertension and extensive atherosclerotic disease (coronary artery disease, peripheral arterial disease) along with left upper quadrant abdominal discomfort, raising concern for splenic pathology. Among the answer choices, suspicion should be highest for a splenic artery aneurysm. This condition presents as a contrast-enhancing mass continuous with the splenic artery on CT imaging.        

Patients with a splenic mass or masses often present with left upper quadrant abdominal tenderness or fullness. While the clinical history can frequently suggest the correct diagnosis, abdominal imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) should be pursued. Common imaging findings for various types of splenic masses are summarized in the table above.   

Option Analysis

✅ Contrast-enhancing mass continuous with the splenic artery       :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hypodense round fluid collection with rim enhancement:
